column10:
Was great on release and just got a lot better since. Sure it was rather missing content in the beginning but so did The Forest. They released the game like that on purpose and they listened to the feedback, any issue or idea the community had was 1 month later in the game. As of right now the game features an enourmous open world island that changes every season. The building mechanic is insanely detailed, it reminds me of minecraft only imagination can hold you back what you want to build. There are many items, weapons you can gather which can make you kill basically anything but it only last till you have resources, making you collect loot if you wanna survive long enough. The game looks so beautiful and immersive that i would have a hard time telling if it's a screenshot from the game or just a picture of a forest, i couldn't take a single screenshot without any bird, turtle or whatever animal just chilling in the background. Also improved ai which makes the whole journey more mysterious the "people" living on the island usually are not hostile unless you make them or just feel like that. 

Great game would recommend especially with friends.

A human body is worth roughly 125,822 calories. It has roughly 10.6 kg of protein, or 15.1% of body mass. However, this would be if you ate every part of the body, including things like skin, bones and cartilage.

Edited review after last updates.
Some of the issues have been fixed and there is hope some others get adressed too.
---
Some not so important but annoying things:
- The building system is great and I enjoyed it much - but it has issues that need to be fixed, acceptable for early access, but not for full release (e.g. things are prevented from being removed that were not needed before). 
- It is impossible to hold a torch AND a weapon - but the extremly dim flashlight may be held?

Some really messy things:
- The inventory is very overloaded and spotting a recently found new item is a challenge... a and dropping things is only allowed for certain objects - so wanna give your multiplayer friend a pot? No, you need shelf to exchange it properly...
- Things are available for every character in multiplayer - picked up a pot? Your friend can also pick the same again. Leaving you with three times the resources - survival? Same with weapons and ammo....

Story is ... not very captivating, but ok like it was in the first part but with less emotional motivation. I liked the innovative building system and the idea and concept of Kelvin is nice, reducing the typical grinding to a very acceptable amount. I was totally not ok with the survival aspect - with "Green Hell" being my reference and having done this way better. I also lacked a bit the horror aspect of the first game, the cave design in the first part seemed much better and horrifying to me.
So summary: Recommended in general but for fans of the story, horror and the first part. You can have fun with exploring and the building in multiplayer but far from the perfection other comparable games try to reach.

Loved the original and this game builds on that great foundation. I really like the added features such as helpers which really make gathering resources less of a chore. I will be playing this game for years to come.
so boring after the 3rd hour

I like the game, everything is perfect, except nights it's super dark which I don't really like, you can't move, if night catches you while exploring it's super hard to go back to the base

Sons of the Forest, in my opinion, i think, is the best open world survival craft on the market. The level of detail is amazing. When i cut a tree with my axe, i feel like I am actually chopping the tree and moving around the trunk as i would in real life. I can use my crafted spear that i made and stab fish for food which i can then place on the fire and cook. I actually play this game on peaceful mode and enjoy the survival aspect of it rather than for the horror aspect. Graphics and sounds are beautiful. Animals behave like animals and don’t glitch or spin in silly directions. 

Also, giving Kelvin jobs to do is awesome and frees up your time, delegating those tedious tasks to him. 

Exploration is really well done too along with the story. 

Definetley a game worth getting if you enjoy open world survival crafting. A massive bonus if your into horror survival too!

A sequel that's been done right, The animations & the base building are greatly improved and the enemies are all updated in their beautiful grotesque glory, Plus many more new weapons and traps have been added, There's lots of places to find such as caves, bunkers, special locations, and navigating with just your GPS instead of a mini map really adds to the immersion imo, There's lots of ways to customise your single player experience from the many options before you start a new game which i am very grateful for such as
Changing how long or short the days are
How long or short the seasons are
How punishing the enemies and environment is
And turning off re spawning for containers 
I highly recommend the game if you are into open world survival/base building and horror, With a story line dropped in for good measure 10/10

It's much better than the alpha release.  Many QOL changes and new content.  If you haven't played since alpha, you may be pleasantly surprised.  "hard" difficulty enemies are currently extremely stressful even with a group of 3 to 5.  It creates a great challenge, but building up a homestead is much more work intensive. 
 That being said, Kevin helps a lot.  Building a base isn't as time consuming as before, but building a HOME will take a lot of time, and as seasons now exist, you cannot build over water and expect to live all year. 
 The lakes will freeze.  Currently working through the storyline, but will revise review as gameplay goes on.

This game is not good. 

The map is 4x the size of the original but that isn't a good thing when 90% of the map is nothingness. Traversal is also awful, the vehicles get caught on the geometry constantly and walking is far less annoying. The design of the caves look cool but most are just confusing labyrinths with an item at the end.

The game play is no different than the original other than the addition of guns. The guns aren't good and the view models are absolutely atrocious. The iron sights are so far away from the camera and are held from the bottom half of the screen which just makes aiming challenging not to mention looking ugly. There's also the modern axe weapon which clips through the GPS when you block which is just immersion breaking and obviously blocks what you need to see, probably isn't the only weapon that does this either. 

The original game is far better in my opinion and this game is a huge let down. The first game has a way better map that isn't congested with hundreds of thousands of trees and you could get across it in 10 minutes. This game tries to give you a wide range of weapons but most of them aren't good. It tries to "improve" building but now it takes hours upon hours to make a basic structure. The new enemies are cool but I don't think I'll complete this game anytime soon. This game isn't engaging and I often feel bored 90% of the time.

I tried to hold off on making a review of this game till I spent enough time with the content I could find.

At this time, I cannot recommend Sons of the Forest. This may be subject to change as the game is developed.
The reason is the content is still lacking. I can only hope it gets fleshed out as development continues.

The game as it stands, is the most beautiful forest environment I have ever seen in a video game. The foliage looks astonishingly real, and the caves finally look like a real natural cave system. The graphics really have been given an overhaul, which is great as I always found The Forest to look off.

Honestly beyond this singular aspect, I struggle with finding more positives to list here, as each eventually stems into negatives after longer scrutiny.

Yes the building system is a refreshing new take on how to do it in survival games, but what is available is not intuitive, and lacking in depth. I encountered a few of aggravating issues with building:
1. Certain full log posts I placed for my defensive wall would not be able to be cut into pointed tips, only cut into a 3/4 log. Even after picking up and replacing said log, still could not be cut into a defensive post.
2. Building a sloped roof requires leaving gaps where an angled wall needs to be, I had tried to put 1/4 logs, 1/2 logs, 3/4 logs and full logs into varying positions to fill the angled gaps, but nothing seems to work.
3. Firewood is apparently useless in it's current state(?) After doing enough building, I was left with a bunch of "scrap" wood logs, which I found out could be cut into firewood and stacked into piles. This seems to be a purely aesthetic purpose, as I have found no use for the firewood after that.
4. "Repairing" a damaged staircase removed a log and put it in the wall vertically. Was required to dismantle the entire wall and roof above it to remove the vertical log and replace it as the angle for the stairs.
5. Building a bed in a home you built doesn't appear on your GPS/minimap as a building icon like the tarp shelters do. I assume this is also a "home" mechanic as, after a reload, Virginia was stuck at one of my tarp shelter locations, and did not leave that shelter, even when I was at my main base for several days.
6. Certain log placements show as white, but when you go to place the log, nothing happens. It seems this might also be tied to a potential duplication issue as well. Building on certain slopes with snapping positions just do not work together no matter what you do.
7. To not have a bunch of dynamic objects around, I decided to stick extra 3/4, 1/2, and 1/4 logs in the ground as posts. Doing this I noticed they could be stacked on top of each other, but after a certain amount of time, they could no longer be stacked. This also happens with the firewood stacks, if you left one unfinished for a while, you cannot place any more on that stack, you have to dismantle it and rebuild if you want to put them all together.

Yes they detailed the A.I. system, but it is woefully underdeveloped in this current state.
Kelvin will chop down the tree you're building a tree shelter in. 
Kelvin will stop filling log holders and eventually just drop logs in random spots near empty and full log holders,
Kelvin and Virginia's pathfinding is atrocious. They continuously walk into/over, stand on, and lay on the firepits, log holders, standing crop plots, and basically any other object in their path
Kelvin trying to navigate a semi-open area to locate a single log holder is a winding maze at best, and a parkour climb fest at worst.
The cannibals have a degree more of A.I. than what was in The Forest, but in the end it all still boils down to whether or not you're getting in a fight at that time. 
You can't befriend any tribes, you can't have them fight against each other (as far as I could tell, at least) and once they're aggressive, there is nothing you can do to reverse it.
Some advancements in those areas would go extremely far I think.

The story, is incredibly confusing, vague, and absolutely unfinished.
There is so little there, and what is there is missing pieces, with extra bits that don't make sense.
I won't spoil it, but really, the only gameplay to speak of is exploring the environment itself, not the story.

After running as much of the map as I could, I find it to be a little too empty.
It's not as empty as most people seem to notice, as they think the majority of places to explore are marked on the GPS, which I will tell you now, there are multiple P.O.I. locations that do not appear on the GPS. I have found a crashed plane, an entire golf course, campsites, survey sites, not to mention the cannibal camps.
Though, it still feels too empty to be engaging enough.
As far as I can tell this island is meant to be, to some extent, a resort of some kind. Though I think it needs a bit more to represent that. Only the golf caddies and golf course really show a resort type of P.O.I.
Also, the caves are mostly empty, just 3 are actually worth going to, the rest being small (just a single room typically) empty of mutants and only containing crates of basic materials.
The cave system in The Forest was far more vast and complex than what we've been shown here.

At this time, I can only give Sons of the Forest 3/10, and do not recommend buying.
A beautifully flawed early access title, with a good foundation that *needs* building on.

I want to like it... hell I want to LOVE it...nope.   I just can't find a way to scrape out enough fun to even really get into the story.  My review is heavily based on enjoying the first game so much, and then trying this and it just feels like you took all the aspects of The Forest, and added 6 more tedious steps and mind numbing "Immersive?" ways of doing things.  Honestly if I hadn't played the first game, I might have liked this one.

I was so happy to get into the building, finally a part of the game that would make up for the meh up to this point.... nope.  I sounded like the dad from Christmas Story repairing a furnace 5 min in.  Logs of every size shape and split angle were strewn about uselessly as I tried to puzzle my way through my 2x2 shack construction.  Finally I gave up and decided to use the odd ends as firewood... then spent the next 15 min trying to figure out what mystical order I had to lay things in to create a bonfire (using the guide book for ref). 

All in all, nothing really felt good about the game to me other than the visuals.  The game play felt like an oddly floaty finger dance of g-f-z-x-c for acions.  Can't win them all, and this one for me is just a loss.  But I'll check out Grandsons of the Mountain or Daughters of the Desert as they drop.

I first played this game a year ago when it was released in early access and now have almost completed the game in 1.0. This game has evolved nicely and met all my expectations. 
Safe to say that this game is my favorite of the genre and definitely one of my favorite games of all time. It's the type that you don't put down once you've started it.

Also, I recommend to turn off AA if you're on 1080p. Your eyes get used to the lack of AA but the reason for this is that DLSS, FSR and all the anti-aliasing techniques are poorly executed with the upscaling techniques and AA looking blurry, except SMAA. However, SMAA looks exactly like how it does without anti-aliasing but it eats some of your FPS.

On a Buy, Wait, or Sale.... I would say wait. This is not a polished, finished product.

Unfortunately I cannot recommend this game on the 1.0 launch. 
Here is exactly why in a bulleted list why (Spoilers)

TLDR: 
- Travel is slow even with vehicles (doesn't feel like the game respects your time)
- You are punished for killing enemies instead of rewarded
- The open world can feel very empty especially before you get the re-breather/shovel(which good luck finding those without the wiki)
- You can only save at a camp

Expanded for those those on the fence about the game and for the devs if they'd like to read 
(love the devs btw, every game just isn't going to be for everyone)

1. The map is huge and travel is slow (I am aware of the golf carts and glider)
To expand on this, no one wants to have to run 30 minutes north, get excited that they are about to find something new and then realize that they need a shovel... this was one of the worst feelings and totally killed the exploration spirit. 
"Should I run to the next GPS marker... nah its probably something I can't even interact with yet... guess Ill go kill some more stuff.. oh wait that will make the enemies stronger..."

2. You are punished for killing enemies... the new scaling enemies makes it so now when you kill an enemy you feel like you screwed up instead of feeling like you accomplished something.

3. If you miss a key item in a cave you have no way of knowing it so that you can go back and find it. 
For example, with the re-breather in the cave up north, I felt I had explored the cave and continued onward to the next cave. 
This limited what items I could get as I ran/drove/flew around the map trying to find the re-breather (which you need for multiple other caves). This was extremely frustrating until I finally looked it up online (feels bad man) and realized it was in a cave I felt I already explored. 
To be fair, the path is probably obvious to the majority of people but it was not for me.

4. Still not a fan of the saving system, wish it was skyrim style (especially with the long distances)

For these 4 main reasons I cannot recommend the game in its current state. I did "beat" the game when it was originally released on early access with friends while this attempt I am describing was solo.

What a let down...bought on early access release, waited a year for "full' release.

Devs have created a running simulator with useless building mechanics, useless enemies and useless survival mechanics.

Let me explain: 
The story requires you to run from cave to cave, bunker to bunker to unravel the 'story', gather essential items til you hit the last cut scene.

Not once during this running around did I need to make a single building. Just used the first tarp they gave me to sleep in.

I just ran past every enemy, no need to fight at all.

Drinks and MREs littered every where so no need to hunt/cook.

Winter came along, a cold waning came up but nothing happened. No need to warm up.

Devs talked about hiring a movie actor to play a character. In game he has maybe 5 lines LOL. 

Very disappointed considering graphics are top notch. Crafting and building is solid, just pointless if your playing the story. Huge wasted potential. Do not recommend. This is not a survival game.
Pro Tip: Ask if someone saved before kicking them. Do not be an asshole.

Incredibly barebones, every trailer seems to have been false promises. Even graphically the game is no where up to par with what they showcased over a year ago. This just feels like The Forest with worse building mechanics, a worse menu and with more tedious animations and forced realism. Kelvin broke within the first 5 minutes of gameplay for us and has been stuck on the mountain the entire play time. Even for early access this seems rushed and empty. One of my most anticipated games of the last 2 years and my first experience has been really tainted by this release; they should have just delayed it again

1.0 edit: game is still genuinely not very good. huge empty world, materials and food thrown at you, inventory always full. you'll spend hours wandering aimlessly for seemingly no reason because outside of caves there isn't really anything to see or do. like others have mentioned, base building is pointless from a gameplay perspective as you never lack resources and can do everything from your inventory anyways. building is frustratingly "realistic", almost no creative freedom and you can't even do something as simple as lay blueprints to preview a potential build. i have no idea what the direction was with this one, seems all over the place and nothing really quite clicks
I enjoyed it so many times that my friends and I had to keep replaying it each time someone joined us

I bought SOTF when it first came out because I was a big fan of the original game.  It was a rough start.  There were a ton of QoL problems that I couldn't believe they released it in such a state.  I left a thumbs down at the time.

HOWEVER, the game was updated consistently and they improved these pain points and added new things here and there.  Some updates were more meaningful but it was great to see them working hard to get the game in a better place.  I have found a lot to love in SOTF since it came out and I still love it now. 

There is a lot of hate for this game in the discussions that bewilders me. I see people disappointed that V.1.0 doesn't have enough new stuff and I see a lot of people saying it was a cash grab. SOTF is different enough from the original both in appearance and mechanics to hold it's own as it's own title.  Is SOTF perfect? No. Is it finished? I sure hope not!  Is it worth the price tag?  Absolutely.

Played during Early Access, and I won't lie, bought it primarily due to the building mechanics and survival.

I haven't beat the story since I've been too focused on messing around and building to get through it, so I don't exactly have any insight on that...

GAMEPLAY aspects, however... the survival is great, and the building is awesome and diverse (you can build anything... cabins to huts to mansions. Your companion Kelvin, however, can't help with those unless it's a blueprint from the book)

Animals...? They're mid at best. You got squirrels, deer, rabbits, turtles, and a bunch more (less predatory) animals. Unless you count the sharks. The new raccoon is a nice step towards the possibility of land predator animals being added. 
I'd LOVE to see bears and wolves in the next updates.

But overall this game is a must-try even if you aren't a horror-person like myself. You can always disable specifics in the settings and it's nice how some things are optional to have.

My post 1.0 review is in progress. My old EA review is no longer relevant so I have deleted it.

TL;DR: If you're a "The Forest" vet and need more forest, the game is solid enough now. If you're not - it's still fun, but you need to go into this game with the idea that this is a "Forest" game, and not similar-looking survival games. The engine is enhanced vs "The Forest", but this game still has pulpy-jank that isn't for everyone, and is particularly geared toward co-op and fighting rather than wilderness surviving. You will either love it or hate it.

Initial impressions from an early EA build to 1.0:
- Performance is a little better, but still needs tweaking. Considering most of EA ended up being what feels like 70% content patches and 30% bugfixing based on the content patches, there's plenty of room for optimization - I'm sure that will come with time. I have trouble getting the outside world to run smoothly more than 60-70% of the time, but I am still tweaking my settings as I play.

- The huge world now has much more stuff in it. A lot of it is a bunch of static props that you can't actually interact with, but I'm okay with that. Environmental storytelling has and continues to be a staple of "The Forest" series. Certain caves have markers that help point you towards story locations, which I greatly appreciate. Too much of the map is revealed out of the gate, I feel, but I can understand balancing exploration with people who are genuinely bad at navigating massive game worlds. Having some caves revealed at the start is probably for the best.

- Survival still isn't that difficult due to the abundance of food / berries / low penalty for unpurified water, although now that containers don't respawn (they did before, cartoonishly trivializing survival) the difficulty feels more organic. Scarcity is a thing for the first time and it makes for a more interesting time!

- The soundscape is still a little off. Enemies often don't make any noise despite running at you like professional athletes through bushes, bats are still an inch over "tinnitus triggering loud" but not as loud as they used to be, and audio from certain enemies alerting to your presence sometime feels off - in that occasionally I'll hear them from MUCH further away than I should be able to, but sometimes it works correctly and I don't hear them due to distance.

I'll revise my review once I finish the story and collect most of the items & achievements. I recommend this immediately to "The Forest" veterans who want prettier graphics and a new island, but newcomers should not approach the game alone, or expecting another "Green Hell".

One of the best building systems in a game that doesn't deserve, respect, or need it.

Save system flat-out sucks ("but it only takes 10 sec to..." - then why make us do it!?). Inventory system is overly skeuomorphic and extremely inefficient. Keybinds while in inventory always feel wrong - can't even drag-n-drop to the craft area. Spears are abysmal. Items sometimes don't spawn, and you shouldn't save and reload in a cave to attempt to fix it due to other issues. Heavy increase in focus on fighting from previous game in series ruins the experience - 1000 enemies isn't as scary as 10. Many actions are overly tedious. Survival games don't have to be like this.

Most of my pre-release time was spent playing with their building system. Anyone who thinks tedious and annoying equates to hardcore will love this game.

 I have finished the game is here is what I have to say: Sons Of the Forest is definitely missing a lot of things.

 First, why remove the water collector? It was fine as it was in the other game and I do not think anyone would complain if it was a "repeated" thing and brought back here in SOtF. It worked well and was interesting in an aspect of survival; so why remove it? It makes the survival more realistic in my opinion. Also, getting sickness/damage from drinking water from ponds and rivers in the other game was a nice survival addition. Why is it not here? Is the water in this game all disinfected and cleaned?

 Second, I do not understand the removal of the log sled (as others have also said); it was something that worked fine and was a great concept. If the devs really didn't want to keep adding the same things into this game from the other one, then why not improve on the concept?

 Third, the AI doesn't *SEEM* to have improved. Maybe it has and my reptile brain cannot see it, but the cannibals and mutants do not have noticeable differences other than maybe a clan hierarchy or something. Something has to be said about Kelvin and Virginia. Kelvin is overall a good companion but can get stuck in rocks and other objects, and also completely do the opposite of what you want him to. An example I've seen of this is when you tell him to chop some wood for your tree house, and he instead chops down the whole ass tree you're building the tree house on. So much for advanced AI. Virginia has some interesting AI programmed with her interacting with you and slowly befriending you. I don't really have a bone to pick with her AI; there isn't really anything bad I've seen with her AI.



                                           !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!SPOILERS AHEAD!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!




 Fourth, the story is so fucking confusing. Who is this silver jacket guy? Why are we shown a futuristic alien city? Why does he randomly show up with other people when you are about to enter the cube? WHERE WAS HE THE WHOLE GAME? Why was Timmy and Eric Leblanc randomly fighting a giant ass monster in the middle of nowhere? Why are they here even? The silver jacket guy is shown at the beginning where they almost kill you, but don't. They are never brought up again in the game until the end where the magically come running down a few steps behind you when you head into the cube. There are so many loose ends and just things in the story that loosely are connected but overall just don't add anything nor make sense. It's a lot worse than The Forest and it's like only kinda connected to it lore-wise.

 Fifth, there aren't many new survival elements added. What I mean by that is: the survival aspect is not really improved upon. I understand it may be difficult to do this. But honestly, there just aren't many new plants that are different from The Forest, barely any new animals, and the seasons change wayyyy too quickly. There isn't even new buildings that help you survive or add a new cool survival element. It isn't that much different to The Forest in this aspect.

 Sixth, the game needs to be more optimized. A lot of people complained about its performance in the game.

Bugs I've experienced:
When Virginia is given a pistol with all your attachments on it, all your attachments are gone once you take it back.

Logs bounce way too fucking much in water and don't just gently float along it. I reloaded once and they started flying towards the stratosphere.

Some items still make a "kerplonk" sound when hitting the surface of a frozen body of water.

Sleds can be used to go into mountains sometimes.

You can walk into certain parts of the mountains because the textures go invisible for no reason.

My tarp tent randomly breaks when walking near it.

 Also, do not play hard mode. It's way too difficult. Monsters are just copy pasted EVERYWHERE and deal unfathomable amounts of damage. I got hit once by the twin mutants once and half my health was gone. Babies take 1/5. Oh and they are also damage sponges. They deal a shit ton of damage and take like none. It wasn't even the challenging type of fun. I just suffered.

In conclusion, this isn't to say the game cannot be enjoyed at this state. I had fun even with all of its bugs and confusing elements. I believe with some time and community feedback, the devs can truly make this an amazing game. But as it stands now, it is not finished and is missing a lot of things. It feels empty in a way and like there is nothing else to really do other than the story (which is also kinda shit :/..)

SotF is two, unfortunately very disjointed games, neither of which is particularly great on its own.

The first and primary one is an action/shooter where you explore caves and bunkers. They are always the same and have to be played in a predefined order due to each being locked behind a key item only found in the previous one, as a result replayability does not exist. While in theory it's supposed to be a survival horror experience, saving is trivial, dying merely respawns you inside the cave or in the nearest cannibal village, and resources are effectively infinite as loot respawns every time you load a save. Combat itself is not particularly fluid or engaging, and enemies mostly pose a threat because of how weak and clunky most of your weapons are. And the reason I said primary is because all progression in SotF is tied to those caves and bunkers - weapons, all kinds of resources, including a lot of basic ones, outfits and schematics can only be obtained there. While you can explore the open world instead, it's big enough to make sure you'll get stuck if you don't know what you're doing. Which is why SotF is played with a bunch of wiki articles and interactive map routinely opened.

The second game is the base builder, which is a pointless and entirely optional affair. Your inventory space is generous enough to make you never want for storage space, and everything you need to complete the game is readily available from caves and bunkers (you can live in either, making the need to build anything even more questionable) - and 9 times out of 10 is not obtainable by any other means anyway. All the crafting is done from the inventory, and the only crafting station capable of creating new stuff (3D printer) is located inside bunkers as well. While it's possible to do some base building purely for fun, even with the help of an AI buddy Kelvin this turns into a grind. Case in point: you want to build a small electric fence around the entrance to your bunker, about 30 segments, each requiring a piece of wire. You can't craft wire, so your only way of obtaining it is getting a respawnable one from the bunker. As such, you'll be able to get the fence done after mere 30 save/loads... yeah.

As a result, SotF tries to do two very different things at once, failing to merge them into a coherent gameplay loop. It lacks refined combat and resource management you'd get from Resident Evil or Dead Space, and its overreliance on getting stuff from caves and bunkers turns base building into a useless (even if somewhat elaborate) gimmick.

"The 1.0 update of 'Sons of The Forest' is fine, but I think it would have been better to include a new NPC.

I'm referring to a character that can accompany you in the caves; preferably, a mercenary similar to the one shown in the 2019 trailer. They don't necessarily have to assist in construction but should be a defense companion accompanying you in dangerous places, providing significant assistance.

It would be great if you consider this feedback, especially for those who enjoy playing solo.

[My Opinion on This Second Installment]

Regarding my opinion on the game, I believe it delivers on its promise as a good survival game. However, concerning the story, I find it ridiculous and unrealistic. Despite the game having great narrative potential, it seems that opportunity was wasted. The ending of the first 'The Forest' is, in comparison, ten times better than those offered in this second installment.

I understand the game doesn't aim to be extremely realistic, but they leaned too much towards the fantastical in the endings. Compared to the first game, which maintained a more realistic and enjoyable approach, this second installment lacks that coherence. The endings are disappointing, and although the narrative has potential, it fails to materialize satisfactorily.

If this comment reaches any developers, I want to express that there's still an opportunity to adjust those endings and make some modifications to the story. While it may sound bold to suggest this when everything is already well advanced, I believe it would be beneficial since I'm not the only one with this sentiment. I've seen many people criticizing the plot and endings, unfortunately."

"Additionally, I hope that in future updates, questions are addressed, such as: What happened to the rest of the team that came in the second helicopter? Who is flying the helicopter that hovers over the mercenaries' camps? Why do you only find the pilot's body and not that of your other companion, [FishEye]? Did they die or survive? And, I know this may sound trivial, but why doesn't our character wear a vest when in the introduction it is shown that they have one? Similarly, it should be worn and visible in multiplayer. I see that this is set aside and not discussed. Lastly, I would like to add that they improve the character voices a bit, specifically Timmy's. I noticed that the voice actor doesn't put in enough effort or get into the situation."

It is with great regret that I have to say that Sons of the Forest is a complete disappointment and went into a direction that essentially removes everything that the Forest so unique and special.

To be frank, Sons isn't necessarily a bad game but it is a lackluster sequel. The Forest managed to blend survival, action and horror together but in a unique fashion which enhanced the narrative and exploration of the island. Unraveling the mysteries of the island and exploring the vast interconnected cave network was an absolute blast. The added horror gave it a nice spin.

Sons looks marvelous with lush environments, offering superb vistas combined with an atmospheric soundscape. The island is large with diverse biomes and seasons which can be some absolute eye candy at times. Thankfully, the overall gameplay feels smoother with refined controls and animations. Some of the quirks have been alleviated and there are plenty of QOL features.

Despite this, Sons completely fails to capture the sense of dread and exploration of the prequel.Sons puts a larger emphasis on base-building and combat but I'd argue that these mechanics were never truly great to begin with. Combat is still clunky due to the AI being rather awful and with jerky animations. Enemies get easily stuck or float about, sometimes they won't really react at all.

For some baffling reason, the building has become more obtuse and needlessly difficult. Sons introduces a new system that allows for more complexity and player freedom. However, it's finnicky and borders on being esoteric when attempting to craft basic things such as doors.

Exploration feels flat as the island is simply too large and actually quite empty. The amazing and interconnected cave system of the first game is barely existent. Players have to contend with boring small caves devoid of any decent rewards. Even when exploring for the sheer sake of curiosity, there is barely anything to see. The Forest managed to create quite a mysterious setting with the various hints and clues strewn about the map. Sons has almost none of that and there is no real mystery here.

It's serious downgrade from the first game which always had enticing locales, caves and points of interest. Sons simply lacks the charm and intricacy. Locales are lazily scattered around with identical campsites with dull caves (with some exceptions). I cannot stress how dull the island feels compared to the first game.

One could argue that this game is more about survival with the objective of setting up a base with solid defenses. I admit that I never bothered much with base-building in the prequel mostly as there is no real incentive for it. Sons is no different and makes no effort in giving base-building some actual substance. The inventory size is still huge so there is no real use for a storage. Tents can be easily built while exploring and resources are abundant which renders most base facilities useless. Furthermore, the game actively punishes the player because building will cause the cannibal raids to drastically increase.

Perhaps Sons is more of a survival defense game where you fight off sieges with your buddies? In theory yes but the execution is flawed. The raids are manageable in larger groups but otherwise you will never have be at peace once you start building a fort. Pairing the less intuitive building system with the constant barrage of attacks ends up being an exercice of patience. In solo, it is a major pain as you have to juggle all these mechanics with the clunky combat. With a buddy, it's alleviated but still a struggle. It's decent in mp groups but then you have to wonder what Sons is all about.

This may be the core survival challenges of the game and a personal skill issue. Still, it doesn't feel like a gameplay challenge and more like a constant wrestling with awful mechancis. This aspect may be entirely subjective as some players will truly enjoy the advanced building system with the siege type attacks but honestly there are better alternatives to play.

Admittely, building could be ignored in the Forest. However, the exploration and mapping of the island provided a completely engaging experience. With Sons, you're being left with a game that has an inferior plot with a lacking mystery factor. Your map indicates all the important areas. Building can be entirely dismissed or is a rather frustrating experience. All the new gameplay additions are welcomed but don't provide a substantial upgrade to the first game. Sons isn't even [i]more of the same[/i] as it is just barren. The beginning hours are exciting but this feeling quickly fades. 

You may get a few good hours out of it when playing with a buddy. Nevertheless, I don't think that Sons has enough content or a decent gameplay loop to keep players hooked for an extended period of time. Your mileage may vary but I think it's a shallow follow-up to the first game. If Sons was intended as an open world multiplayer survival sandbox, there are better alternatives. If you want something akin to the first game, Sons is definitely not it.

trash solo play too hard

I really wanted to enjoy "Sons of the Forest" because I was a huge fan of the first game. However, this sequel feels like it missed the mark, especially when it comes to feeling like a finished and polished experience.

First off, the performance in multiplayer is just not up to par. I encountered constant stuttering and lag, which made it really frustrating to play with friends. It's disappointing because the multiplayer aspect was something I was really looking forward to.

Then there's the audio design, which feels almost non-existent. For a game that's supposed to immerse you into its world, the audio doesn't do its job. In a survival game, sound is crucial for creating tension and alerting you to dangers lurking around. Unfortunately, the audio here is so minimal and bland that it fails to enhance the gaming experience.

The enemy AI also leaves a lot to be desired. Their movement feels off, and they seem to have little to no recovery time between attacks. This often results in feeling overwhelmed, as enemies can continuously attack you without pause. It could be a matter of needing to improve my skills, but even so, it doesn't feel rewarding to keep trying, given the other issues at play.

I'm holding out hope that with more time and updates, "Sons of the Forest" could evolve into the game I was excited for. But as it stands, I'm left feeling disappointed. Perhaps in a year or so, with more development time, the game will reach its full potential. But for now, it might be best to wait before diving in.

My own opinion:
I would like to start off and say that this is one of the best open world survival games out there. The graphics are beautiful, the atmosphere is spot on and the game itself looks like it just got made by the unreal engine program. When i played the first game i liked how the story progressed throughout the whole exploration i went with. The Forest map were very interesting with the amounts of caves you could go into, and interesting buildings and structures, the inbuilt facility and of course the mutants and the monsters who were lurking in the shadows. The new sequel though is really good for it's early stage of development and even for an early access point it still holds up today with many things to do! This is very satisfying for me to see how serious this team is when it comes to their game and community. They are willingly to listen and have us help with their game by using our ideas and make it even better than expected, compared to when it came out on the first day of launch.
Important features that needs to be added to the game:
I think there are some ways to make this game even better. The island is pretty empty so it needs some buildings of course. Basically things to check out when found but still, for an early access i am very impressed indeed for it to have some content around, special areas to make you excited, but that depends on how long you actually walked towards this place unknowingly. They need to add more cut-scenes to the game and more voice acting. It is necessary because it will guide you to an easy understanding on what the game was actually about in the first place(going through videos and watch people explain it to you will ruin your gaming experience). More possible ways to build things too would also spice up some things. 
End of review:
I hope that the game will turn out super great when it's finished and i think this game deserves an 11/10 because of how great and awesome the story goes, how the game is built and why my graphics card hasn't been burned up yet when running this game. What a wonderful game with excitement!

vvv 1.0 Release Review (Day 1) vvv

EDIT: New dedicated server update broke the saves and potentially broke gportal server in general. I don't know if that's the game doing or the server provider. They also don't have auto server backup on by default.... Feels like early access all over again.

EDIT 2: We eventually somehow got a recovered save but this sh*t is annoying and messing up this whole experience of this game.

The game in general looks great visually with the graphics and animations but why the f*ck don't we have an auto save feature still. I was playing coop with 4 mates and I haven't played the game since early access release so it's been a bit, I played for 5 hours or so and it was late in the night, getting tired af and I was done for the night so I logged off not thinking there wasn't a autosave since that should be the norm these days in games but nope, lost a few hours of progress. Completely forgot this game has a manual save at every sleeping structure (beds/tents etc). 

Yes it is somewhat my fault for not realizing but also a bit stupid that a game in this day in age we don't have auto saves for survival games that take hours to do stuff especially exploring and games these days are prone to crashing. Also with the prompt of leaving the server, why don't you make the prompt more obvious and tell you that "Hey, you haven't saved in *such and such* are you actually sure you want to loose this progress?", which I thought was just a normal prompt saying "Are you sure you want to leave the game?" like every other game so you don't accidentally press quit.

Now this just in, my mate literally just messed up his save somehow when joining our dedicated server. He's not sure if he press New Game or Continue but he joined and it started him off in the helicopter again, and he 100% sure there was no prompts of starting from scratch. This game really loves to not tell you important sh*t. So I'm assuming we can just get our mates character save and import it to both of ours from the server files but I guess we'll see when he gets on since he owns the server. Again this game is great and all but cmon man, just give us quality of life things that actually matter. I experienced nearly the same thing in the early access game, this sh*t shouldn't be experienced again. So again this review is staying negative.

And wtf is this new jump pad thing, it launches you up in the air and kills you if you don't have a glider. Ok sure I can probs get away with that but it's absolutely not realistic but the fact you can use the unicycle on it and travel 1km vertically, no man that's fkn stupid.

And this just in again while typing this, my mate saved his game as a fresh character, left the game, rejoined and he's got all his stuff back from the previous save... Yeah this game makes sense.

vvv Early Access Review vvv

EDIT 2: The game is a weird somewhat polished letdown. The building system is really well done and the AI companions are pretty cool but the story is fucking dogsh!t. The end doesnt have a boss and it doesnt even feel like there’s any story at all. They show you this glimpse of this “story” but then it ends suddenly like it really doesnt matter until either the next game or update. So what was the point of putting “story” in in-the-first-place. Melee mechanics are still clunky af as the first game which makes it really annoying trying to kill mutant babies. Guns are cool but makes the game too easy. Overall it’s alright, they done a lot of things that are innovative then threw the rest out completely. So I'm still gonna keep the review negative since my overall experience was pretty meh.

EDIT: I've managed to use my mate's inventory save slot into mine and it works. I've tried enabling the dropped backpack in the config but as soon as I pick it up, it still has the no backpack issue. There must be a boolean somewhere in code that completely stops me using my broken inventory.

After 13 of playing 4 player coop I currently cannot properly progress in the game due to a game breaking bug.

I'm at the part of progression when I've got the shovel, keycards, pistol/shotgun, chainsaw and after running to my next point-of-interest; I got damaged while eating and stopped me from accessing anything so I died and after respawning and picking up my backpack some of my items were missing and some things I have that I haven't have before (felt like I was using someone elses inventory). So I saved the game and restarted to see if I can refresh but in doing so completely removed me having a backpack at all.

I've tried killing myself by either fall damage and by the mutants; and got one of my mates to kill me also but nothing worked. Everytime I try to access my inventory, it just says I need to retrieve my backpack. Tried restarting my game and validating but nothing works. I can still pick up stuff which says some things I'm full in and I can look at my gps; so my inventory is still technically there I assume but I'm being blocked due to not "Having a backpack" because of a random bug and it's impossible for me to progress any further unless I get someone to do everything for me which is impractical for myself.

At this point in time, this review will remain negative until it's fixed since it's literally stopping me from progressing.

Sons of the Forest has come a long way since its early access days. While initially captivating, it quickly lost its charm due to limited content. However, with the full 1.0 release, the game has undergone a significant transformation, offering much more depth and excitement. From expanded gameplay features to a plethora of new tools and weapons, there's now so much more to explore and enjoy. The freedom to build without boundaries adds a new level of creativity, while the storyline has become even more engaging. For me, it's a must-play, and I highly recommend experiencing it now that it's fully complete. The difference between then and now is truly remarkable.
The game definitely feels more alive in the full release. I do think its missing some things but I know they will add them in future updates. I would give it a 4/5 stars.

This is a good game, right off the bat I will say such. However it is very uninformative. The map sucks and is difficult to follow. The story (now that is finished), is disjointed and hard to follow. As a player who is not new to the game, I was able to figure my way around, but I fear for new players. The full release brings countless new additions that were much needed and really make the game better, however the misdirection is still the main issue. You will get a marker on your map for a bunker you cannot access, but you will not get a marker for a cave or bunker you need to do first to access said bunker. It leads to unnecessary amounts of "running around in circles", which is certainly a fault. Also hit boxes have not been fixed in full release, hits feel cheap and unfair, and your offensive hits will often not connect, melee is a mess still needing to be fixed. But overall the game is solid and worth a recommend, it is just simply not up to par with other survival crafting games, but still, however, better than the original in every aspect. And the game is utterly BEAUTIFUL, graphically it is one of the best in the genre.

1.0 is a serious DOWNGRADE to the EA experience I had a year ago when the game came out.

(Solo)
-Enemies are way too hard to kill now on normal. 20 stabs with a spear to a naked person is absolutely ridiculous, and they can kill you by slapping you 3 times.

-Enemies can just continue attacking you now even if they are taking damage. They also have action animations that can't be interrupted. 

-Weapon damage goes unnoticed by enemy/wildlife AI. ex. Throwing a spear into a deer's thigh only for it to sprint full speed into the woods, costing me a spear. Enemies largely do NOT react to having a spear penetrate through their torso or limbs, certainly not hindered by it. There's a few second knockback animation and it's back to business as usual.

-If you die you get one chance at a comeback then it's game over.

-I just spent an hour building up my base, just to watch an enemy walk into one of my traps and die, and instantly crash my game. All progress on my base lost entirely because saving is only done at beds on command.

-This game has to have the absolute worst vehicles I have ever seen. The golf cart handles like no one even bother testing it before putting it into the game, the Knight V is somewhat better but it's still a big yikes. The glider? Haha, good luck...

Honest Steam Deck Review 

Let’s get this part out of the way, the game is not enjoyable on steam deck. “Unsupported” for good reason, the control mechanics don’t work properly which completely kills the immersion. I’ve tried every community layout and only 1 kinda works but you still need to tweak it further and even then it’s just too much work pressing buttons and holding buttons etc. 

The game looks amazing for a handheld, I can play a pretty solid 30FPS on medium graphics which is a huge performance improvement since early access. That being said, the devs don’t plan on making this steam deck compatible so that just confirms to me that I will have to put up with the clunky controls. 

I’m still recommending the game but just not on steam deck. Play this on a PC. The story seams interesting, the environment is great, graphics are great, horror elements are fantastic. The game is good, I won’t write a negative review about a game that’s not designed for steam deck, if it even said “Playable” I would argue against that but it clearly says “Unsupported” which is exactly true. 

Don’t buy this on steam deck unless your willing to put up with cluttery button mashing or Bluetooth a keyboard and mouse.

As someone who greatly enjoyed the first game, I feel Sons of the Forest is an all around improvement in most areas, building upon the things that made the original good. 

One notable improvement is building itself. While a bit more tedious than before, placing down individual parts does make it easier to build custom structures, (although fences are hard to keep straight and placement targeting can be finicky). Having a helper can help reduce the tedium of collecting materials so long as you're mindful about what you tell them to do and where. Do not order him to cut trees in the area you plan to build tree houses.

Defensive buildings and traps feel more potent and useful than they were in the first game (in first game, wall spikes seemed entirely for show.) Making it easier to defend your holdings. Although you do have to make sure to maintain them after battle (your helper can be handy for this.)

Exploration feels more challenging than the first game. Caves are not the "clear and safe forever" simple jobs they were previously. While more linear in design, they can open up to very large areas unexpectedly and that can be disorienting. The island itself is far larger than the old penninsula, though there are a lot of interesting ways to help get around, like a motorized unicycle, and a foldable glider. The GPS helps a lot for getting around and avoiding getting lost.

Story, however, is where the game is at its weakest. While a "breadcrumb" narrative of mystery and discovery worked for the first game, the first game was much simpler narratively. Here, it feels like a considerable amount of context is not established or explained and that left me feeling a bit lost. I have yet to find every bit of story in the game, but some basic exposition that I feel should have been provided about key plot elements and devices: what are they and how do they relate to what's going on? Hopefully that's on some missing documents I've yet to discover, but if they're going to have voiced cutscenes, that stuff really should have been in at least one of those.

Still, the game remains a fun survival horror experience. I should caution people to keep their expectations reasonable, as this is one of three games so far flooded with people who had absurd demands. As a result, there is a considerable amount of misinformation. I can safely say what the trailers showed me, I ultimately found and got. And if you played the first game, you should have a reasonable idea of what the second game offers. Consider that and make your own best judgment.

Is it a proficient Action or Adventure game? Perhaps, but none of the individuals I know played it for these elements. The Forest, an immensely enjoyable survival game, consumed numerous hours of my time and stands as one of the best survival games on Steam. Consequently, when Endnight announced the sequel and addressed their extensive community of survival enthusiasts, the expectation was for an enhanced version of The Forest. Unfortunately, what we received was a subpar survival game with a heightened emphasis on Action/Adventure and a narrative-driven storyline. At no point did anyone express a desire for a mediocre blend of Action, Adventure, and Survival elements. Regrettably, I can no longer recommend this game; it has fallen off my Favorites category and will be forever lost and forgotten as a missed opportunity.

Sons of the Forest provides a very unique style of game play, you can either choose to make it face paced or slow by completing challenges, exploring caves, and discovering landmarks quickly or taking your time and building a lovely cabin in the woods.

What makes it stand out from the rest of the survival games I have played is that the visuals are fantastic. Each tree, shadow, rock, and animal is designed very well to make you think the game is real, even though the required specs for a computer may be a bit high its very much worth it. The games design is incredible and with how big the map is compared to the forest you always have something to explore even when you have completed the game.

On top of the exploration a huge part of the game for me is the building, it is very different than most games I have played with premade buildings that you cant edit onto or premade structures which you can attach onto but in both they are very limited. Sons of the Forest brings the flaws of both out and allows you to custom structures however you want but also making it realistic in the sense you need structural support and a bit of knowledge to make something even as simple as a cabin.

One last thing I like about the game is how the setting works, there is no one set season, weather, or even AI path, everything revolves around how you play. The seasons change dynamically and AI paths change all the time according to where you go and where you have been to never give you the sense of safety. In the winter water freezes and makes it a challenge to find a fresh source if your not near a river, animals don't go out as much meaning you need to stock foods. Everything in the game is so perfectly put into place it always give you a sense of "what will happen next" just like life and your constant battle to stay alive.

This is an amazing sequel to the critically acclaimed survival horror game "The Forest", which excels in every way from the original.  Things this game has improved on from the original: More realistic and in depth building and crafting mechanics, a more realistic survival simulation, hyper realistic graphics, in-game proximity chat which enhances realism and immersion, scarier monsters, new helpful ai companions which helps eliminate the monotony often associated with solo progression, and much more.  If you enjoyed "The Forest", then you will ADORE "Sons of the Forest."

Worst game of the Century
We spend 2 hours filling in a blueprint with logs and stuff. Then my friend chopped a tree down and crushed our house.

Building definitely needs some more tweaks and improvements to make things smoother and more expressive, but is otherwise a highlight.

Atmosphere is fantastic. 

Graphical fidelity is great - running surprisingly good on my relatively old hardware of i7 6700K and GTX 1080.

An option for a purely survival playthrough would be great. Like an alternate mode where you don't have (or don't start with) the GPS.

But yeah, if you liked the first, this is overall an improvement. If you like survival crafters then this already has enough content to while away some hours.

Edit: 1.0 is here!

The Story additions seem great so far, the extra 'things' (there's a lot) on the map are a welcome addition.

I still hold the belief that there should be a little less on the GPS right now (maybe as a toggle option in settings), intentional mission markers and lootable GPS tags are more than fair enough. But the 'vehicles' show up way before you actually discover them, and it kind of ruins the exploration. They're almost if not always by PoI's so you'd stumble upon them anyway, but as it is now you can just run about a bit with the map open and easily track them down. Because they add so much to gameplay, it'd be like putting map markers on all the weapons. I kid you not, within maybe 10-15 mins of spawning at the beach, I'd already found a golf buggy and glider that I otherwise wouldn't have know was there.

FSR 3.0 is a great addition. I don't know my exact FPS, but I now have the game set on ULTRA (1440p) with FSR 3 on Quality, and get very little if any stuttering and smooth frames, and my CPU and GPU are like 7-8 years old at this point. Endnight have taken an already beautiful, and wonderfully optimised game, and made it even better. SotF is really putting other current games in the genre (Enshrouded, Nightingale) to shame on these fronts.

The few new additions to building are welcomed, especially those platforms. I am greedy though, and would always love to see more to both prefabs, and the custom building, as the building in this game is an absolute highlight.

The new upgrades to the golf buggy are ace, but I feel like they should've been things we as players do, rather than them already being present. You find a golf buggy barebones. You then get the options to slap a solar panel on the roof, a radio in the front, an extra gps to the dash, hell, maybe even take up a back seat slot to add another battery. It'd go a long way to making a great addition to the game even better, and more personal. People would value the buggy even more if they had to put some work in to make it even better.

TLDR; I echo my previous closing statement. If you liked the first game, this is better in a lot of ways. If you like survival crafters in general, you're going to like this. It's all-round just a great game. And be it updates or new projects, I look forward to whatever Endnight gives us next.

its captivating blend of survival mechanics and horror elements. The game's immersive atmosphere, stunning visuals, and tense gameplay keep players on the edge of their seats throughout their journey. From the thrill of crafting makeshift tools and shelters to the adrenaline rush of facing off against grotesque mutants, every moment in the game feels impactful and engaging. Moreover, its compelling narrative and mysterious plot add an extra layer of intrigue, leaving players eager to uncover the dark secrets hidden within the forest.

In the shadow of dense, impenetrable forests, a world unfolds where the darkness of the night intertwines with the mysteries of the unknown. Sons of the Forest, the long-awaited sequel to The Forest, beckons players once again to enter the dark wilderness, a place saturated with tension and danger. As a fearless adventurer, I embraced the challenge to discover whether this game could live up to the lofty expectations.

The atmosphere of Sons of the Forest is truly impressive. The thick, ominous woods exude an elusive threat, with every shadow and rustle of branches keeping your nerves on edge. The developers masterfully utilized light and shadow to create a sinister ambiance that consistently gets under your skin. Even after hours of gameplay, the oppressive atmosphere remained undiminished, a testament to the power of immersion in Sons of the Forest.

The story is subtly interwoven into the environments, and the exploration slowly unveils the history of the island. As I roamed through the vast forests, I found cryptic clues and abandoned camps urging me to discover more. The narrative depth fueled my curiosity and motivated me to press on, without ever feeling forced.

One of the most striking aspects of Sons of the Forest is the enhanced graphical beauty. The island's flora and fauna are breathtakingly rendered, with realistic details bringing the wilderness to life. The day-night cycle adds to the dynamism of the environment, with the nighttime hours adding an extra layer of tension and danger. The moonlight reflecting on the trees and the subtle shadows swaying in the wind enhance the overall visual splendor of the game.

In terms of gameplay, Sons of the Forest offers a well-balanced mix of survival, exploration, and horror. Building shelters, gathering resources, and mastering survival skills remain core aspects, but new elements have been added to increase the challenge. Encounters with the local inhabitants feel more terrifying and intense than ever, and the struggle for survival is further intensified by innovative AI and an extensive crafting system.

The multiplayer options add an extra dimension to the gameplay, allowing you to survive together with friends in this ruthless wilderness. Cooperation between players is crucial, and sharing resources and strategies enhances the social aspects of Sons of the Forest.

Sons of the Forest has exceeded my expectations and firmly established itself as an immersive and challenging survival-horror experience. The combination of breathtaking visuals, immersive atmosphere, and improved gameplay makes it a worthy successor to The Forest. For enthusiasts of the genre, Sons of the Forest is a must-play that will pull you deep into the wilderness and quicken your heartbeat.

A shockingly impressive 1.0 release. I'd been playing with some friends on and off throughout early access, with various issues here and there, though the game remained quite fun. For 1.0, there was quite a lot new added, and we noticed almost immediately upon starting a new world. The biggest difference though was that I had had various issues with performance throughout the entirety of early access, better and worse through various patches. Yet for 1.0, I noticed zero performance issues. The level of optimization that went into 1.0 is impressive. I would have been hesitant to off a rec for this in EA due to performance issues, but even with my ancient PC, it runs smoothly.

I enjoyed the game at the release it was something that i was dreaming for a long time.
Especially when "The forest" was such a banger even at the release.
But in reality...

This game is total failure not gonna lie, why?

There are a couple of reasons.

Firstly the map
That is huge, yeah huge but empty even after 1.0 update you walk and walk and walk through the map and find absolutely nothing.
Also you need to run whole map to get something that storyline requires then run again to the other edge of the map to do the same XD.
They added a knight V and golf carts which are useless because if you want to travel you have to drive arround this big mountain.
We cant even attacht the log holder or something else to golf cart to make it usefull somehow.
They should add Helicopter or i dont know maybe the plane to be able to fly over this mountain. 

AI which is not even improved in over a year the NPC's are still dumb and the enemies are more stupid than you can think.

Combat system that is embarassing and terrible and even worse than this from original "The forest". 
The initial idea to add the modern weapons to game was great but cause we're livin in XXI century.
Its kinda funny cause when you get the pistol which is so simple to achieve you're becoming OP not gonna lie the weapons are OP
but the problem with them is that u need to have a lot of ammo which is not that easy to find.
Yeah weapons are extremely strong so when you gain a pistol or a shotgun or even a sniper rifle the melee weapons are completely useless.
Cannibals can block ur attacks when you cant block theirs XD.

The idea of building system was also greatfull but in reality it sucks because you have to use the patterns to build something.
The building system is just limited in "The forest" you could build whatever you've wanted without fear of limiting your ability to place logs.
New system just makes building harder.
Also the basic structures from the first part of the game are not implemented in the second part for some reasons.
The electrical system that is incomplete and its not what we need ingame.

Endnight games is focused on the story when the gameplay is the thing that as a players we want.
It has to be improved who ffs is playing SURVIVAL GAME for story. 
We need gameplay features cause game is just boring and repetitive.

The game has such a big potential but we need updates we need specific updates to make the gameplay more enjoyable that it is right now.

If you want to buy the game i advise you to wait one more year cause is incomplete.

When I was diagnosed with a rare form of testicular cancer one of my biggest worries was never getting to play the sequel to my favorite game of all time: The Forest. Fortunately the game launched within what my doctors told me was my final week of life. Even stuck bedridden with my groin the size of my head I was still excited to play the game. I launch with tears in my eyes. This might be the last game I ever play in my life and I just know that Endnight Games will deliver. As soon as I open my inventory after the intriguing intro, my game suddenly crashes. I go to close the game proper but my mouse freezes. A nagging beep sound echoes from my laptop. Doctors rush in believing my vitals have gone dark. Instead they find me sitting there dumbfounded that the sequel to my favorite game is this broken. I go to open the game a few more times and the same thing happens. 

This very well might be the last thing I write. The Sons of the Forest will most certainly be the last game I play. I just wanted it to be an unforgettable experience, but the game is just too buggy at this stage. Unfortunately, this is my final stage. 

Goodbye. I hope the game gets fixed so nobody has to go through this pain I'm feeling right now.

There is no universe in which this game will not need a metric TON of work to even scratch the surface of being considered “good”. What started off as a fun and hilarious return to The Forest franchise turned into hours, upon HOURS of completely insufferable slog to the very end. After a failed group playthrough and a second attempt where players dropped one by one, the only thing that kept the rest of us going was purely the sunk cost fallacy. Prior to the full release the game had a pattern of crashing at the most inconvenient and horrible times, forcing us to replay sections over, and over. At no point is Sons of the Forest intuitive or easy to navigate. We were right at the end of the game before 1.0 released. Opening the game again we encountered horrible optimization issues and were unable to get to the very end to FINALLY be done. At the end of the day after 40 WASTED hours we had to abandon it. An absolutely wretched experience all around. One of the worst games I’ve forced myself through playing ever. Save your time. Save your money. DO NOT GET THIS GAME.

Genuinely, the game is a solid follow-up in regards to being a successor to The Forest. Top comments I have for it: the building. Building, while similar to the Forest, is alot more diverse and interesting. In all fairness it's been years since I've grinded some hours out in Forest, but still, the nostalgia factor was there. Just something about making communes in the woods with your buddies is great. Graphically, it's a step up from the original, firing this bad boy up for the first time was certainly an eye opener, and made me glad I'd just upgraded my graphics card. Settings cranked, didn't skip a beat and i was honestly impressed.

The downsides: Combat. After day 30 in game, combat becomes really becomes rinse and repeat-y. Cannibals get bigger and stronger, mutants become more abundant but... its not exactly engaging like the first game. The first one's combat was alot more "adapt-or-die" to where as this is just "lay-traps-and-build-walls". Doesn't make you get creative with ways to start mulching cannibals. Next grievance: [spoiler]the final boss. Man. MAN. That was such an underwhelming fight. I remember spending literal WEEKS researching new strats to try and merc her. The feeling of accomplishment afterwards was honestly something to hold onto for a while. But this one? Killed him in two minutes. The final cutscene? That had me at the edge of my seat. Then Mass of Flesh comes out and I was just kinda like "... well thats something." I was so let down by the final boss. So much so, it left a sour taste in my mouth. Lore-wise, yknow, in the first one it made sense. Fighting to save Timmy or fighting to save yourself. But from a storytelling standpoint... why was Jianyu even the final boss in the first place? What was his driving force? Besides being a Saharan op, but.. is that it? Honestly let down by the ending. The end is supposed to be the cherry on top, the final clash,  but this. This one does not spark joy. For me, anyway.[/spoiler] Overall though, multiplayer is good fun and pretty seamless, the walkie is a good system, hang gliders and golf carts are busted. Shout out Virginia. Kelvin, the only reason I kept you alive was because I needed a stick bitch. 

Overall Score? 7.5/10.

The game is amazing, and from what i've seen pre 1.0 release, everything has been going smoothly. My laptop could run the game at medium graphics without lag, but after the full release, i can't even play it at ultra low settings anymore.

There's two ways you can play this game:

1 - Bounce from POI to POI. Collecting food and drink as you go. Go straight to caves to collect needed items. Kill mutants, beat game, done.

or

2 - Try to actually build something, and play like it's a survival game.
Get harassed by locals. Stop to kill. Killing needs calories, so eat and drink. Go collect logs. Get harassed by locals. Repeat past steps 8-10 times, until ugly log cabin is built. Go get canteen, hunt food, get harassed by locals. Kill cannibals, burn bodies, get harassed. Stop, burn bodies, kill cannibals. Burn bodies, collect logs, kill cannibals, etc, etc, etc...

Actually trying to enjoy the game's survival mechanics is the most unfun and monotonous activity I've ever experienced, in a game. Which is a shame, because the game is so beautiful. AND NO, I DONT WANT TO TURN OFF ENEMIES. It's part of the game. It just doesnt need to be this excessive. Hell, the enemies aren't difficult, AT ALL. It's the constant pestering while you're just trying to enjoy what the game offers you to make.
It literally forces you to just... do the story, and thats it. The game rewards you for just cave hopping. It gives you endless supplies and you never get harassed, coz you're never in one place long enough.

I really wanted this game to be fun, but it just isnt. It's very thematic, ominous, and sometimes breathtaking. None of that matters, though, if all your game mechanics are designed to push you into content. Let me decide when I want to do stuff. Don't send your endless hordes of respawning mobs at me. It's a really dumb system that ultimately ruins the game, for me.

A finished game

Damn Endnight, you guys did it again! I'm not gonna lie I was starting to get worried maybe this wasn't going to live up to the Original game while watching it grow in EA, but I'm glad I was wrong. They stepped up everything that made the OG Forest good and fun and made what is shaping up to be one of my personal favorite survival games, just like The Forest was in it's day. 

The combat is a big step up from the Original as there are more enemies and weapons and traps to kill them with, as well as traversal being more engaging and important in this sequel because the Island you play on is HUGE! (There's a foldable Para-glider you can use anywhere, Electric Unicycle thing, a Hand Gun, Shotgun, Tazer, Clubs and etc.) So Getting around is easy and fun even though the map is very large. The Island is also full of detail and interesting POI's that often tell gruesome but sometimes funny stores. 

The first Forest was a Masterpiece so this had big boots to fill, and it filled them. Buy this game if you love Survival/Horror. If you loved The Forest, you should already own this!

Visceral and just as much fun as the first game. Intuitive and creative construction system and beautiful graphics.

Negatives: AI Pathing and behaviour can be frustratingly stupid i.e tell friendly AI to collect wood to build a treehouse on a marked tree -> ai proceeds to knock down the exact tree that the blueprint is highlighted on.

Storyline is a bit of a mess because you will undoubtedly explore and come across random segments of storyline and have little to no idea what is going on.

Cave side events (Whether you died and were captured or if you found a hidden cave entrance) are great; cold, dark and ominous however certain AI are extremely difficult to kill even after exhausting the little amount of ammo from your handgun, bow or grenades. Especially the enemy AI that have two human legs and then a large sideways mouth with huge teeth for an upper body- They are such a pain in the arse to deal with and not in a fun way.
