When I had only about 3 hours in the game I left a negative review but after playing the game for around 8 more hours I can say my opinion has changed so I'll do a detailed review. I'll be rating different parts of the game while comparing them to the first one.

Story and premise:
 
"After the ending of The Forest where the player revives Timmy via crashing another plane (and the subsequent talk show), an apartment scene is shown from the adult Timmy's perspective. It appears Timmy has decided to research more about the Peninsula, and discovered another island which he designated 'Site 2'. It is assumed this is where Sons of the Forest is taking place. At the end of that scene, Timmy is revealed to still be suffering from side effects from the Resurrection Obelisk but fortunately has not fully mutated like Megan Cross."
"There are three openings to the game. One in which the player's helicopter crashes over the forest. The player is stuck on a tree. Shortly after, the pilot attempts to leave the helicopter and falls to his death. Another opening involves the helicopter crashing in the snow. The pilot is seen dead while the helicopter is crashing and rolling down a mountain. The third opening is the helicopter crashing into the ocean. The player wakes up on the shore. Each opening involves a man in a silver suit hitting the player rendering them unconscious."
-Sons of the Forest wiki "Story" page. https://sonsoftheforest.fandom.com/wiki/Story
I find this premise very interesting and I'd like to see how it progresses, I'll update this section more when i finish this game.
Overall 7.50/10

Map:
SOTF has a map around 4x times bigger than the one in the first game. This an upside but also a downside, the map is more detailed and has more zones but I often find useless caves or zones who seem important but aren't also, I may not have gotten to that point in the game yet but I don't see an objective that is as clear as in the first game. In The Forest you could tell from the beginning that the sinkhole was important but in SOTF the objective isn't as clear even with waypoints and stuff.
Overall the map get a 8.5/10

Enemies:
The enemies in SOTF are similar to the ones in The Forest, you've got cannibals and mutants. The cannibal AI is a bit better but the fact that they 1 shot you is pretty annoying and most of the times they just sneak up on you with no warning or even any way to tell. It also kind of annoying seeing 1 cannibal destroy and entire mansion you spent 5 hours building in 5 seconds.
The mutants are also kind of the same as in The Forest but they have slight changes, the mutants are much more on the scary side instead of the gory and gross side that was in The Forest. The mutants still do gross things but they aren't as macabre and now sneak up on you and you barely get time to see them in their fullest.
Overall the enemies get a solid 7/10

Survival:
In this game resources and water sources are more well distributed because of the bigger map, you won't have an actual mental breakdown while looking for drinkable water now :)
Cutting trees and gathering rocks and sticks feels more realistic in this game with more in depth mechanics.
Food is an active problem, you have to build your house near a pond or lake or else you will just die of starvation if you don't go out hunting.
In this game you also have a companion, Kelvin. He is one of your fellow comrades who lost his ability to speak and hear so you have to give him commands using a notebook. He can search for items and food, help you build, make you campfires and shelter and best of all be your loving companion :)
Overall the survival part of the game gets a very respectable 9.5/10

Building:
Building in this game is much more in depth and improved than in the first game. You can make your own houses with no blueprints and much more. The only downside is the fact that at least up to the point that I got to in the game there are no roller coasters like in the first one but i guess it's fine since they got replaced by ziplines.
Overall the building aspect gets an 9/10

Combat:
The combat feels faster and much more focused on just surviving then actually having a fair fight. Most of the times you'll find that running is much more efficient than fighting. There is a large selection of weapons that are good at different things. Cannibals can also be scared off and be worked around a lot more. With all that the combat still is based on how fast you are and how accurate you can get.
Overall the combat gets a 8/10

Multiplayer:
The game is more fun with friends but if you don't have any Kelvin is still good company. The game feels more fluid with friends, you can all work together and go together on adventures or you can all be on your own and try facing the dangers of the island while trying to race against eachother.
The multiplayer is a bit better than in the first game and it gets a 8.5/10

Sound/character design and graphics:

The characters and enemies are interesting and the enemies have scary designs, the sound design is good but ti can be improved in some places. The graphics are amazing but you need a pretty beefy computer to run it well. I have an GTX 1070 and an i7 6700k and with a bit of overclocking and some settings changed in the Nvidia control panel I can play on High settings with around 60-90 fps. I can do a guide on the settings I use for overclocking and on the Nvidia control panel if you want. You need the latest drivers to run this well.
Overall: 9/10

Fun:
It is just an all around fun game, I really don't have anything more to say than that.
Overall 9/10.

The game overall:
This game adds to the first game perfectly and improves most aspects of it refining mechanics and adding new and fresh stuff. This game is still in early access and isn't yet finished, but it gets regular updates and I think that the finished product will be really good.
Right now it depends on if you liked the first game enough or if you like survival games enough. If you do the price is fully worth it.
The game gets and overall score of 8.4 I am sure the score will improve after I finish the game and it gets more updates but until then this is all I can give.

Love, Pancake :)

WALKIE TALKIE NEEDS TO GO!, but seriously you could still keep the walkie talkie has a simple on off mechanic for the mic but it should always be on and be able hear/talk to people,(if you want it to be realistic then why does my character have to use his left hand while using it could just have it strapped on back pack/vest like normal person would irl) but bec of this u need the ability to mute people individually which u already have a players tab.

Might give this game another try.  We did "finish" it in Early Access so it's very likely things have changed a bit.

That said, as far as our early access experience goes we have a few main frustrations:
- Didn't seem like building a base was very useful or important.  It was "fun" I suppose but no real point.
- You can effectively beat/finish the game just by running around to objectives and stopping to make a quick fire fill your bars up.
- Seems like you can find enough food/water and other supplies to finish the game without actually using the building/crafting system much at all.

I think this game could have a lot of potential, but it feels like they spent more time making some cool systems and features and forgot to tie all of them together into a full gaming experience that requires you to use all your "tools"  (building/crafting/etc) to survive and escape.

Sons of the Forest is a GOOD game but what makes it so frustrating is that its SO close to being a truly GREAT game. Put simply, apart from gathering weapons and base building, you soon feel like you're out of things to do. With a game world this size that is this detailed, it feels like their should be a lot more to do. Also, how are there no boats/rafts yet? Why is there no PvP mode? Why does the OG forest feel more 'alive'? 

All that said, I'm looking forward to the full release, which I hope will address some of the above. If not, this game may serve as a an example of a very promising start that was squandered.

Great game.  I usually get frustrated with survival games.  Mostly due to stupid item degradation and annoying "grinding".  This stays fun all the  way to the end.  Cave don't feel randomly generated (because they aren't) or similar.

As of writing, I only have 25hrs in the game. That being said, let's get into it.

First impressions are huge, and I'll be honest: the loading screen SUCKS. My system is 3800x ryzen 7 w/ water cooling. X570 mobo, and as of a year ago, the fastest nvme drive on the market: wd black pcie 4.0 nvme. I also have 32gb of Corsair vengeance ram, so when I say I have to wait about 5 minutes on the loading screen for my game to load, you KNOW it's slow 

With that out of the way, there are a TON of positives. The new free building mode is a MASSIVE upgrade from The Forest. Seriously, I can't state how good this feels once you understand it! It did take me around 15 hours of tinkering to become "decent" at building. Some things take forever to build, and would benefit greatly from being able to 'queue' actions -- like making sharpened fence posts. You have to cut them all 1x1 which can take forever depending on how long your fence is.

Combat feels satisfying, and the AI has been beefed up too. This time around there are WAY more ranged options -- and you can customize most of them. This makes the weapon system feel more immersive vs the forest which felt more like "stat sticks".

All in all, I'd definitely recommend this game. I'm personally hoping they add the UI scale slider from there first game as there is currently no way to customize the size of any UI elements

Overall, I LOVE this game and cannot wait for more updates. Just please don't do an EA and put out "DLC" and make us pay for them. UGH that is so annoying. Anyway the forest two is SO worth it.

*UPDATE* I bought the game again and gave it another chance. Yes, the graphics are beautiful and the crafting system is like nothing I've seen before. However, the plot is actually GARBAGE. To make friends with certain individuals is something that I couldn't do until day 43, even though I was doing everything that I was supposed to. The weather sucks, not enough mobs spawn when you're past day 40, and there is no motivation to hunt, craft, dig, build, collect, or literally do anything. 
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
*OLD REVIEW* As the game stands right now the game is nowhere near ready. The animations are beautiful but become more of a burden when 10 cannibals are attacking you as you take 15 seconds to make a stick covered with tape. Just give this game a year or two, and play The Forest if you have an itching for cannibals to chase you on an island.

I HATE the cave bits, I find it really depressing. There's only one kind of fish you can hunt, small animal traps are never explained and don't work. Creating a defensive wall takes about 50 hours, and it doesn't work well. You can't drink water from any natural source without sacrificing health, even if you boil it, so the pot you collect seems to make no sense. There are large areas of the map that seem to have nothing - they're just there for the sake of it. Finding your own bearings is difficult. The best parts are Kevin who can collect resources for you but is absolutely effing useless for anything else, Virginia can fight people, but it's very buggy. You can collect x10 aloevera, which would not exist in this Alaskan inspired landscape, and not get a seed to grow it your own, at least on my playthrough. The survival guide is really odd, some of it you have to create from scratch, others you can place down a shadow thing of it, and Kevin can fill in bits of it, since he can't work out how to use tape or rope, and seems to have suffered a severe head injury given the blood outside both of his ears at the beginning. 

This game could benefit from more NPCs or some kind of narrative that you have to discovers from pamphlets. You are essentially thrown into this world with nothing and have to gradually figure out what happened. 

For me. I enjoy killing the cannibal guys and burning their bodies to get their bones. If I could torture them and try to learn their dumb language (I guess it's Serbian) that would be cool too, but for now I just walk them into traps. 

The Cannibals seem to be based on Serbians for some reason, it's not entirely inaccurate but I imagine is offensive to Serbs.

I'd give it a mixed review if I could. Exploring is fun, the crafting system is expansive, and the combat is serviceable. Overall a solid open world survival game with well-functioning online co-op.

The primary thing I don't like is....what am I supposed to be doing? Like why am I here? What should I be doing? What is the end-goal? Feel like I'm just wandering around aimlessly and mostly finding copy/paste camps. Occasionally there is a cave with something more interesting. Is that the objective? to explore all caves and get their unique loot? Why is all the interesting loot only in caves? Aren't there other geological structures that they could have done anything with???

The other thing that bothers me is that the crafting system has zero tutorialization and doesn't follow a standard template. You just have to mess around to figure out how things work. Every item - try left clicking and right clicking, and holding click, and using it against various structures or the ground. A simple log can be used dozens of ways depending on where you are standing in relation to the log, what you have equipped, what you are looking at while holding the log. I wouldn't mind if I was holding the cooking pot and it just told me straight up - left click to drink, right click to dump, E to place on campfire to cook, E to fill at water source. But no, you just have to figure it out. And some actions are somewhat counter intuitive against the actions of another item. Like some melee weapons can right click to block, others can't. Electrical items, like stun baton, how do they recharge? Not with your solar panels. Well they just expend consumable batteries automatically and don't ever tell you they are using batteries. Why is everything so confusing?

Now that I have played Sons of The Forest for a while, I am finally ready to give a review. If you played The Forest, this game is a must play. It takes all the great and scary things from the first game and puts it on crack. 

If you are new to The Forest series I still recommend this game. Get your friends together and try to survive in the scary but yet hilarious forest. It is the perfect combination of tense creepy moments and funny moments when trying to build your base, hunting for food, or just exploring.

The only negative I have to say is the amount of content. First playthrough is great, but once completed, there is not much left to do. I hope this will be changed when the full release arrives. And add more achievements! It is always fun to get achievements.

So, it's a great game like it's predecessor. I bought it in december of 2023 when it was in the final version of the early access. Many people has said that this game is a running simulator. Yes, that's partly true. The map is VERY big. Four times bigger than the original The Forest map. On the first playthrough of the story I really didn't mind running across the map exploring it at the same time. The map offers you SO many exciting places with great graphics. The woods and the overall nature looks so good and it's fun to explore.

The story will change when 1.0 version releases but in early access it was still great. I will update this part of the review when I have completed the 1.0 story.

Gameplay is very good. Movement is great and controls overall feel good. There is veeeery much different equipment and items you can collect from all around the island. The game has many guns etc. to help you out in killing enemies. I even stopped using them at one point because they just made the game too easy. In the early access it was possible to farm ammo and therefore I had over 500 rounds of each ammo type. 

Graphics could be better. I mean they are so so so good and I play on ultra settings but still I feel like they could be better. Maybe they will upgrade in 1.0.

Couldn't really think of many downsides :D Some bugs. For some reason when you press crouch, the character won't sometimes get back up and he stays crouched for some seconds even though I have released the crouch button.

Idk how to write good reviews but overall a great experience. I RECOMMEND YOU BUY IT B)

Impressive and immersive game. Almost gave up due to high difficulty surviving, but I toughed it out, acquired more equipment and resources, and was blown away by the natural exploration based progression system where you acquire more and more tools to make survival easier, leading to an impressive tone shift from survival horror to post apocalypse as you begin exploring the island's underground bunkers. Highly recommend. One of the most engrossing survival horror experiences I've ever had. That this is open an open world that blends exploration, survival horror, survival mechanics, and crafting so well is also a remarkable feat by these devs. I am hooked.

It is so sad that I cannot recommend what was my most anticipated release for so long. The original Forest is in my top 10 favorites, I think it is absolutely brilliant, and while I had my reservations about the abundance of guns in the sequel, I was excited about all of the other features the devs promised. 

The devs announced this game would only be an early access release less than a week before it came out, which blindsided everyone. Even worse, the game released in a very very basic state. Not even a fraction of the things you can build in the first game are available in this one, the number of blueprints is so limited that it feels pointless to play when the first one holds up so well and has SO MUCH more content. Their strategy is to slowly release items one at a time, which means there is NEVER a good time to jump in-- what are we going to do, jump in build the one new thing and then go back to waiting? Many of the new items are janky and barely function, like the hang-glider which is not even worth messing with. 

All of the above could eventually be forgiven-- presumably the game will eventually release and have sufficient content, and the bugs can be fixed. However, what cannot be fixed is the massive, bland and boring map that is difficult to traverse and feels auto-generated. The island in the first game is the perfect size, and each area has unique landmarks to help convey a sense of space. This island is utterly empty and the mountain in the center makes it difficult to get around what is already too large of a gamespace. I don't know how they could fix this problem, but it is bad enough to potentially be a deal breaker for me. They had the chance to make a lovingly crafted or at least curated space that you get to know through exploration, but they chose to take the easy route. The map is also just vertically too tall, you have to skyrim up many of the slopes, and even the top of the mountain itself is just a blank texture with 0 landmarks, like they hadn't even realized the player would go up there. 

The other absolute miss with this game is the new building system, which is truly awful. Instead of the sleek Rust style construction, they have chosen to go with a realistic and highly complex custom system which is utterly tedious and difficult to use. I find myself dreading building anything because you can't even just lay out a custom blueprint and add to it like before. Even simple objects need to be crafted via a needlessly obtuse and intricate new method that is just time consuming and not fun. I wish they had just improved on the system they already had. 

There are a lot of positive things to say about the game: it looks absolutely incredible, the weather effects are great, the combat is satisfying, and the new enemy and ally AI is vastly improved. However, these visuals and mechanics are all wasted if the most important central aspect of the game - the forest island itself - feels like a generic featureless unity asset. 

I wish the devs the best of luck, I really hope they can turn this around and make something great, but it seems they have focused their attention on all the wrong things. They had a perfect formula, all they need to do was update the graphics and enemy AI, create a more dense and detailed island, and add fun new stuff to build and do. Instead, they decided to reinvent the wheel, and the most important and fun elements of the game have suffered as a result. Big sad :(

When people talk about this game, they mostly talk about how unfinished it is, and how it is almost laughable at how long it has been in early access. For me, I don't see a problem with it. Even without the full release coming out soon, this game would still be put high on my list of the best games in my steam library. Sure, it may be a bit shorter than the first game. Sure, it struggles a bit to keep players engaged after the end of the story, but what did people really expect? This wasn't supposed to be the next gargantuan hit of a survival game, yet even now it approaches on that goal anyways, despite all the haters. At it its base, this game truly is the sequel to the Forest. If anyone is left out there who hasn't already tried this game out, if not for the graphics alone, and are holding out because people say it is not what a game should be, then know that those people are wrong. This game feels unfinished because its potential has still yet to plateau. This game is fun. This game is repayable. Anyone who says otherwise would be more focused on the cover of a book than its actual contents. In my eyes this game was finished five months ago.

The building mechanics for this game is very intuitive compared to the first game, you have more flexibility with how you'd like to make your own structure which is always a plus. The game is beautiful, regardless of the crazies on the island; I like how the developers are continuing updating and keeping to their word and even listening to us for things we'd like to see in the game (such as drive-able golf carts). Even though there are a few bugs in the game, it does not stop the fun and some of them actually make for a pretty funny and enjoyable experience. 

My only gripe about the game is that I wish there was more wildlife in the game, specifically more predators like wolves or bears. I know it is an island but it feels sort of empty without other wildlife and it would add an extra challenge to the game trying to avoid this. I also wish there was more environmental factors like the ability for your character to develop frostbite if you are wearing something ridiculous like summer clothes on your character during the winter season.

If you are thinking about getting this game, I encourage you to do so; however, I would strongly recommend you not complete or start the actual story mode yet as more things are being added to the game and the actual story; more caves, more mutants; more boss battles, etc. With that being said, the story is kind of short and is pretty broad at the moment and does not feel well thought out yet. I would definitely encourage the developers to think about adding more details into their story to make it more immersive story-wise.

Been a fan since The Forest, at its current state, I still preferred the previous game which gave a good balance between resources, survival, and the 'horror' element of the mutants and cannibals. 

In SOTF, I felt that the food/resources are a bit too readily available (eg: MRE packs, energy drink,) that hunger/thirst did not really become an issue (which somewhat removes the challenge of trying to survive). And we see mutants/cannibals rather frequently and regularly, so much so that it lost its 'horror' when we see one. Also, it feels like there are lesser variety in terms of enemy type compared to TF. 

Overall, there are room for improvements, but still a good game to play together with your friends to build a nice base, and explore caves together. Hope the 1.0 version will be better!

Sons Of The Forest is the direct sequel and improved version of The Forest original game. It includes more content, more enemies (both cannibals and mutants, with the addition of demons), bigger map with more things to do, more items, better graphics, improved interface, completely overhauled building menu, better animations, companion system (2 companions in which 1. Kelvin, works as a dog who follows you everywhere and obeys orders and 2, Virginia acts like a cat and helps you but has her own routine and behavior)., and a lot of other great improvements
Considering at the time of this review the game is still on Early Access and hasn't been 100% finished, it is amazing the amount of content this game has. The premise of this game is the same as its predecessor, only that this time you are looking for a special operations team and uncovering the mystery of the Puffton family instead of looking for Timmy, although [spoiler] you will see plenty of Timmy in this game as well [/spoiler]
On the negative side, there a a few things that do require fixing. The game crashes every once in a while which can be frustrating, the AI somehow feels worse than in the previous game, cannibals are more abundant but all they do is raid the base every 15 minutes, and random encounters become more of an annoyance than a scary or special experience due to their frequency, the slug ammo for the shotgun is completely worthless, the attachments fit in the dumbest ways possible (take the flashlight for the shotgun as a clear example of this), corpses despawn as soon as they are out of your FOV if you kill more than 2 enemies, effigies have no use whatsoever, getting stuck in terrain can happen randomly, and finally Kelvin can get stuck too (had to play the entire game with Kelvin stuck on a lake, unable to move even when given specific commands). Overall Sons of The Forest improves in every way over its predecessor, and it is an amazing experience if you haven't played the first one, it is easier than the fist one in every single way (combat, vitals, construction, item availability and resource management) but it makes up for it with better atmosphere and more content. Bunkers are AMAZING to explore and markers make cave exploration more intuitive. Completely worth it. Considering the way this devs work on their games, I am 100% sure the final product will be even better with tons of fixes and new content to be added soon.

OLD REVIEW:
Pros:
- Game is fun with Friends 
- Exploring the world feels fresh and the graphics are beautiful
- Enemies are actually tough, which is very refreshing and always keeps you peeled
- The Weather Dynamics and seasons look like they are very good

Cons:
- This game feels very stripped back from "The Forest". What I mean by this : 
- Lack of building options, even when you have to switch mode to the old style.. There is a lack of things in the game.. Whether this is intentional or not I am not sure.. but it is not a good move
- Combat feels a bit Static here and there
- AI doesn't really feel like it has that "behaviour" system they were talking about.. Every person I have met has wanted to eat my face
- The New building mode is good, however it lacks so much functionality that you end up having to switch to the other mode to get few bits done
- Inventory size and system is nice, however the panning from left to right is way too slow, especially when you are in combat!

I do feel like there is a lot of improvements to be made and I think over time these issues should be fixed. However 100% having a lot of fun playing with people!

Bought this game on early access a few days after it was released. Spent quite a few hours into the game and it's easily one of my favorites so far. The building mechanics, exploring, story and sounds are amazing. Kelvin is a bit scuffed (but I'll forgive him for that -- he's been through a lot) however, he's still pretty useful. 

I've played both solo as well as with friends and I enjoyed it either way. I do recommend though if you prefer building most of the time to recruit a friend or two to help with resource gathering and keeping enemies at bay while you work. Otherwise, unless you have the difficulty setting set to peaceful you'll be taking frequent breaks to chop up some enemies. 

So all in all, if you like survival games or even enjoyed the previous game a lot I recommend giving this game a go.

Cant wait for the full release.
 Started playing this game around two weeks ago. Finished the story section pretty fast, with guides. The game and the dynamics are great, the graphics are beautiful to spend time in the island. The combat dynamics are fun and enjoyable enough to keep you entertained, but killing enemies still lacks some incentive beyond some ok loot you can get from them. I kept in mind this is early access but still, it comes to a point after a certain time that enemies are no longer as challenging to kill and after a while, I mean a while 80+ hours the game is repetitive. I would love to see new challenges and a sense for survival a bit more interesting, spending hours on a base and have a raid that lasts three minutes makes building the base kind of anticlimactic. As of today, the game has little incentive to explore the island beyond the loot you already now is close to your base and the main objects (which are really fun to get). That being said, the building dynamics are extremely fun, you can spend hours just building and rebuilding a base. I would like to have the cold address by being able to craft your own clothing from hides, feathers, etc. 
All this being said, this is amazing, cant wait for the full release. Congratulations to end night on making an amazing game. 
Cheers.

I was having such fun chasing squirrels down mountains, watching butterflies soar over the ponds. Watching the trees blow in the gentle autumn breeze. Playing house with my best friend Kelvin.
Thought I'd spend the day at the beach today drinking energy drinks, it was a normal day.
Until I came face to face with the pike mounted head stuffed with fingers.
Until I sat upon the throne of butts.
Until I was captured and eaten by horribly disfigured cannibalistic tribespeople who did everything they could to ruin my day.

Whether you're a horror fan or seeking a thrilling adventure, Sons of the Forest is a must-play.

The gameplay is great and the graphics look awesome, the devs at Endnight are adding new things monthly as of now. The only thing that takes away for me is that sometimes I just run out of things to do (aside from chopping trees and building houses) when I'm not working on the main story. They are continuously adding new things for me to do so i still hop on for a few hours after each update. Starting from the beginning i would say it takes roughly 15 hours to complete the story without stopping for things like building, exploring the map, etc. In total id say you have at least 40-100 hours of gameplay before you run out of things to do. I would highly recommend you pick up a copy and play it for yourself. Im really exited to see what they do for the full release of this game.

Sons of the Forest is an 'okay' game. Beautiful visuals, and better audio in comparison to the first game. However, the story feels like a dumbed-down, diluted retelling of the first game but now with some tactical guys with guns. Some story beats fly by so fast even if you played the first game I feel the game doesn't do a good job elaborating on any of it. Environmental storytelling is good but yet again... Endnight somehow manages to trip and fall over itself having such a neat concept and rushing over all of it for a boring, lackluster resolution (wtf even was that ending??). The difficulty isn't really much of an issue either as even on the hardest difficulty it still feels like a breeze, making the enemies become just a minor annoyance. While I loved the variety of enemies in this game all that fear disappears when you have a gun, I feel this game did itself a disservice by including them and that's really disappointing.

*Potential Spoilers*
While the exploration is fun, and some areas of interest are actually really neat none of that intrigue pays off in the end. I felt the scale of the island also could be reduced and nothing would have changed overall. However, I understand this game is 50% story/exploring/combat and the other 50% is base building, but those soil and water physics, tree destruction, and snow deformation, etc. is all cool.... but why? why not add that later on in polish phase and make a better connected story that makes sense. Impressive display of tech in this game but if the story sucks, who cares? Especially if you have this type of story with a time paradox, why establish this story and not play by its rules? it makes no sense. Beating the game within the time trial established (29.5 days) the reward should be the artifact is destroyed and THEN given free reign to explore if the player chooses to. Why make it a choice if there was no consequence anyways (my character was on the island for 60+ days)?.... again, creative ideas but poor execution.

Building is still about the same but with the new lumber system Endnight has somehow managed to make that more annoying. Mix that in with the friendly Ai that loves to casually stroll in front of you while building can cause the game to crash due to the buggy conflicting collision boxes. Some of the buildings and schematics are really neat though and are fun additions to the game (some I admit are even more inventive than the first game, and I love that.) 

I understand this is early access and my opinion may change over time depending on updates. I just think an intriguing premise like The Forest has such potential for a solid story but it sucks seeing it get wasted on sandbox experiences that are a dime-a-dozen.

This game honestly isnt that bad. The cannibals are pretty over powered though when you start out the game. You get killed in three hits, but they take like ten hits to kill with the starting ax. The companions are really fun and honestly at times are better than my friends lol. The biggest problem I have with the game is mostly just the cannibals from the start because they are overpowered and are hard to kill while dealing boat loads of damage. And when you die, sometimes it spawns you in the water right next to the shark, and I've died to that twice now. All in all, 7/10 game and I would say it's a little worse than the original The Forest

There's a lot of frustrating elements that still exist in this and they've got no sign of actually getting patched.
One of the most fucking annoying things in this game is hard mode. There's no change in enemy placement, no change in their armor, no change in the weapons they use, the only things that change are the INSANE buffs to their health and damage. A single cannibal can kill you in 4-5 hits if you have no armor, and they only use their fists. What makes this EXTREMELY frustrating is that I have played this with my sister and we shot a single cannibal with slightly over 20 arrows and once we ran out, we speared him to death. It was no brute, it wasn't the blue skin guys in the caves, just a regular non-mutated cannibal. They're such fucking sponges in hard mode and every single encounter has impossible odds stacked against you. They can kill you in 4-5 hits with their nails if you don't wear armor, and it takes 20+ arrows to kill them! Holy SHIT.

I, like most fans of The Forest, counted the days before its early access release. I absolutely couldn't wait. This game was my #1 wish listed game a year ago. I think this has proven both very positive and very negative for myself as well as many others. 

The game is beautiful. Fantastic visuals, weather, scenery, etc.. Once again Endnight has redesigned the building system just like the original game. possibly a slight tedious, but customization is through the roof. 

I want a game that i get engrossed with, that i can loose hours and possible days with. The original Forest gave me that. There was something about that game that grabbed my attention. I remember when I downloaded the final release and was finally able to use the key card at the underground bunker. Seeing that red hallway was such a complete 180 from being in the woods for days that it was amazing to experience. The story was something I could relate to. You felt connected to LeBlanc and to experience the moment he found Timmy and tried desperately to revive him was definitely a heartfelt moment. 

I font feel anything like that in this game. Its more cold in a sense. Like so many people have said, theirs something missing in SotF. Sure it has great visuals, its a decent survival game, the building mechanics are great, but something inst there. Sure, many people don't care about story elements, they just want survival or combat and this game has that. But for me, theirs just something off. Maybe my anticipation about the game being something amazing ruined it when I played the game. 

It was actually hard when it was first released. People complained the enemies, especially the muddies, were too difficult. This has since been nerfed. Enemies are easier and that cautious,calculated play style I loved so much is gone now. 

This game can be so much more. I want this game to be its absolute best. The devs can do a ton to make it interesting. They have before. Its a small team, but they can be creative. They've already proved that. I really hope the full release is worth it. I want a jaw dropping experience just like the first game. Come on Endnight!

Sons Of The Forest is similar to the original (The Forest) but deviates enough to be a brand new experience. Though, from my time of playing, I have encountered my fair share of bugs. Such as Stutters, Unstable frame rate even on lower settings, and some minor malfunctioning AI in Cannibals. Gameplay wise it has some things I do not find a joy to play through. A lot of the locations and items you are required to find and collect are hard to locate without searching it up beforehand. Travelling to each location can take up a fair amount of your time as well. Despite these issues, I have found that the frequent updates to Performance and Gameplay keep me coming back every now and then. The building mechanics are satisfying to toy around with. As well as the intuitive AI (When it works as intended) to be a fun and new experience each time I start a new Playthrough. If you are interested in a good survival horror game, this would be a fun time for you and your friends to try out. 7/10, would recommend! <3

Would recommend for people who love a mix of horror and survival like Subnautica, but people who love base-building survival would probably love it as well.

- Game is shorter than the first.
- Only a few enemies variety and not as creepy as the first game enemies.
- Gunplay is meh (Can be a pass since it's a unity survival game)
- No auto-save at all so your progress will be lost if you disconnect. Host and all players must save by themselves. This is so annoying especially in this age of gaming.

Overall, this game is not worth it unless it's on sale and if you're looking for something to play more of the first game but be warned, it's short and shallow.

Ahoy, fellow forest wanderers! Gather 'round the campfire, because I’ve got a tale to spin about a game that’s more thrilling than a monkey juggling bananas on a tightrope. Enter Sons of the Forest, where survival meets mystery, and the line between sanity and slipping on banana peels blurs. Picture this: You wake up on a lush, temperate island, surrounded by towering trees and the occasional coconut. Your mission? Survive, explore, and uncover secrets. But beware, my friends, for this island isn’t just any island—it’s like the love child of a rainforest and a banana plantation. The story? Well, it’s as elusive as a chameleon in a banana grove. But who needs plot when you’ve got bananas, am I right? Grab your banana-shaped pickaxe and start building! The crafting system is clunkier than a gorilla trying to peel a banana with mittens. But fear not, because nothing says “survival” like constructing a banana-themed fortress. Walls made of banana leaves? Check. Banana-powered generators? Double-check. And when the cannibals attack, just throw banana peels at them. Works every time. The environment in Sons of the Forest is downright a-peel-ing. The lush vegetation—more diverse than a fruit salad—makes you feel like Tarzan on a banana diet. The changing seasons? Imagine autumn leaves falling, revealing hidden banana caches. And the lighting? It’s like the sun peeking through banana leaves, casting golden rays on your banana-hunting escapades. Now, let’s address the elephant in the banana grove: performance. My trusty RTX 3080 chugged along like a banana boat in a storm, occasionally dipping into frame rates lower than a limbo dancer. Pop-in? Yep, leaves and rocks appeared closer than a bunch of ripe bananas. And the glitchy sound during rainstorms? It was like bananas arguing over who’s the top banana. But hey, it’s Early Access—like finding a half-peeled banana in your lunchbox. Sons of the Forest takes everything its predecessor did well and does it a little bit better. Exploring this huge, beautiful, deadly island through the changing seasons is a treat. So, my fellow banana enthusiasts, grab your vine-swinging gear, ignore the lack of plot, and dive into this banana-tastic adventure. Just remember: when life gives you bananas, make a survival game out of them! 🍌🌴

This game has one of the most interestingly programmed enemy ai systems I've every played with. The natives on this island actually seem to learn from your actions and use them against you later. If you go into this game guns blazing they will become more aggressive faster as a result and if you're like me and largely remain peaceful they will attack less. The building mechanics are all satisfying (if a little wonky at times) and it's very satisfying to watch seasons change the forest around you. Everything is visually stunning even as I turned down the graphics settings a couple notches.

Now with those good notes I need to add, If you are looking at this game for constant action, shooting and slicing, this is not the game for you. This game wins in its slow burn effect. Surviving on an island, building up a base and protecting said base with various traps home alone style are the main appeals I've seen. You can just rampage though but you'll find not much gameplay that way. The main storyline can be completed in just a few real life days.

At time of writing, this game is under a month from their 1.0 full release so here's hoping for more improvements in the future.

This game delivers in more ways than the first one ever did while still keeping things pretty simple and easy to digest. Survival is a lot easier in this one and a can be customized to cater to how you want to play which is a huge plus. Cave systems are a lot larger in this game compared to the first and they have a lot of unique things about them compared to the first game (which just contained items to progress to other caves, same thing in this game too but there's also pretty cool extras in the caves now). Companions are now here to help build bases, collect resources, and defend your bases. Lot's of new weapons and items that shake up the gameplay from the first game. Lots of returning features from the first game that get expanded on which is always nice to see.

What I REALLY enjoy is the free building you can do! No more building with blueprints to make a house. If you think of something, 99% of the time you can build it!

Early access was a bit of a rough start in terms of content, over the course of a year of this game being out the devs have added a lot of things to make this game really enjoyable to replay. The have added new structures, new caves, new outfits, new building plans, new ways to get around the map without having to craft (like the hanglider from the first game), new items, new traps, and improved the mechanics of the game since the first game.

When the full version comes out later this month (Feb 2024) I will be definitely giving it another go, making it my third time beating the game after the full release. Pick this one up, excellent game to play with minimal bugs that do not even effect the game since you hardly even see them happen.

Single Player: It's certainly different than the original and the early access version is buggy/glitchy yet but overall I think it is going to be a lot of fun even if you played the original a LOT. Would recommend, there's  lots that's new. The AI on these new enemies is kinda wild at times. Creepy factor is definitely higher in this game imo. I will say though, the new building system is kinda suck. Just makes it harder to build things. I appreciate the ability to customize buildings/structures but they should have left the basic structures on the old build side. That's really my only complaint. Expect there will be a lot more new stuff/story once the complete release comes out.

Multiplayer: I think the dedicated server side needs a lot of work yet to be considered completely playable. Notice a lot of glitching/lagging/disconnecting for no reason. Hosting a game for you and another person locally seems...ok, but notice similar issues. Not sure if I would recommend it for this just yet.

favourite game of all time without hesitation

I was addicted to the first game "The Forest" The amazing world, environment, atmosphere, and last but certainly not least the story. I waited so antsy and gitty for this games release, when the first trailer dropped. I ended up caught in a predicament of not having a way to play the game as I was on console. I had been wanting a costly personal item for years and had the money to finally purchase said item however I ended up buying a pc instead solely so I could play this game. I do not regret it at all! Endnight is one of the best companies in the gaming industry. Listening to their player base, and always knocking out the bugs and glitches. Sons Of The Forest is an absolutely astounding game! By far the most beautiful game I have ever played. The map is absolutely amazing and huge. Almost every part of it feels hand crafted and polished. I can tell so much hard work went into the world space. The animations for use of items and even weapons is very well done. The gunplay is better than most shooter focused games, and melee combat being very difficult yet rewarding. The enemy types are very unique, and perfectly designed. But where this game shines is the story. Creating a very overwhelming start. You are thrown into the dangerous horror filled world with nothing. No info, no weapons, food, water, etc. All you know is you have to survive. Personally I am a huge 80s slut and having a game that is modern set, with an 80s theme really makes it bad ass. They've done an absolute amazing job of making this game feel immersive. I felt so uneasy and uncomfortable going into bunkers and caves. You could almost feel the horrible things that had happened on this island. Being a Christian I love being able to build a giant illuminated cross at my base to represent my faith, and using a cross to burn demons. Protected by my creator I am in life as I am in this video game. Where most games being blasphemous against Christianity, and mocking it, this game makes me feel like it is supported in at least some way. (A demon from hell being set afire by just pointing a cross at it proves the existence and holiness of the Lord, and the promise from God that I will always be protected.) I love how the story is tying in Christianity and other fictional scifi aspects! I'm extremely excited for the full release, and the future after as well!!!!

Revising my whole review here since my opinions have changed up a bit.

So first of all, the most apparent improvement that they've made in this game is of course, the building. It feels a lot more immersive and hands-on compared to the previous game. And that includes the crafting in the inventory too. However, there's still the old ghost-outline builds that you can do for things like storage and decorations, but I wouldn't say it's too much of an issue.

Another thing I feel like has been improved a bit is the combat. Sure, now there's guns that make it a lot easier, but that's besides the point. The melee still feels almost as fun as the first game and there's even the return of stuff like the machete and katana (and also some new weapons like a literal guitar and golf club.) Although, I feel like there's a couple times when the enemies will kinda f*ck you over with their attacks at times.

The animations also feel a bit more fluid than some of the ones in the first game. More notably, the swinging and tree-chopping animations look noticeably better. However, at times it does feel a bit stiff. Mostly in a couple of the cutscenes, to be more specific. Sometimes it looks pretty solid, while other times it's kind of... strange looking.

An unfortunate downside to all this stuff is that there were a couple things that aren't really present in this game that were in the first. Most notably, a couple of the builds. This mostly includes stuff like boats, ziplines, and a couple more. But, the zipline builds are pretty much redundant now with the inclusion of the Rope Gun.

As of Jan 31, 2024, the full game is still about a month away from release, so some of my opinions are subject to change, but overall I think this game is pretty solid. I'd give Sons of the Forest an 8/10.

The story for Sons of the Forest isn't "bad", I just had very high expectations coming from the first game. 
However, I do enjoy SOTF more than The Forest. The building can be annoying sometimes and it does take a while to build a base, but I personally enjoy it. You can be really creative and make your own cabin from scratch or you can use blueprints. I do wish there were a few more cabin blueprints to choose from because the ones we have are quite small. 
Sons of the Forest REALLY brings out the horror aspect, especially if you're playing alone. It's terrifying. The cannibals are a huge upgrade from the first game. They're so much smarter and stronger and will ambush you. The caves are horrifying. The mutants are horrifying. Everything is horrifying.
My main gripe about the game is that the map is huge and it's hard to get around though you do have golf carts and the Knight V. I just wish there was a better way to get around the map because it can take forever and the vehicles can be annoying to find and annoying to drive. 
If you've thought about buying this game, do it. It's so addicting.

What can I say - I enjoyed the predecessor and I have certainly enjoyed this game. There are more different types of enemies now and additional weapons. Combat has remained more or less the same but one thing you notice pretty early in the game is how much darker caves have become (or how much less light your "lighter" provides, depending on the perspective). Building is just as fun if not more than in the first part and the overall atmosphere doesn't get enough recognition, especially at night. Your companions can come in handy. It does feel strange to constantly tell Kelvin what to do and takes some time getting used to. Frankly speaking, in the beginning and looking at this guy's face, I wasn't too sure whether his ineptness was caused by a head trauma or general stupidity but you do grow fond of the boy (even though he just won't fight). My recommendation: Take a friend or two, play this in co-op and enjoy the experience...

I was off-and-on this game over the span of several months. Gameplay is repetitive, unrewarding, and boring.

[h3]Repetitive[/h3]
For example, I really like using my shotgun to kill enemies, but I also dread it because I spend ammo. Then after I am out of ammo, I have to go back to a cave I already explored just to restock. But then at that point, what is the point of being resourceful? Just go to a cave, loot everything, save and quit, and effectively duplicate everything until you are fully stocked up.

[h3]Unrewarding[/h3]
Same problem as the first game: Building a base is pointless. Don't get me wrong, it's fun! And you can decorate it a lot more in this game. But what is actually the point of it? It definitely isn't storage because every item you ever need will be in your inventory at all times. It also isn't for shelter because you are safer on the move, placing tarps or hunting shelters whenever you need to. In fact, it's worse to build a base because it attracts enemies to you. Though in my playthrough, enemies disregarded my base. So much so, I never utilized a single trap. Apart from building, every new thing I found wasn't dramatically useful (with the exception of the shotgun). For example, there are 3 different axes in the game that each offer equal utility. I think one is better at chopping trees, another is slightly better at attacking but is super slow, and another has a higher block stat. This theme is found throughout most of the items in the game. Why can't there just be an item that is directly better in every way? That would make finding it very rewarding. But instead, it's just another item to collect.

[h3]Boring[/h3]
My biggest complaint is that this game puts me to sleep if I play it for more than two hours. Everything is just so, [i]painstakingly[/i], SLOW. Opening the inventory lags the game for a few seconds, then finding an item in the inventory takes forever! Panning around in the inventory is super slow. Equipping clothing is omega slow! Those last three points I made combined actually makes it slower to equip the wetsuit before diving underwater than just jumping in, even though swimming isn't as swift without it. Next, I hate when I pick up a book because then my character takes a stupidly ridiculous amount of time to inspect it and I cannot do anything within that time. And then walking and running is very slow! Even when I have the best mode of transport in the entire game (hang glider), the map is so huge that it takes such a long time to get anywhere!

I was honestly about to give the game a good review until I played it today. What happened? I beat the game. The story is the most convoluted piece of narrative I have ever witnessed in any media in HISTORY. I swear there were more coherent plots to Resident Evil 6, Polyball, f*cking idk, RAFT (2018) than this sh*t. It was actually atrocious beyond a reasonable doubt. At the very least, I think the game was more fun than its predecessor and I was going to give Endnight Games that. But I don't know anymore. Maybe it will be better when the game finally releases out of early access, but I doubt it.

I have a ton of suggestions for this game to improve, but I'll list a few of them. First of all, why do they not implement useful and fun features from the first game such as the cave map so you can actually see where you need to explore or the climbing axe so that all the verticality in the map can actually be utilized instead of acting as some annoying obstacle? Secondly, if they are going to make a survival game then please add resources! I'm not talking about logs, sticks, rocks, and leaves with their primitive building mechanics. Instead, it would be cool if there were sites throughout the map with limited (or replenishing) resources that you could use to restock your ammo or generate electricity. Something like oil that you can suck up or unrefined ore that you can mine. Because right now, it feels like a half-baked survival game with DayZ mechanics, where there are structures around the map that you loot and that's all you get in terms of resources. I want to make my own equipment and items so that my base can actually be useful.

I don't know man, play it if you want. I guess I just expect too much out of games.

Played when the game first came out and loved it. Biggest complaint, along with most other people, is how easy it is for people to join an online lobby, quickly start cheating by generating items, gear, then flying around the map. I played for a month before having my lobby ruined by a cheater and saving before noticing what had happened. When you leave a cave and want to save, you're base may have been absolutely wrecked by other players. I stopped playing after this out of frustration. Tried the game again recently due to all the updates, and it is amazing. Feels like a new game again! Imagine my surprise when my day 48 Lobby is ruined by someone joining the game and just killing Virginia and Kelvin. Full dead, no revive. Then bragging about how this is good content for their YT channel. So we are a year into early access with the same major problem as 8+ months ago. Very frustrating, yet again, to see there is no way to combat this kind of toxic player behavior. An auto save feature that could be used to revert back to would be easy enough. Suppose I am done with this game until release with fingers crossed that there is some remedy to the current issue. If it was a rare occurrence, it would be tolerable. However, it is a daily encounter. I will go from having 0 players banned from a lobby to over 10 in a single day from people joining and cheating/griefing.

As much as I enjoyed the first game, I was surprised at how little there is to actually do in Sons of the Forest. Updates throughout early access have slowly made the game artificially more difficult, while enemy AI hasn't improved in over a year, developers have removed armor and ammo sources, and even reduced the effectiveness of some weapons. Electrical system is largely incomplete and low-function, Kelvin's AI still doesn't allow him to swim after nearly a year, and Virginia is still a hit or miss when it comes to being friends. The "new" lumber system simply makes building harder and cutting down trees is mostly the same.

Sons of the Forest lacks the love that was put into the original game, this game is NOT ready for full-release.

this is one of the most punishing and annoying experiences I've personally played. everything in this game is just constantly overloading you with persistent punishing annoyances like oh you have nothing equipped we will keep putting random sh*t in your hands until you reequip something useful, the mid game which i would personally consider to be doing the story elements punishes you by making the end game of exploring and building your settlement harder with the constant annoying raids that destroys what you just built making the game turn into build a wall and then rebuild it after you just had the 500th wave of the day. switching the building end game to your mid game also punishes you by making the caves harder by spawning more enemies in the caves and over world. trying to take your time and accustom yourself with the surrounding and mechanics and story actively punishes you day by day. this is my most played game on steam and whenever someone asks if i recommend this game i always say no, i gave my hours to this game with the hope of being awarded with more content but now all i and the fan base can think of is actually asking end knight to please remove content. the map is way to huge with little actual content and after a recent update the big a** mountain in the middle of the map can no longer be scaled head on and this is especially shitty as this was everyone's main way of travel to the south part of the map for finishing up the story. Farket a creator over on you tube recently recorded the length of time it takes to travel from the lowest spawn location on the map to the south end along the sides of the map and it can take upwards to 40min the player is once again punished for just wanting to finish the game by taking away everyone's time to just walk to another side of the map. vehicles don't help much either with the knightv being far to unreliable crashing after going over a tiny stone in the road. the golf cart you are currently unable to look at your gps so you can end up wasting more of your time for going a route that may be the slowest way possible and its not nimble enough to go through trees so the reliable way of traversing with the cart is the roads which will take forever. this game needs more work than the 1.0 update will be able to achieve and not only that but i doubt the devs will be willing to delete a third of the map to make traversal more plausible. this game had everything going for it day one crashing steam the day it went on sale for early access but over time its most loyal fans have all taken a step back including creators and the modding base. these are symptoms of a game that just isnt captivating. The Forest did all of these so much better and with the devs unwillingness to copy the forest i dont thing this game has a chance of bringing back its core fanbase. i hope im wrong

2. Making The Map Smaller - Like number 1 people are not gonna build bases for the reason of the map being the size it is leading to people being just nomads but this is where the bag size comes into play limiting the amount of weapons/tools you are carrying but who is gonna do that when the map is so huge!? Well make it the forest map size but 2 and a half of that size. depends on amount of caves, bunkers, etc.

3. Add Ocean Caves - The forest had them why doesn't Sons of the forest And yes there is exit ocean caves but why not ones like the forest for example in order to obtain a crossbow you have to go out in the ocean and find floating marks of wood it would make more use of the shark and add more scary moments.

4. Combat With Some Cannibals - Although the combat is good, fighting some cannibals isn't for one "muddy" cannibals. trying to fight these guys are fine nothing hard about them except the fact you have to be looking down and swing at them, I wish these guys were more like the "skinny's" from the forest as they crawled, stood up, and twitched while walking around this gives them more character and gives the player more of a creepy feeling. it would also be more enjoyable slashing them while they are standing up.

another would be the "Heavy" I would gotta say the only change would be how much he should be able to knock you down. that's it.

6. 8. [h1]Exploring the Depths of Terror and Survival in Sons of the Forest:[/h1] [h2]A Harrowing Odyssey[/h2]


[list]
[*]Sons of the Forest, the highly anticipated sequel to the acclaimed survival horror game The Forest, plunges players into a nightmarish world of terror and survival, where every step forward is met with peril and uncertainty. Developed by Endnight Games, Sons of the Forest builds upon the foundation laid by its predecessor, offering a harrowing and immersive experience that pushes the boundaries of the survival genre.

[*]At its core, Sons of the Forest excels in its ability to deliver a visceral and intense gameplay experience that keeps players on the edge of their seats from start to finish. Set in a mysterious forest teeming with hostile creatures and enigmatic threats, the game challenges players to navigate its treacherous terrain, scavenge for resources, and fend off relentless adversaries in a desperate bid for survival. The tension and atmosphere are palpable, with each encounter ratcheting up the stakes and pushing players to their limits.

[*]Central to the Sons of the Forest experience is its emphasis on exploration and discovery. As players delve deeper into the forest's depths, they uncover a rich tapestry of secrets and mysteries waiting to be unraveled. From hidden caves and ancient ruins to cryptic symbols and supernatural phenomena, the world of Sons of the Forest is brimming with intrigue and intrigue, inviting players to piece together the puzzle of its enigmatic narrative.

[*]Moreover, Sons of the Forest boasts stunning visuals and atmospheric sound design that further immerses players in its haunting world. From the eerie glow of moonlit forests to the bone-chilling cries of unseen creatures, every aspect of the game's audiovisual presentation is meticulously crafted to evoke a sense of dread and awe. The attention to detail is staggering, with each environment brimming with life and atmosphere that draws players deeper into its sinister embrace.

[*]However, Sons of the Forest is not without its flaws and frustrations. The game's steep difficulty curve and punishing survival mechanics may prove daunting for newcomers, requiring patience and perseverance to overcome its formidable challenges. The reliance on trial and error can lead to moments of frustration and repetition, as players struggle to adapt to the unforgiving nature of its gameplay.

[*]Furthermore, Sons of the Forest's narrative and pacing may leave some players wanting more, as the story unfolds in a fragmented and cryptic manner that may leave them craving a more cohesive and satisfying conclusion. While the game's emphasis on mystery and ambiguity is part of its charm, it may leave some players feeling unsatisfied with the resolution of its narrative threads.

[*]In conclusion, Sons of the Forest stands as a testament to the power of survival horror gaming, offering players a heart-pounding and immersive experience that pushes the boundaries of the genre. With its visceral gameplay, atmospheric world-building, and haunting narrative, Sons of the Forest invites players to confront their deepest fears and embrace the unknown. While its flaws and frustrations may test the resolve of some players, its gripping atmosphere and intense gameplay make it a journey well worth undertaking. As players venture into the heart of the forest, they are reminded that in the darkness, the truest test of courage lies in facing the shadows that dwell within.
[/list]

Sons of the Forest: A Hauntingly Beautiful Dive into Survival Horror

Introduction:

Sons of the Forest, the highly anticipated sequel to The Forest, brings players back into the unsettling world of survival horror, blending elements of suspense, exploration, and terrifying encounters. As a long-time fan of the horror genre, I eagerly plunged into this eerie wilderness to experience the next chapter in the unsettling narrative crafted by Endnight Games. Here's my detailed review of Sons of the Forest, a game that goes beyond jump scares to deliver an atmospheric and chilling adventure.

Graphics and Atmosphere:

From the very beginning, Sons of the Forest captivates with its hauntingly beautiful visuals. The forest is rendered with a level of detail that immerses players in its unsettling ambiance. The play of light and shadow, coupled with the dense foliage and eerie weather effects, contributes to an atmosphere that is as atmospheric as it is terrifying.

Character models, animations, and environmental details are all meticulously crafted, enhancing the overall sense of realism. The game's lighting design plays a crucial role in creating tension, casting long shadows and illuminating the mysterious creatures that lurk in the darkness. The overall result is an environment that feels genuinely alive, in the most unsettling way possible.

Gameplay Mechanics:

Sons of the Forest retains the survival mechanics that made The Forest a standout title while introducing new elements that elevate the gameplay experience. The crafting system is robust, allowing players to build elaborate structures for defense or exploration. The sense of vulnerability is palpable as you scavenge for resources, knowing that danger could be lurking around every corner.

The introduction of new tools and weapons adds depth to the gameplay. The bow, in particular, becomes a crucial tool for stealth and survival, emphasizing the importance of careful planning and strategic use of resources. The dynamic day-night cycle and weather conditions further add to the unpredictability of the environment, creating a sense of constant tension.

Story and Exploration:

Sons of the Forest weaves a mysterious and unsettling narrative that unfolds gradually as players explore the island. The game introduces a compelling mix of environmental storytelling, audio logs, and visual cues to piece together the events that led to the current state of the forest. The sense of isolation is heightened by the enigmatic nature of the story, leaving players with a constant desire to uncover the truth behind the horrors they encounter.

Exploration is a key component of the experience, with the island offering a variety of environments to discover. From dark caves filled with ominous echoes to abandoned structures that hint at the island's troubled past, each location tells a part of the story while offering new challenges and horrors to face.

Horror Elements:

Sons of the Forest excels in delivering horror that goes beyond mere jump scares. The game relies on a combination of atmospheric tension, unsettling visuals, and a haunting audio design to create an experience that will leave players on the edge of their seats. The creatures that inhabit the island are both grotesque and terrifying, and encounters with them are pulse-pounding experiences that test your nerves and strategic thinking.

The horror elements are not limited to the creatures alone; the game introduces psychological horror elements that play with the player's perception and sanity. The result is an immersive and psychologically intense experience that stays with you long after you've put down the controller.

Multiplayer and Cooperative Play:

Sons of the Forest introduces a cooperative multiplayer mode, allowing players to team up with friends to face the horrors of the island together. The cooperative experience retains the tension and atmosphere of single-player, while also introducing strategic elements as players work together to survive.

The seamless integration of multiplayer into the core experience is a welcome addition, enhancing the replayability and offering a different dynamic to the horror. The shared experience of facing the unknown with friends elevates the emotional impact of the game, creating memorable moments of both terror and triumph.

Technical Performance:

In terms of technical performance, Sons of the Forest impresses with its polished visuals and smooth gameplay. The game runs smoothly on various hardware configurations, and I encountered minimal bugs or performance issues during my playthrough. The attention to detail in both the visual and audio aspects contributes to a polished and immersive horror experience.

Conclusion:

Sons of the Forest is a triumph in the survival horror genre, delivering an atmospheric and chilling experience that goes beyond the conventional jump scares. With its hauntingly beautiful visuals, intricate gameplay mechanics, compelling story, and relentless horror elements, Endnight Games has created a title that will linger in the minds of players long after they've left the forest. Whether you're a fan of horror games or simply looking for a truly immersive and unsettling experience, Sons of the Forest is a journey into the unknown that is well worth taking. Brace yourself for a thrilling and terrifying adventure that redefines the standards of survival horror gaming.

Here's a few opinions of someone that bought the game Day 1 but is waiting for the game to leave it's early access to come back to.

> Graphics are way more beautiful than The Forest, it's a decent upgrade.
> Gameplay itself is more diverse specially when it comes to using different weapons. You can now use more ranged weapons besides the bow.
> Building on this game is tedious but it does allow you to personalize to a nail everything in your house including using stone as a building material. I just wish you could also choose to build a full wall instead of doing it step by step by step... etc.
> The new followers! It's a great addition, Kelvin adds an interesting help for those who play solo without making it too OP and Virginia adds an interesting point of view to the history that wouldn't exist without her. She also fights and uses cute dresses! Who in the world did we find a three legged suit?!
> Ways of transport! Having one is good enough but it could be less buggy. You bump a tiny rock and are yeet all across river.
> The story is up to you to find and combine. As the old fashion Forest.
> Price is fair but if you never played The Forest or are unsure, wait for a better deal. I believe it's quite a niche to enjoy this game. 

Overall, I'd recommend and rate it a 7/10 for now. I'll update it after 22/02/2024 when the final version arrives.

I've been playing - or more accurately *trying* to play - this game since it's early access release in February of 2023. Almost a full year at this point.  I still only have 14 or so hours because of the issues the game has. It is completely broken, and I've found no way to work around it.

The audio glitch from release is still there. Nasty, overloud, corrupted static blasting from my speakers and headphones anytime wind goes through the trees or I am near water sources.

Janky, stuttery frames regardless of settings. I've even tried mods, INI edits, undervolting...you name it.

And all topped off by every single machine I try to run the game on tries to cook it's graphics card *AND* its CPU. I predictably get temps in the range of 96 to 104 C. Unacceptable, especially since other newer and graphics intensive games run in perfectly stable temp ranges of 68 to 75.

I suppose that if you have some kind of NASA supercomputer you might have an easier time. Maybe I just somehow have 3 lemon machines that will run any other game in my library but this one.

But I doubt it. If it looks like a duck, walks like a duck, and quacks like a duck...it's probably a bad and broken game.

This game is essentially a build-simulator, with survival horror elements. VR support would truly be a game changer for this title.

I am not recommending this game on the basis this review is for Early Access, and being continuously updated.

EA Feedback:

Building animations can force you to place yourself in a compromised position, causing instant death by sharpened stick.

Unforeseen inconsistencies are frustratingly present within building mechanics, (ex. inability to connect two parallel walls that form a hallway). 
It is one thing to have to rebuild, it's another when you can't discern what the architectural error responsible is. Things should better "snap" into place to ultimately facilitate what would ideally be a grid under more consistant units. The "laws" are just not intuitive, and relatively uneven when practiced. This really needs to be fixed as a core-mechanic somehow, so new players can more easily build what they envision without any awkward hiccups in their creative expression.

The entire animation for writing down instructions should be sped up exponentially.

Player takes inexplicable damage after drinking from stream. If the water is unsanitary, maybe make damage over the long-term.

The scenic introduction is too uneventful prior to the action sequence.

A Doom-style "kick" stun ability would be a very, very cool addition.

I finally beat the game
For this review I will split it into two bits
non-spoilers (gameplay)
Spoilers (story)


To start off with, the gameplay.
It is so fun, the way the building works is easily the best building mechanic in any game ive played.
The combat is alright, nothing special but I felt myself getting use to the fighting.
The enemies are really good, and very scary at times. However it can get tiring in the later game.



However

SPOILERS




The story feels very plot-holey (I understand its early access) but I found that the final boss, the science guy, just kinda felt unfinished. Weve seen him roughly twice before, and both times hes not really had any role. No real connection.
The ending itself feels rushed as during the last cutscene, when you enter the cube, suddenly Virginia and Kelvin show up, along with the scientist. But the final fight was fun, even though I felt that we needed more of a connection to the bad guy, and more love for the protagonists side guy who appears in the later game and becomes a mutant.
However, I felt that they need to focus more on the story personally.
Maybe I was not paying enough attention but I found that the bad guy was very lacking and sudden. Just kind of no real drive to kill him.
The side guy who helps you find the cube (NOT KELVIN) has no real connection to the player, as you only really meet him at the end.
As for Kelvin... I love him. I wish he had more of a role, maybe appearing to help during the final fight. Or maybe even replacing the side guy.





But all in all, a great game.
I hope they keep working on it.
I just hope that we get a more conclusive but understandable story with less plot holes.
But I still recommend it, its a fun game regardless.

To start this game is great one of my favourite survival games of all time but there are a few minor problems, like how the map is quite repetitive, the caves are a pain to complete at times and some weapons are to overpowered.

 Besides from those and a bit more the good stuff overtakes the bad stuff, for example building in this game is hard but it feels quite realistic in a sense and the combat is fun it makes you want to fight most of the time.

The story really feels like your trying to discover a mystery and most of the story is shown through little items you can find around the map.

The games graphics are done really well for a survival game of this kind, and small details like the butterfly landing on your backpack or random gore props around the map, they really add to the immersion.

This game is a nice break from all the repetitive survival games that already exist like Minecraft or Subnautica. This game is great I would highly recommend to anyone looking for a new game to try out. 8/10
