The bones of "Sons of the Forest" are fairly decent, and there is a possibility of a good game here if the developers are so inclined as to actually bring it out. It is in my opinion, WAY too EARLY to be releasing the game. The game needs more time in EARLY ACCESS to mature and develop before calling it a release candidate. There is much work to be done before calling this a real game.

BUILDING SYSTEM
A fairly robust, and yet often aggravating, building system allows you to build bases throughout the island world of the game. Unfortunately, there is absolutely no point to building a base at all in the scope of the game, other than simply for the "joy" of building something. There are no advantages to building one. There is really no challenge when it comes to inventory management, so the base doesn't provide REAL help with managing inventory.  Planting and growing stuff seems like more of an afterthought than a valid part of the game. Bases offer no real benefit when it comes to sleeping, saving or really surviving in the game. Prop up a little tarp with a stick, make a little fire - and you are able to sleep, save - and aparently none the worse for wear sleeping on the cold wet ground.

CRAFTING
Crafting is "OK", but with limited range and scope. Crafting animations are clumsy and clunky, and the game lacks any real crafting depth with progressive technoligies, unlocking new crafting stations, progressive materials, etc... basically, crafting isn't really developed - like many elements in this game.


THE WORLD
The world itself is pretty enough to look at, but largely devoid of substance. The island feels so very very empty, and almost devoid of life, despite some animals and the baddies you encounter. There just aren't enough of anything to make the island an immersive environment. There should be animals on the island that add another layer to survival; making encounters with dangerous predators a new challenge would be great. The cannibal camps are silly, and don't offer much for the story or the gameplay - neither do the "hunting parties" that come to visit your base. The NPCs feel clunky and buggy (Kelvin and Victoria), as do the cannibals and demons and whatnot. The caves add a level of creepy factor to the game, but even the caves feel devoid of real substance.

THE VEHICLES
These are the biggest joke of the game, with the Knight V, golf cart, hang glider, and the ridiculous sled. None of these "vehicles" really works well (in practice or in the scope of the environment). Golf carts would be more expected if there were paved areas and drives on the island (which is strangely devoid despite having things such as the golf course), the Knight V is totally out of place on an undeveloped island. Taking an electric monowheel through the woods and on the beaches isn't practical. The hang glider proves to be the most useless of all.

Basically, there is great potential in this game - but it has yet to be realized by the developers. I hope they will put in the work to finish this game and make it something great.

I like the feeling of this game,it's more of an open world story teller than a survival game and it also has the building part which is the most time consuming but depending on your imagination it can be the best part of the game especially if you have some friends to play with so you can build greater things and faster (I have played a full stack of 8 and we had no lag or other problems).

Now that it has an ending and you can play the full game I would say it has a pretty good story line and a good ending but you need to be paying attention otherwise the big picture is a little vague,however there are still a few minor things to be done before it gets out of early acces.

The graphics are really good but nothing more special than other games released in this era of super realistic details,I would say it's well optimized for early acces,I never had any crashes or lag spikes (I also have a high end PC).

Overall I'd say it's worth to play and it would keep you hooked for a while but it would be more fun to play it with some friends than just with Virginia and Kelvin. This is the most refined and engaging survival horror available. At times, it manages to create a great sense of serenity which is then absolutely destroyed by fear-inducing freaks. 
Building is relatively tame and simple to gauge however when building with both stone and wood, parts can intersect improperly and then look incorrect.
The storyline is at first glance quite simple however there are more details that are hard to miss and are ultimately irrelevant to the story but add a nice bit of backstory.
The game's physics are usually quite tame although when placing a large number of logs in one area, they can sometimes react unexpectedly.
Survival is quite balanced between health, hunger, water and sleep. Enemies scale quite well with progress.
I have experienced elk spawning inside my bases and repeatedly knocking me down and caterpillar, when spawned from solafite upgrading, has gotten stuck inside the ground and become impervious to all attacks except explosives  
The suppressor also visually clips in the inventory with the suppressor which is already on the pistol if you have both simultaniously.

"Sons of the Forest: A Dizzying Expedition into the Mundane"

Sons of the Forest, the highly anticipated sequel to The Forest, invites players to embark on an enigmatic journey into the heart of banality. From the creators of the original survival horror game, Endnight Games, comes an experience that will leave players questioning the very essence of their gaming choices.

Let's start with the groundbreaking graphics that defy the boundaries of pixel perfection. Sons of the Forest introduces a stunning array of colors, mostly shades of beige and taupe, that will leave you questioning the meaning of vibrant hues. The realism is so palpable that you may find yourself lost in a sea of neutral tones, wondering if you accidentally stumbled into a digital interior decorating simulation.

The game's soundtrack, composed entirely of ambient sounds reminiscent of elevator music, adds an unparalleled layer of ambivalence to the gaming experience. You'll find yourself yearning for the sweet embrace of silence as you navigate through the uninspiring landscape. The sound of footsteps on grass is so meticulously crafted that you might mistake it for a symphony of white noise. Who needs adrenaline-pumping beats when you can have the soothing melody of monotony?

Sons of the Forest introduces an innovative crafting system that will have you pondering the meaning of life as you collect an absurd variety of twigs, rocks, and leaves. Forget about the excitement of forging powerful weapons or building elaborate structures; instead, revel in the joy of crafting the world's most lackluster stick. It's survival of the blandest, and you're the unsung hero armed with a collection of underwhelming tools.

The game's AI, a groundbreaking showcase of mediocrity, features enemies that are eerily adept at mimicking the average person's daily routine. Watch in awe as cannibals casually stroll through the forest, occasionally stopping to pick virtual daisies or engage in uninspired small talk. It's a testament to the developers' commitment to realism, showcasing the uneventful existence of fictional cannibalistic creatures.

Sons of the Forest boasts an open-world environment that will leave you questioning the very concept of excitement. Explore vast landscapes filled with indistinguishable trees and marvel at the breathtaking sameness of it all. The game's dynamic weather system, featuring a perpetual state of overcast skies, adds an extra layer of monotony to your digital escapade. Prepare to be captivated by the sheer lack of visual diversity.

In the multiplayer mode, team up with friends for a social experiment in shared boredom. Engage in riveting conversations about the meaninglessness of your in-game existence as you collectively question why you chose this over more exhilarating alternatives. Sons of the Forest is not just a game; it's a communal exploration of the mundane.

In conclusion, Sons of the Forest takes the survival horror genre to new heights of tedium. From its uninspiring visuals to its lackluster gameplay mechanics, this game is a masterclass in the art of pointlessness. If you're seeking an adventure that will leave you questioning your life choices, look no further. Sons of the Forest is the epitome of gaming mediocrity.

In conclusion, Sons of the Forest is a game that exists, and that's pretty much all there is to say about it.

my son said this program is for cooking recipes so heres a easy ckocolate cake recipe

2 cups all-purpose flour
▢2 cups sugar
▢3/4 cup unsweetened cocoa powder
▢2 teaspoons baking powder
▢1 1/2 teaspoons baking soda
▢1 teaspoon salt
▢1 teaspoon espresso powder homemade or store-bought
▢1 cup milk or buttermilk, almond, or coconut milk
▢1/2 cup vegetable oil or canola oil, or melted coconut oil
▢2 large eggs
▢2 teaspoons vanilla extract
▢1 cup boiling water
▢Chocolate Buttercream Frosting Recipe
Instructions 
Preheat oven to 350º F. Prepare two 9-inch cake pans by spraying with baking spray or buttering and lightly flouring.
FOR THE CHOCOLATE CAKE:
Add flour, sugar, cocoa, baking powder, baking soda, salt and espresso powder to a large bowl or the bowl of a stand mixer. Whisk through to combine or, using your paddle attachment, stir through flour mixture until combined well.
Add milk, vegetable oil, eggs, and vanilla to flour mixture and mix together on medium speed until well combined. Reduce speed and carefully add boiling water to the cake batter until well combined.
Distribute cake batter evenly between the two prepared cake pans. Bake for 30-35 minutes, until a toothpick or cake tester inserted in the center of the chocolate cake comes out clean.
Remove from the oven and allow to cool for about 10 minutes, remove from the pan and cool completely.
Frost cake with Chocolate Buttercream Frosting.
Notes
The cake batter will be very thin after adding the boiling water. This is correct and results in the most delicious and moist chocolate cake I’ve ever tasted! xo
Freezer Friendly
Let the baked cake layers cool completely. Wrap them well with plastic wrap and then with foil. Put each layer into a freezer bag and freeze up to 2 months. To serve, thaw in the refrigerator overnight with wrapping intact. The next day, the layers are ready to fill and frost.
High Altitude: If you live at a high altitude, adjust the recipe based upon the altitude for your area. 
Nutritional information is for the cake only.

best game ever

Well wow, for an early access game this one hit the mark for sure. Just came off from beating "the forest" and jumped into this on spoiler free. 

The horror element is definitely refined in this one, they absolutely nailed the caves, although there needs to be more loot spaced out in them (maybe have mutant cannibals drop skin pouches since they no longer provide creep armor). Would be handy to have a way to check your strength level also. Armor needs a buff (perhaps damage reduction while wearing any armor at all) feels like paper most of the time, which I suppose is slightly offset by a scaling health pool. Survival elements are a  great improvement from it's predecessor, the seasons are beautiful and well designed, enemy variety is refreshing. Building is a little ridiculous at times, as you will often get into situations where you have to redo the exact same design in a slightly different order to get the click system to register, I see what they were trying to do but seems much more limiting then the first game. Combat is good, well balanced with priority on range being the limiting factor of ammo, and melee when that fails, it works, sucks not having as much upgrade variety like pumping speed or damage on certain items for freedom of choice. 

This game is breathtaking, though seems to have an odd habit of capping utilization of GPU/CPU/RAM without giving max allowed frames, despite being able to push the hardware 30% further, haven't figured that out, could just be my setup. All in all a great purchase, the map most definitely needs to be filled out more, but I imagine this is coming with the full release. If you were on the fence before, just buy it on sale, you wont regret it :)

Things i like about this game : 
1. Building mechanics are much diverse and depending on creativity.
2. The Ai companion is good to have (however the path-finding needs improvement)
3. Less Buggy and laggy compared to the previous game when entering caves, 
4. Un-aliving cannibals with different weapons are satisfying. 
5. Un-aliving cannibals with Traps are also satisfying & Hillarious. 

What i don't like : 
1. The AI companion path-finding sometimes gets stuck under a log house 
2. I understand the pitchblack darkness during night time can bring alittle horror but alittle brighter would help. 
3. Light bulbs are less bright than torch walls, from my pov, i think the illumination of light bulbs need to increase and further range. (hope the devs sees this) 
4. Couldnt interact with Virginia like how we interact with Kelvin. I guess there's a good reason. 
5. Story wise, i dont feel connected to the characters we are being introduce, unlike the previous game, We play as father who's looking for his missing son. (I still haven't completed the story, but founded the CEOs)

Here's the answer in short: If you liked the first game, you'll have fun here, but do not expect a complete evolution of the game. Even though the game isn't done yet, full release is only a month away at the time of me writing this review, and there are still some things that to me, are problems that I feel may not get fixed. The first problem is the fact that the enemies just aren't scary or threatening enough. The second problem is that it's kind of pointless to do anything. Survival is too forgiving. It is impossible to starve or die of thirst. Being cold doesn't do anything either. The enemies, again, are just too easy to put down. There is no sense of urgency regarding anything. The game is also too inherently bright and clear, I had to put my brightness to 0.00 in order to feel a little more scared. Endnight did a LOT of things right. Combat is extremely dynamic, they revolutionized the building system AGAIN, caves are easily the scariest part of your gameplay experience (Which in this case is both a good and a bad thing). I just want them to maybe give a little more purpose to ALL of that in the future.

The problems (that I have) with this game are:
No purpose/urgency to do anything
Most enemies aren't as creepy/scary/threatening as one would like them to be
The default settings are CRAP. (Brightness is too high, too easy to see and therefore removes further anxiety, boxes refill when loading up saves like the first game)
TOO EASY!!!! Even hard survival feels extremely sugar-coated compared to the first game.
Cannibals are also too easy, they go down in 2-3 hits in some circumstances and I would like to see them be much more tankier (Perhaps nine to even fifteen hits for a regular cannibal).
Creepies, even the gigantic ones from the first game, are really small and unimposing.
Story isn't very fleshed out (Though that could just be because the game isn't finished)
The map is four times as big as the first game, yet it is very empty and lacks character
The sound design just isn't as great as the first game. In the first game you would grunt and emote and scream while doing activities such as attacking or chopping down bodies, and the cannibals sounded terrifying. Here, you sound lifeless, and the cannibals sound like dogs. (I do like the sound design for the creepies though, and the composer for the game's music is amazing).
Visuals are too bright and too clear, having it be darker with less fleshed out colors and more "fog" would really help set the atmosphere even more.

TL;DR:
A lot done right, a lot could use some work. It is still fun.
This game is so fun and the full game hasnt even come out and its still super fun to play with friends and by yourself. Just remember not to kill kevin and ur good. Very realistic graphics 5 stars

This game is fun alone or with others. Exploring "zombie" ridden caves. Scavenging through cannibal camps and abandoned shacks and campsites. Play with or without modern type weapons. Build a base (if you plan on staying a while), or just blast through the story line. Either way, the exploration is fantastic. The graphics are top tier. Lastly, the game consumes a lot of time due to the involvement. My only regret is I wish I waited to buy this game when it is released.
dont die to people eaters or you kidnaped

Currently, my review is a thumbs down.
Absolutely loved The Forest and I was SO excited for this game and it's just a disappointment.

The graphics are wonderful, lots of weapons.
Crafting is annoying, building is annoying but also a little more unique so at the same time it's alright?
Hit reg is terrible on enemies/animals.
The caves are absolute sh*te, so many caves that do nothing and go no where. The caves were such fun in The Forest and these are so disappointing, they look amazing but they're just boring for the most part.
Story seems to be random and not really articulated well at all, mostly we spent our time saying 'what's happening?'

We are about about to finish the 'story' section and for the 14 hrs we have in the game, probably about 4-5 have been any actual story progression/useful caves/findings.

It's EA so bugs expected but it's so poorly optimised, getting terrible FPS for all of us with rigs more than capable to play the game on top graphics and even on the lowest it constantly takes a shit.

Oh, and Kelvin has such low health and dies much too easily. :(

All in all, it's nice but massively disappointed and not really worth the price tag currently.

Maybe this will change in the future.
Right now, we're about to finish the story and just be done with it.

Sad about it really.

Edit:

Finished the story and it is so poorly written. 
The game just doesn't make any sense, had to watch a 10 minute video on the story to understand it all.

Such a shame.

Edit Edit -

Played almost a year later after a few updates have been done.

It's better, but they still have some bugs which is bound to happen, that's fine.
There's things missing that were in the first game that I think..why have you removed this? 
Such as farms for farming.. or decorative items like the couches for inside buildings/bases.

It's enjoyable, but I loved The Forest, and it's better but it's now where it should have been on release - or even still missing something, I just wish they'd pushed it back a bit more and been more realistic. They released an unfinished product, sadly.

I got the game about a week ago and it is by far my favorite game ever. I have over 40 hours on this game and there is so much to do and the game isn't even fully out yet. I highly recommend this game.

The main improvements from the original are: More realistic building, photo realistic graphics, increase in map size. However, from my experience so far, the Sons of the Forest is simply not as good as The Forest. I've played many hours in the original and it's clear when comparing these two together what's missing from this. 

The world is much bigger and provide more verity in landscapes and building areas, yet the map is incredibly empty and lacking in content to explore.

The cannibals unfortunately have lots their spark. The original cannibals were much scarier, covered in blood, dirt, tattoos. They've scream throughout the night and run around your base with Molotov's and attack you relentlessly. In The Sons of the Forest, they're simply lack lustre. I've only come across a limited amount of them, all of which just looked like normal people, removing the horror aspect. They don't scream anymore and they move very oddly and aren't considered as a threat to the player. 

The base building although is good and has been improved on, is painfully unless. Without a serious threat of cannibals, building a base is simply not needed. You no longer need to stash bombs, armour and arrows to survive the onslaughts, because there aren't any... 

The world looks stunning and the layout is interesting but caves are simply very small, lack any content within them and have lost the horror atmosphere they once had.

Kelvin, your disabled team member, although is useful and a great addition, ruins the horror aspect of the game with his calm manor and excited responses to collected the 100th log. His silent character is almost humerus and pulls you out of the immersion. 

Following on with immersion, the players movement animations are over the top for the simplest things. Instead of reacting naturally to your environment, all hand gestures are flamboyant and over the top but more frustrating, painfully slow! 

Key changes to essential mechanics, I understand the need to change the crafting areas from the original as more space and clarity was needed whilst managing resources, but the current system is slow, clunky. In the original, the game was smoother for the player, there were simply less buttons to click to do the same thing. Managing campfires now has it's own UI menu, making the process laborious. UI changes to the crafting book are similar to the previous.

Traps have been removed from this entry as well, limiting the fun dynamics which the first game had. 

Unfortunately I could go on, but I'll wrap this up: The game has lost a lot of its atmosphere and doesn't challenge the player like the original. With UI over complication, an empty map that's far too big, laborious menus and animations you have to sit through painfully... It simply needs more work to win me over and for now, I will be sticking to The Forest until further updates.

In the current state I cannot recommend unless you are a fan of the original, but keep your eye on this because there is a lot here that is worth most of the asking price.
This is from the perspective of exclusively multiplayer sessions with 4 players.

I will revisit this review after Early Access and adjust as necessary. I am hopeful about seeing improvements.

PROS:
[b]First of all the game is beautiful and the environments are brilliantly realized[/b] from the deformation effects on the snow and sand to the trees losing material as you chop away at them and the high fidelity models for everything. The weather and god rays are also top notch and not overly emphasized. Exploring under a full moon at least once despite the dangers is a must.
To be brutally honest this feels like where most of the budget went, and for the returns on visuals to drive sales makes sense.

[b]Minimal and/or seamlessly integrated UI.[/b] Like the GPS item for a large map, although the controls are very unintuitive as I will cover in more detail later.
Interacting with your inventory, or the "quick" version, is unique and while it can be a bit of a chore to locate something the first time quickly becomes second nature and overall looks great.
The HUD gets a pass as it is mostly out of the way and provides only essential info.

[b]Vehicles.[/b] They are a blast and mostly indestructible in their current state which is great for when you inevitably wreck and get forcibly separated from them (except the golf cart).

No progression/game breaking bugs to speak of in 15+ hours of playing.

CONS:
[b]Death tis but a scratch[/b] (in online sessions). I don't know if there are plans to make dying more punishing, but currently your bag always appears right next to you, so why have it separate at all? Feels like something was cut here or is still to change.

[b]Controls.[/b] I personally would appreciate an auto-sprint feature on double taping forward or simply the ability to toggle sprint by pressing the button once until you let go of forward or run out of stam.
The scroll wheel is not seemingly used for anything, however middle mouse clicking is... for the GPS zoom levels of all things. I would really like the ability to use scroll to flip through my hotkeyed items or at the very least be able to quickly flip the pages of the guide book which goes into my next point:

[b]Unskippable animations.[/b] The worst of which are when crafting from the backpack or flipping pages in the guide book. This could be a personal failing, but would it be so unbalanced or unrealistic to be able to bulk craft multiple arrow sets for example if there are enough materials selected for crafting?
Of course we want to see the excellent immersive animations, but after the dozenth time of waiting 4 seconds to proceed it is pretty old. Since the guide book must be used to place blueprints it would be great if the buttons to flip pages did not depend on the previous page flip having completed.

[b]Minor bugs.[/b] None of which are a deal breaker in Early Access mind you, but it would be nice to see them gone.
- The minimap compass indicator does not work when you are sitting down [i]including[/i] when you are driving/riding the golf cart.
- Speaking of the golf cart you cannot pull out your GPS to navigate and must stop, get out, check GPS, then get back in to resume your journey. Possibly related to the above point.
- Inconsistent shared (can only be picked up by one person) vs instanced (can be picked up by everyone) loot. For example the guitar, certain harvestable plants, and creep from slain enemies can only be got by one player while almost everything else is able to be got by everyone.
- Additionally about creep harvesting and butchering in general if all players start the process at or around the same time, before the first person to do so finishes, everyone is able to harvest from the one corpse. This feels like an unintended duplication glitch.
- Minor multiplayer de-syncs. When the season changes, like to winter, the clients see the full change immediately while the host is just starting to smoothly transition. This also resets all GPS markers for only the clients which never re-syncs with the host as I assume this, and exploration/progress in general, is part of the local save file.

The story is a bit of a fever dream at the moment. Mechanics are fun and easy to learn. Most of the past issues have now been patched, and I haven't got much to nitpick.

Updates flow consistently and have a countdown, which is something very few developers can achieve. They have an extremely well-designed AI system for this game. It's clear that lots of blood and tears went into this, and it's visible from a mile away. It isn't easy to do what Endnight has done.

If I had any say in it, I would love to see some changes. For example, some of the hand/equipment animations are a little "stiff and clunky." Weapon attachments such as the Pistol Rail could either be removed to make room for the iron sight or add a small holographic sight. This would mean the Laser Sight would need to be remodeled to fit the pistol but would remove the unconventional rail that blocks the sight.

Flat sights should be changed to a holographic diffraction sight instead of the flat transparent emission texture. Additionally, a 'Focus sense' could be implemented, which would remove sway but introduce a small jitter when looking down the sight while holding a keybind for a short length of time.

The game is fun, creepy, and has a good sense of humor. Kelvin is very entertaining.

The map is not interesting, its same thing over and over and exploring feels worthless after first 3 hours.

Verily, the cost is just, yet the tale hath depth in a foolish manner. We expended more than ten hours erecting a foundation, unrelated to the narrative; had we not built it, the outcome wouldst have remained unchanged, for it bore no relevance to the principal story. Three of us partook in the realm, and it felt exceedingly facile, with swift resurrections and an absence of dread in facing demise. The chart lacks intrigue, repeating the same monotonous pattern, and the pursuit of discovery becomes futile after the initial three hours.

[h1]EDITED AFTER COMPLETION:[/h1]
Well hmm. I guess I'm torn up over this one, still. I finished the game, took maybe 12 hrs, all told, to get through the "story" sort of deal that the game has going on. It's a bittersweet feeling, honestly. It seems that's how beating endnight's games feel. [spoiler] In the last game, there was at least a little bit of explanation after the storyline was complete... But not here. [/spoiler] Excellent "replay" value (of sorts) in their games, though. They're a bit like minecraft and the like, where even after you're "done" playing them, you're not really "done." 


[spoiler] I got both endings to it as I chose one, and then promptly walked into helicopter blades, dying instantly. I then completed the last boss fight(s) again. Don't really need it to be THAT that realistic. [/spoiler] 

[h3] B*tches, gripes, comlaints [/h3]
link between previous game and current game could be better fleshed out in the "main" story, without collecting the [spoiler]artifacts.[/spoiler]

Also who the hell were [spoiler] the non-kelvin guy at the end cutscene; the guy trying to get in the box with you but who was pushed out? etc. etc. [/spoiler]

[spoiler] The boss fights were ok. With enough grenades, anything is possible, it seems [/spoiler]

However: [spoiler] It took me waaaaay too long to realize that the "demons" were demons, and that "bad kitty-ing" them with the cross would work on them. I don't know... I guess I was literally expecting lil' red guys with horns and tails as "demons." Pale blind guys "full scorpion-ing" you, as Rob Dyrdek would say, were not what I expected. [/spoiler] 

Similarly: [spoiler] I also didn't pick up on that you can just "bad kitty" the penultimate boss to death. I kept trying to shoot/explode the thing and it just wouldnt work. [/spoiler] 

So... yeah. It is what it is, and it was good, tbh. Begrudgingly, I'll say that. I guess it's the difference in how I wanted to play the game, and how the game wanted me to play it. As I say below in my original review, the game wants you to play stealth. I just don't do that. They want you untethered from a base, running/creeping through the forest from the various fetch-quest caves to get the several items you need to progress. 

I will point out, though, that the rebreather and grappling-hook-gun were nigh-on useless for me, save the couple instances you need them to progress to the next item. Shovel, too. So, it kind-of hurts to have to go through hell and high water (literally) to get them only to use them once-ish. The rebreather use was more or less forced on the player... By the end I said every time "gah, another fkn water portion" (*Swims downward*). 

All in all, good job. But I will say, beautiful revamp of construction. It still has its flaws now, like little log placement quirks and problems every now and then, but you took everything I didn't like about The Forest's construction and made it a zillion times better, and into a game where I actually want to build, as you can get resources back from things you've built, finally. That's hard to do as i'm not really a "building-centric" player. 

Looking forward to the release.



[h2]ORIGINAL REVIEW:[/h2]
Eh... I put "recommend" for this game as I can't stop playing it, but... it's tough. 
One of the issues it has is balance. Enemies in the game infinitely respawn, however... ammo doesn't. Thus you're forced to use spears, bows+arrows to take down the cannibals that constantly harass you. It's a little tedious. Don't get me wrong, I enjoy it, but I almost don't see it as being possible to beat in the state it is. If you check the subreddit for the game, it had steady posts up until about 10 months ago. Reason being, that was when the devs released an update to where boxes/crates didn't respawn ammo. It seems that killed the playerbase. 

The problem is that it bills itself as a base-building survival game whereas the way to play through it best seems to be to be nomadic and constantly running around the island between the places you have to go for story progression, and not building a fort/stronghold and going back and forth. It's about a month off from being released, and I don't see them "fixing" the changes they made (which were for "survival" and "realism" reasons). See what I mean? It's also a game where mutants exist, so "realism" shouldn't be a huge huge concern. 

I beat the original without guns and only poison arrows, molotovs, and prox bombs, but the same doesn't feel achievable with this one.

I mean, like I said, don't get me wrong, it's fun, but fun in a way where you get attacked, die, try again, get attacked, die, try again. If you were trying to play permadeath and not load a save, I got news for you... youre gonna have a bad time. V hard mode? Forgetaboutit.  

Passive mode is ok, if not a little too boring, ironically. I would prefer a gamemode/option like the "Vegetarianmode" of the previous game where the enemies only spawn at night, minecraft-style (didn't need to use it in the previous one, but definitely would now). As for ammo/resource spawn, the suggestions I read on the subreddit that seem best would be crates that wash up on the shore or helicopter crashes (with no survivors) containing ammo/meds/food; or an option to have refreshing containers, like the first game did. This would fix the issues the game has with ammo scarcity and infinite enemies. Others suggested being able to craft ammo.

A very enjoyable sequel to one of my favorite survival horror games, The Forest
however, as stated below the game is currently still in early access and it still has its issues.
mostly some minor bugs and the lack of content

there are a lot of improvements though, namely:
- the map has been replaced with a GPS that tells you how late it is, and tells you your exact location
- the enemy ai has made some improvements
- the graphics have improved substantially
- the gore is a lot more visceral
- cave exploration feels better
- a lot more mutants to kill, skin and make clothing out of
- basebuilding animations are fun (although it can be a bit slow
- the progress can be sped up by making your hearing impaired ai companion gather resources
- mutant girl companion

overall very enjoyable, am excited to see more of it in the future when the game fully comes out

Sons of the forest was and continues to be a wild and fun game pre-launch. from building giant wood forts, to discovering buried bunkers and treasures from forgotten civilizations, to fighting and usually running from terrifying mutants. this game is much better with friends, as lootable items in game are duplicated for each player (all loot is exclusive to each player). Compared to the first game, the gameplay and crafting is definitely a step back from the previous entry. Some people may disagree. I find the options for building options to be lacking - hopefully this changes. However, the visuals and exploration are unlike any game I've played before. Kudos to the team at Endnight for creating such an immersive and exciting experience. Excited to see what this game has to offer at full launch.

Really enjoying this game. Playing with my son, in some ways it feels very different than the original Forest, some ways better some ways worse but overall I feel its more refined. Started sort of slow, but once you get going and explore its a blast. While the inventory system looks pretty, it is a bit of a bear to use for multiple reasons. I did like how many new enemy types and whatnot there was. Definitely recommend, and its much better with a friend to play and explore caves and fight off enemies. IMO the game goes from a 7/10 to a 9.5/10 with friends. Building, exploring, spelunking, etc.... and can help when attacked. The enemies seem MUCH stronger in this one over the original Forest.
It's a fun game. But if you ask me it's definitely more fun to play with friends.

I've racked up a few hours in this game and got no further than the starting corner of the island, not because the game is bad but because the base building is excellent. I've absolutely wasted my time starting game after game after game trying different strategies out. 

Anyway... The visuals are amazing, it is absolutely stunning being in the thick forest with the morning sun pushing through the canopy, the forest feel alive!

The base building is top drawer I normally couldn't care less about this, but there is a certain level of tower defence going on here. If you're minding your own in your base preparing some supplies for the next run, you will have to defeat waves of increasingly strong and deadly enemies. I turned structure damage off because I was stuck in a loop of gather resources->fix base->defend base->eat/drink/sleep->gather resources->fix base etc etc. This does make defending your base super easy though, just get high up with a load of spears and you're golden - each to their own. The base building is as open or closed as you want it to be, be warned if you started building your own structure I would strongly recommend having a read through both versions of the book, there are some useful techniques for layering and scaffolding.

Kelvin is very useful once you understand how he works, when I first started playing I had just constructed my custom building, then went for a quick excursion and told Kelvin to collect logs and fill the holders I made. I came back one in-game day later and my holders were full of logs from my building that he dismantled!

As with the first game, the survival element is only really relevant until you've figured out the mechanics. Once you've got it down thirst and hunger won't be a problem.

Great game - I'm going to start my unknownth run, this time I think I'm going light. Storerooms in each corner of the map, no base, no defences, just a room to store stuff and move on.

Tip: The tarp can be dismantled just like everything else, you only need one.

Hear me out.

So I've played the first game like, alot, and I love it to death. I was so excited for this game when it was announced. The hype surrounding this games release was insane. It's release crashed the steam store, it had one of the best launches for a game on steam in nearly as long as I can remember. 

So, what's wrong. Or should I say, what went wrong along the way? This game has been getting regular updates since release. That's great. My issue, is that none of these updates have changed the game significantly enough to where I feel the game has enough replayability to be considered fun. There are glaring issues with this game compared to the first game, and I was hopeful, from release, that the devs would be able to mitigate this issues over time. But there's only one more update left. It doesn't look like the game is gonna get much better.

So what are the issues, specifically? 

#1 Map is way too big. If the map was more filled in with things to do and things to find and interact with then this would not be a problem. But this is not the case. The map is empty. They have been adding things to the map since release, but they have not added anywhere near enough to the map, in my opinion, to feel like they made any kind of difference.

#2 The building gets really boring, really fast. In the first game you could build relatively quickly at an expense to realism. You could make very unique custom structures too, structures that this game's building system will not allow. Every structure in this game, is based on a grid system and each log must be placed individually with an animation for each log. This is cool at first, but the charm wears off very fast. Basically, building is a lot slower and less creative in this game when compared to the first.

#3 Balancing issues. Some items are literally pointless. Good example is berries, in the first game they were actually useful but in this game you are better off forgetting they even exist. They are no good. Regular stone arrows have an insanely short distance as well compared to first game. Shooting a stone arrow, feels like you are just throwing a stone. To be fair, many of the balancing issues have been fixed, but some remain. Oh yeah, and armor in this game sucks. They need to make it better. Even the good armor can get whacked off of you like it's nothing sometimes. How tough it is to get versus how easy it is to break just feels wrong.

#4 Story sucks in my opinion. The first game had a great story with a great cliff hanger. This game disappoints in comparison. After you beat the story there is very little to do. You can go into any caves you may have missed to find some blueprints to add to your base, and just build more of your base. Other than that, and killing random enemies, there's nothing else to do.

#5 Enemies/mutants in this game suck compared to the ones encountered in the last game. An enemy that is most commonly encountered is actually the most annoying and frustrating enemies in the game. There is another one that's probably more annoying, but its far less common. The mutants in the first game were also just way scarier and much more fun to fight.

#6 Caves in this game are much worse than the caves in the last game. The way they advertised caves when they talked about the game before release was that mutants wandered from one area of a cave to the next and just clearing one section of a cave didn't necessarily make that area safe. While this is true, I have never seen mutants wander between sections of caves unless you bring them over. They can re-spawn in areas you've cleared, as in I can walk down one corridor, come back and there seems to be a chance that they have re-spawned but most of the time they are gone until I leave the cave and come back a few days later. Also the cave layouts are such a disaster in this game honestly.

#6 A lack of water craft/islands really hurts this game in my opinion. One of the worst things to be removed from the last game. Just takes even more variety away from the map.

Okay, I can probably talk about other issues, but my head hurts so let me at least address what the game does well. Here are some points I really liked about this game over the old game.

#1 The addition of Kelvin and Virginia as friendly NPC's is a good one. Being able to tell Kelvin to collect logs for you while you build does speed up the building process somewhat if you are on single-player. He can also catch fish for you, collect sticks and stones and perform other small tasks for you around your base. I find him quite useful, although he does happen to get stuck in places quite a lot. Virginia doesn't really provide much use. She will occasionally present you with a gift, but these gifts are often useless item with little value (like BERRIES). She can equip guns that you give to her and if she has guns, she can effectively help you defend your base against enemies. She is a decent shot. Problem is she likes to run off into the wilderness a lot so often, she is never present at the base when I get attacked. Got I am trying to be positive here lol. Kelvin is good though.

#2 Graphics are phenomenal. The game is absolutely gorgeous. While the map is empty as hell, some of the scenery is jaw dropping. The lighting is great and textures are realistic. Way better looking than the first game. Not much more to say other than that though.

#3 The addition of guns is a good one in my opinion. While they are very powerful weapons, the game does a good job at limiting the amount of ammo you can find. So you will refrain from using it, but when you need to use it, it's epic.

#4 Grappling is much better in this game. For late game, this is very essential. The grappling in the first game was quite annoying as you could only grapple at a downward angle. Now you can grapple upwards. This is good.

To be honest, that's it. Everything else is just the same from the last game but with a new paint job. Until the game's issues are fixed, and until the add more things to do in general, there is very little reason to play this when the last one, in my opinion, is a better game. I say all of this as there is one final update to be released soon, so if that update changes my mind then I will update my review but I am not very hopeful anymore

3/5 Listen. I played the forest. Religiously. It was scary, difficult and frustrating at times and I loved it. But....

Sons of the forest just simply does not live up. 
Pros: lore and multi-player is fun.  The camps and tunnels have been revamped and you can find little scooters and hang gliders which is cool. Building is still fun.

Cons: there's no consequences. If you die. You get your stuff back no worries. If you starve you just get slow you don't die. Same with dehydration. Unlike in the first game you can eat the human meat without getting the madness.  There just simply isn't any fear of dying or death or consequences of anything. It truly takes the stress/pressures out of the game. 

It's fun for a little bit but picking up wierd emails and fighting mouth bodied creatures just isn't enough.

Hopefully on full release these things will be adress as of right now. It's a no from me.

I just love this game.
The safe feeling i got when i first spawned to absolutely pissing my pants when exploring my first cave is just magical. The forest had this magic, but sons of the forest turned it up to 11! 
I'll now give you some tips to get the same experience as i had.
1. PLAY SINGLEPLAYER IF YOU JUST BOUGHT THE GAME.
Playing multiplayer is not a good idea if you want the game to be challenging, plus people are gonna rush the caves for the items and not let you admire the view.
2. Do not rush this game, take in the amazing views, listen to the wind blow through the trees, and piss your pants when you hear a scream from somewhere around you.
3. do the story by yourself, other people won't take it into account that you are new, they just want to build and have the stuff to do it.
and most importantly!
4. Play the way you want, even tho stronger monsters spawn when the days progress, that just makes for a good challenge.

I would love to know you guy's first "i pissed my pants" moment when playing sons of the forest or the forest for the first time, have a nice time playing!

After replaying "The Forest", and coming back to "Sons Of The Forest."

Let me say, if you're coming over to see if this one is any better, or the same, here you go.

- The gameplay. Honestly, it plays the same. BUT, there are a lot more elements from the first game that are different.
You get a map with you at all times, it's great because it tells you where your companion is, where the cave is, and is not a piece of paper. It's a GPS.
Like seasons, Winter, spring, all of that.
You get tarps, meaning everytime you're outside running around, you don't need to cut down a tree and make a temporary shelter, you can just put it down from your inventory, and sleep and save. It's a huge thing from the first game that makes this game so much better.
The AI companion. It's honestly amazing. Huge thing that makes getting logs and sticks, and just building everything better. 

Oh yeah, building in this game is SO much better. Snapping, windows, consistent traps, and traps that actually HIT the enemies? Yeah, it's actually amazing. This is one of the best building games, not gonna lie. It's really fun to build. Building in the first game was fun, but man, did it suck sometimes. This game made it even better. The updates added stones to the game and electricity, so you have a lot to work with. 

- The story.

It's a sequel to the first game, so yeah. If you haven't played the first game, please do. I won't really spoil this, so. It's simple, you play as a squad and come in looking for some dudes. Your helicopter crashes and you got an AI with you. Kinda the same as the first. 

But this game when it comes to the story, it's a lot better than the first. It plays like the first, but it also adds a lot more than just the caves. There are a lot more areas that make you question the story more. It's just nicer and you can tell if you've been in this area yet. it's really expansive in this game, and with more updates coming, the story is being expanded. Even the top rated review on this game says the game is dead, and praises the boring building system.

Although it can be very frustrating at times, this game is extremely satisfying once you establish a base and discover ways to protect it. It is certainly challenging, at times, but it can be rewarding, as well.

The contrast between the struggle of early game and taking out 4 mutants with a shotgun in that many seconds helps the player to truly appreciate how far they have progressed. With ever-increasingly powerful and violent enemies, a myriad of objectives to complete throughout the world with various levels of valuable loot, and a building system that is not perfect by any means, but is still quite intuitive and mostly works well in all ranges of game play.

In mid-game, you have the option to take it slow and just work on your base, or get aggressive and march through all objectives and get looted out. Sitting back and building an arsenal and extra supplies between missions is as simple as building adequate defense mechanism and waiting for the mutants to come knockin'.

“The Sons of the Forest” is an incredible and unique take on the open world survival genre. And is capable of capturing your attention for hours doing even something as mundane as building a large stone wall to protect you and your companion(s) from the many forces that wish you harm.

At the time of this review I have not played The Sons of the Forest to the extent that I could explore many of the new features this game offers but despite that I can tell already that the game is quite the improvement over the first game, and is still only in early access. 

But alas there is one thing, one crippling flaw of The Sons of the Forest, one i can not forgive, but I will touch on that detail later. For now I will tell you about the things that I have come across that I like.

 - Building: The new building system introduced into this game is miles better than the first, although I do not have problems with the building system present in “The Forest”, it’s ultimately boring by comparison and is not as involved. The ability to cut logs into different sizes and shapes opens up so many possibilities to explore your imagination and create magnificent structures.

 - Kelvin(I think that’s his name): Kevin is a great addition to the game, he is very handy and a nice companion, although he’s only an NPC controlled by a basic but still intelligent for a game AI, he really feels like a real guy with feelings and wants. You almost want to kiss this incredible person through your screen, so then you lean forward and purse your lips touching them to the glass of your monitor and you are instantly reminded that he is only a NPC placed into a video game and you’ll sit in front of your computer for a while after almost ashamed of yourself, but will still find yourself determined to pursue a (completely platonic) relationship with this spectacular creature seemingly made by god himself, despite the obvious limitations.

 - Combat: Combat is an improvement over the first, it plays a lot smoother and the enemy AI is more intelligent. Combat definitely seems more difficult and intimidating compared to the first game, it feels like you have to be more tactical and use more resources to your advantage to come out on top. Although, I wish Kelvin would come to your rescue whenever you get downed and carry you back to your base and care for your wounds and lay by your side and tell you bedtime stories and gently caress you when you are in need of some [strike] Super Romantic [/strike] completely platonic companionship.

 - Inventory: Inventory system is still unique and cool and is expanded from the first game giving it a visual makeover with this new and tidy mat fitted with lights and bunch of other cool stuff, the first game provided you with some sort of sheet of fabric that you would bundle all your items in, and it fit well with the setting of being stranded alone on an island with not much resources but the new inventory is pleasing to look at even if it ultimately doesn’t matter. I don’t even know why I brought this up honestly, got a little side tracked.

Alright and now I’ll reveal the one thing that I alluded to previously, the one thing that’s holding this game back from it’s potential to be the greatest game of all time, listen close Endnight Games, this could very well determine the future success of this incredible title that is only missing one crucial thing. I think you should be able to sex Kelvin, I honestly find the audacity insulting, the developers ended up creating the greatest character in fiction and didn’t let you f*ck him, talk about blue balls. Kelvin deserves the love of the player after all he's gone through, but Endnight Games in an act of extreme cruelty have denied him that not only to torture poor Kelvin but the player too. Kelvin and every player to play The Sons of the Forest knew from the very moment they laid eyes on each other that they wanted something together, something incredible, something that will transcend time, something the historians would document in great detail but still fail to capture the essence of their boundless love for each other. Now it brings up the question of whether it’s unethical or not to have hot steamy sex with someone that just received brain damage recently. Even if it is unethical to f*ck someone that isn’t mentally all there, love always wins ¯\_(ツ)_/¯.

And for that reason alone, I cannot in good faith give this game more than a 5/10, barely passing my threshold for recommending the game instead of not recommending.

I sincerely hope Endnight Games has learned something from this review and will act accordingly.

Everything about this game is top notch! I've been playing games, well, as long as they've existed! So I've seen it all.  The thing about this game that's amazing to me is that everything is photo-realistic.  The water, the trees, the people, the wildlife, even the fleshy...well, I won't give anything away, but it all looks REAL.  The density of the forest (something you might not necessarily think about) is realistic.  You have to contend with dense trees, brush, rocks, boulders, rivers, snow, storms, night, etc. all represented like you are really there.  OH!  AND THE CAVES!!!  Simply amazing.  
Sounds too are realistic, from crunching snow, to chopping wood, to flowing water, to picking berries, to wildlife trotting through the forest. I'm very glad I played this game.

Needs more blueprints and stuff to build, feels really empty, it gets boring and the building aspect is really slow. If it weren't for wemod it would have taken forever to build a custom house. This game is early access so we should expect more later on. It's fun for the most part, difficult when playing alone. There's room for improvement.

I awaited a while for this game to be released. Delayed playing it because of the lack of server files. 

A few months ago i played this on a server with some friends. My server is Limux so i had to figure out how to run a windows application on the server. After that, the gameplay was enjoyable. 

Building is probably one of the main focuses of this game. I like building so it worked out for me. With a few people you can make pretty big structures. 
Exploring the caves was fun and intense, reminded me of The Forest so that was good.
Models are better looking, more detail. 

One thing that irked me what putting heads on spikes, it turns into the same head model, at least it did at the time of my playthrough.
The story line is not complete. There are cut scenes that dont make a whole lot of sense. 
There isnt much story either. I was disappointed with how short the story was over. Was in the last cave, not knowing, but suscpecting it was the last cave. Tried to play as much as i could but only got 90 hours in. 

Ending was decent enough, it will be better once the game has been completed and polished up. 

Overall, disappointed with the state it was in when i played it. I will complete another playthrough once it the game is finished.

Not the sequel I was looking for but still a good game. The mechanics are basically all the same although I do really enjoy the log building quite a bit. If you compare with the first one, it is really similar. Same mechanics for the most part but the log building is really the best thing this game has. As most people mentioned, its not really a long game. After the main story line is complete, it's repetitive, boring and I think that's where most of the "survival" players are disappointed. Many  games we play have a story ending but we keep playing for long hours after to build massive bases that fend off hordes and push the boundaries of the game. This game has a story and a sliver extra to mess around with. Nothing super exciting  to  keep you playing for years. Even the hordes just get repetitive. Fun game, 7/10 but, like the first one, it's a quick game of puzzles more than a long term play. I will be keeping an eye out for more.

Very good game for the whole, but when compared to the first game there are differences.
- Enemies are alot stronger. When you first begin the game, enemies are impossible to beat if there is more then one. They are stronger and tend to run away to alert others more often. They dont stop either when running so unless you have a good shot your done for.

- Base building is alot more fun. Added alot more chance for creativity in the new game, Being able to split log into about 6 different ways offers alot of experimenting.

- Caves.. omg... hate them, they are much harder when compared to the old game, only ever been in one and died both times i went in. You need to be PREPARED for going into a cave with heals and ammo.

- Kelvin is a absolute G, he makes the game alot more entertaining but you feel like a dad with a child with mild problems. He does take some of the more boring aspects out of the way but make sure you dont have building damage on if hes cutting down trees nearby...

This game, I believe, is absolutely worth the money. I bought this game during the early beta phase and got to watch this game become greater and greater with each update. I spent a good amount of time playing this game while I was going through something, and it was honestly therapeutic for me. I love how the developers take in player feedback and implement it into the game, from game play to features; there's no stone left unturned, and the community management team does a fantastic job at communicating with the players. The gameplay can be difficult and stressful at first, and it's almost certain that you will die multiple times. You have to keep playing, and you will pick up game mechanics and tricks to help you survive, which make this game extremely entertaining and unique.

So in conclusion, I love this game and would never forget it for the memories it has brought me so far.

I like the building and survival elements. Honestly I think the combat is crap, and the cannibals are the worst enemies. I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2023 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Bought this game and played it way too much over winter break and had a ton of fun that being said we'll do a pros and cons list. We'll start with cons.
#1: Building can get tedious and has some annoying rules.
#2: AI feels weird at times. A group of cannibals are staring at you and you shoot their friend with an arrow and they don't immediately attack you or run away from you. It can feel strange.
#3: Story is rather short and hard to piece together.
#4: Once you have all the weapons in the game you feel a little op.
#5: In some situations the amount of enemies feels lacking.
(I've heard some people complaining there are way too many enemies but I have not experienced this.)
#6: Combat isn't too special as you simply slash, block, parry or shoot.
Now onto the pros.
#1: Atmosphere and setting are great. You really get the feeling of a dangerous, mysterious island and the dense forest makes it hard to know when you will be attacked.
#2: Massive open world map. You can go anywhere and build anywhere you want and while walking can get tedious various game mechanics to alleviate this are in-place.
#3: Building is SOO much fun. From building spike walls to giant houses or waterfall fortresses to mansions on a lake or great walls of china you can let you're imagination run wild and build whatever you want. I had that same feeling I had years ago playing Minecraft building whatever I want when I was a kid.
#4: As previous stated combat isn't special but it is fun. Dodging, slicing and parrying with swords, chopping and blocking with axes, shooting with bows and slingshots (Slingshots btw, lol) and shooting creepy crawllies with guns is all a lot of fun anyways.
#5: The variety of enemies is great. While you do eventually get used to them all, the variety of cannibals you fight and the variety of mutants makes this interesting and scary.
#6: The quirks and interactions from the AI with you and each other are fun and interesting.
#7: The survival aspect of needing/gathering food and water and creating shelter is present without being annoying.
#8: Highly customization. The settings and well as ability to create custom games with custom difficulties for individual aspects is great.
#9: You have a personal helper who follows you around who you can tell to do all the annoying stuff you don't want to do.
#10: The island really feels alive with animals weather and changing seasons, each bringing unique challenges and advantages.
#11: Good mods. Game does not have a steam workshop at time of review but the mods on other websites I've found have been virus free, (however still use caution as all downloads and websites have potential for malware) and been high quality, quirky add-ons or QOL improvements.
#12: Game feels appropriately gory and violent for the setting and situation without feeling over the top, forced, or exaggerated.
#13: Game doesn't use cheap jump scares to scare you it lets the monster and atmosphere naturally do it.
#14: Reliable, easy to use incredibly fun multiplayer.
#15: Lots of tutorials to help you if you get stuck,
#16: The music is great.
Random note: It feels very satisfying cutting downs trees in this game. Undoing all of Mr Beast's work is actually kinda fun.
And finally a feature I'm going to call neutral: An easy to use command console. Some people may hate it because it allows the potential for "cheating" and it ruins the survival experience. Some may love it as a means to focus on building or adventuring or survival or whatever it is you want out of this game. Also you can choose just, not to use it. Do not be fooled by websites that say you need to download their special "unlocker mod" or whatever to access the console, you do not. It is completely default within the game.

This game is very much many games rolled into one and done very well at that.
Whether survival, horror, building or adventure is you thing this game's got it all.
Like everything in life it is not perfect but I have really enjoyed myself playing the game and I recommend it to anyone who likes survival, horror, building or adventure games.
Thanks for reading this long winded review. I barely ever review games so that should give you a sense how much I actually like this game.

I enjoy the game, but it absolutely has issues. Mainly, that the combat is frustrating. I don't know if its just me, but half the time i hit an enemy, they are unfazed and proceed to one shot me. Another issue I have is that, as far as i can tell, there aren't weapon upgrades. From what I've played, there's the ax, the club, the spear, and the katana for melee weapons, and the guns and bows for ranged weapons. If there are stronger weapons beyond the base forms, I haven't come into contact with any. 

There's also the issue I have with building. For the most part, the building is immaculate. The issue stems from when other mechanics are added to the equation. Its not fun, to get one shot by an enemy, have to run all the way back from a camp, only to find half of my buildings are gone and whats left of them are swarmed with cannibals. If the issues with the combat weren't present, then the building wouldn't feel as temporary as it does.

I'm giving the game a thumbs up because of what it can be if my issues were fixed.

I rarely write reviews on games, but this is one of the most entertaining fun games I have played in a while. A bit of a steep learning curve but once you get the hang of it it's super fun. A few tips if you are just starting out

-always make sure you have enough materials to make bone traps, you can clear all cannibals and entire caves with just kiting them through a bone trap and resetting it.
-bow head shots will kill almost everything in one shot, so practice it and land them
-you can max stack bone armour and its fairly easy to amass them early, just burn the bodies of the cannibals for bones
-middle clicking while holding the map will zoom it in/ out
-build a base and place a GPS tracker on a stick in your base to always locate where it is
-build your base near water with fish, build a fish trap, build a drying rack, build a storage shelf and you'll have an almost unlimited source of food/ water except during winter

Building is fun, exploring is fun, combat is fun... overall it's super close to 10/10 there were a few issues with crashes/ fps/ freezing which is why its like a 9.5/10 but it is still in BETA when I was playing. Otherwise buy this game and you won't regret it.

VERY GOOD recommend

The Good

- The graphics in this game are one of the best I've seen so far, at least for the scenery.  

- The building mechanics take a little getting used to, but make the game feel more immersive 
   for a realistic survival game. 

- You can hunt, fish, forage for oysters, mushrooms and berries and can wield modern 
   weapons such as cross-bows, pistols, etc. P.S. Yes you can deforest the forest.

- There're seasons (Spring, Summer, Fall and Winter). Throughout the Winter, some 
  bodies of water freeze over which makes you find other bodies of water to live next to or 
  travel more frequent to, during the Winter months.

The Bad

- If you have an annoying friend, this game is not PvP friendly. If you "die" in multiplayer, you 
  will keep re-spawning to the same post/encampment area every time. If you decide to run 
  away without grabbing your bag, you can't pick up anything and you will only have a knife to 
  defend yourself with. 

- It seems as if there're no male deer, so your mostly killing baby deer/their mothers. The 
  deers' survival instinct is severely lacking which may be good for you surviving, but it makes 
  the game feel less realistic than what it's trying to be.

- There is very little directives on what/where you should be going or doing. If you go to a 
  marked location, the map doesn't unmark it.

I've been gaming since I was a kid playing Atari and the first Nintendo so now in my late 40s I prefer games have enough of a tutorial that I don't have to learn how to play through trial and error. This game is like Minecraft in that it drops you into the game with very little direction. That was nearly enough for me to uninstall it within my first 20 minutes... I'm really glad I didn't, because this game is so cool. I ended up grasping the basics of building only to discover that building is 90% useless and just for fun. I sort of kind of got okay at actually hitting targets with a bow. I learned to put certain things together to craft items I need often, and I once I was officially enjoying the game I got my two teenage kids to play it with me too. That was when it really became fun, as we all helped each other learn and make things and explore freaky places in the forest as well as outright terrifying caves. My youngest daughter screamed out loud more than once to turn and see an unexpected crazy cannibal lurking behind a tree near her or a really creepy monster in a cave running at us. Some of the best times though were us just sitting by a camp fire at the log cabin we built together in the chairs we made listening to the surprisingly good tunes from the radio we found and put on top of our house while just talking and watching the cute mutant gal with 3 arms and 3 legs dance and eat human body parts we hung out on a drying rack for her. Family fun. 

The graphics are great. Game is a real treat for the eyeballs when horrific gore and monsters aren't around. Default difficulty was frankly too much for me in single player, mostly due to the scarce ammunition and maybe from me trying to explore places I just shouldn't have been yet, but that difficulty was mostly fine playing with 2 other people. You can change the difficulty, but I think you won't get as much out of this game if it is too easy. I'm not a fan of horror games but fear of what's on the island is a big part of the thrill here. Still, it can be frustrating if playing solo where you don't just respawn every time you die like you do when playing with friends. 

It's just a really cool game already, and at the time of this review its still early access.
It's honestly a really decent game. I also played The Forest which is another great game.
its a really good game for people who like survival games

Here's my early access review... I will avoid spoilers such as story elements, bosses etc. Please also keep in mind I play in multiplayer so some experiences could be very different in single player.

Pros:
-Kelvin is great at filling holders and bringing resources... plus he's a goof you gotta love him
-Building system is unique and immersive
-The map is gorgeous... if you've ever been in a Northern forest you'll be a happy camper
-Virginia is great with a gun
-There are a few options for travel around the map... all of which are fun
-The traps are brilliant and hilarious
-The new mutants are unique and have incredible designs
-The sound design is amazing as long as you aren't near a waterfall (waterfall sounds seem to bug out a lot)
-Many, many unique cannibals, some with very specialised combat skills
-The weapon upgrade system is amazing and unique
-The music is amazing and sometimes reveals hints about the story
-The ending is intense and exciting
-The comedy that's in the game is great
-Guns are great but melee combat is still relevant
-Caves/bunkers look gorgeous and are mostly well designed
-The visual storytelling is brilliant
-Points of interest are worthwhile and rewards for exploring are adequate
-The cooking system is great
-Big head mode

Neutral: 
-Virginia wanders and only visits from time to time... she's more likely to visit if there's a waterfall near base
-The cannibals are very human, takes away from the horror a bit but also adds a bit of psychological horror in my opinion
-The new mutants aren't gargantuan in size... takes away from the horror element a little bit but in my opinion they are still scary
-There's no real incentive to build a large base other than for storage and the fun of building
-Certain enemies only spawn after endgame
-The hang glider is kind of useless since it's almost impossible to carry up to high vantage points after being used... hoping it gets replaced with a paraglider that can be found and stored in the inventory
-Cave D is still a bit of a maze even after it's re-design
-Armour is weaker than it was in the forest but is mostly easy to replenish

Cons:
-Kelvin is a bit buggy if working on something for too long
-Kelvin and Virginia tend to get in the way
-Kelvin and Virginia tend to get stuck really easily
-The map is huge and has a large mountain in the middle that is hard to travel over... hoping that endnight adds paths or  zipline system that is part of the map to get up the mountain. Even perhaps a ski resort with a gondola the player can power
-In winter gifts from Virginia tend to fall through the map

Overall I love this game, upon full release it may become my favourite game of all time. Despite how Kelvin and Virginia have some bugs and the AI pathing can get annoying, I love both of them and still find both to be useful. The story in early access is fascinating and it will be expanded upon full release.

Good Game, the BEST Survival-Crafting Game

The mechanics and crafting system in this game definitely outclass the first game and any other game in this genre, I spent 20 hours alone on building my base. However, I felt like this game fell short on pacing, I felt like I blinked and the game was over with a very underwhelming boss fight. Also, the idea that you can basically jump from one green dot to the next isn't as fun as needing to actually explore the caves to gain access to the other dots. The combat is fun but once you get the shotgun the game goes easy mode. In the first game you basically had to rely on your own crafting to do well in combat and it made it feel more satisfying when you killed large enemies and bosses. The story was intriguing and I see how it ties in to the first game but I do not think that you are involved with the father and son nearly enough. This game lacks the mystery that first one had. I overall recommend it, the developers haven't let us down so far and they are continuing to work on the game and while listening to feedback.

Sons of the Forest, the highly anticipated sequel to The Forest, presents a mixed bag of improvements and setbacks that leave players with a conflicting gaming experience. While the gameplay has seen notable upgrades from its predecessor, the narrative takes a disappointing dip. The graphics impressively cater to a broad spectrum of hardware but, unfortunately, occasional stutters mar the experience even for players equipped with high-end systems.

In terms of gameplay, Sons of the Forest excels, building upon the foundation laid by The Forest. The survival mechanics, base-building elements, and cooperative play options create an engaging and challenging experience that surpasses its predecessor. The Forest, known for its unique story, had gameplay that could be described as merely okay. Sons of the Forest, on the other hand, manages to elevate the gameplay, offering a more polished and immersive survival experience.

However, where Sons of the Forest falls notably short is in its narrative. The Forest was praised for its unique and intriguing story, which added a layer of mystery and excitement to the gameplay. In the sequel, the narrative lacks the same depth, leaving players wanting more from the unfolding events. Sons of the Forest missed an opportunity to build on the success of The Forest in terms of storytelling, resulting in a less compelling and emotionally resonant experience.

Graphically, Sons of the Forest impresses by accommodating a wide range of hardware, including older systems, without sacrificing visual quality. However, even on high-end machines, players may encounter occasional stutters and performance issues that, while not game-breaking, can be disruptive to the overall experience.

In conclusion, Sons of the Forest represents an upgrade in terms of gameplay when compared to its predecessor, The Forest. The survival mechanics and cooperative play options have seen improvements, offering a more refined and enjoyable experience. However, the narrative takes a step back, failing to capture the uniqueness that made The Forest stand out. The graphics, while accommodating older hardware, suffer from occasional stutters on more powerful systems. Despite its shortcomings, Sons of the Forest is recommendable for fans of the survival genre, particularly those who prioritize gameplay over narrative depth. The game's mixed bag of improvements and setbacks warrants a somewhat harsh 5/10 rating.

I like the feeling of this game,it's more of an open world story teller than a survival game and it also has the building part which is the most time consuming but depending on your imagination it can be the best part of the game especially if you have some friends to play with so you can build greater things and faster (I have played a full stack of 8 and we had no lag or other problems). 

Now that it has an ending and you can play the full game I would say it has a pretty good story line and a good ending but you need to be paying attention otherwise the big picture is a little vague,however there are still a few minor things to be done before it gets out of early acces.

The graphics are really good but nothing more special than other games released in this era of super realistic details,I would say it's well optimized for early acces,I never had any crashes or lag spikes (I also have a high end PC).

Overall I'd say it's worth to play and it would keep you hooked for a while but it would be more fun to play it with some friends than just with Virginia and Kelvin.
