(Early Access Review) I think Sons of the Forest does a lot of things right and a few things wrong which are quite noticeable to someone who has beat the original Forest game.

Pros:
- Graphics. Easily Better than the first game.
- Guns. Makes combat more versatile and allows for different approaches to enemy camps and base defense.
- Golf Carts/Knight V. Makes travelling easier and allows for funny moments and group travel in MP
- Seasons. Adds dynamic elements to the world and makes the world feel alive in an other wise dead map.
- Enemy Density. Found that I was being jumped by more than 5 enemies at some points and made the combat more fun.
- General Animations. Chopping limbs off and other role-playing animations make the game feel more immersive.
- NPC's. made delegating boring tasks and defending the base more fun.
- Demons: Fingers, Twins, Spider-Mans, and Slinky guy were cooler than the original Forest demons. 
- Cannibal Variation. fun to fight cannibals with different moves/armor/weapons. 

Cons:
- General instability/Load Times. Really slow and buggy at times (Although I don't have the best PC)
- Re-breather. Hate using this thing in caves and think it's not useful outside of them.
- Night-Vision. Make is clearer and have it use up more batteries.
- Inventory system/Storage System. Having a max of 10 ropes/X items and then having to store them on stupid ass shelves which takes so long is a horrible system. Simple Chests or a faster storage process needs to be implemented.
- Building System. No custom builds/foundations destroys creativity in building and limits Kelvins true potential. Long animations and overall build time being slower is more realistic but also bores the fuck out of me after an hour or 2.
- Food system/Drinking system. So many MRE's and Soda's which made hunting and eating cannibals practically useless.
- Lack of story outside of collectibles. More cut scenes or audio logs to give background would be better for overall interest in the story. 
- Hanging Skeletons/Bats. We can more creative Endnight cmon now.
- BIG and EMPTY map. Map is massive which is fun to traverse for the most part but my god there is basically nothing but trees for about 90% of it. More camps. More small caves that provide loot or less trees would make the exploration and discovery more satisfying. Mountain in the middle = bad traversal obstacle.
- Armor: Clothing and Armor is basically useless.
- Force uncomfortable encounters. We need to be forced into scary situations that test our skill as survivors. Have our flashlights go out or our guns jam when we are being surrounded to provide us with different approaches.
- Stealth system. Useless. Give us stealth take downs on normal cannibals and make stealth a true viable option to avoid cannibals.

Even with the cons list partially out weighing the pros I think that I can comfortable say that the game is a 8/10 and with the full release and another play through I can improve this rating. If you played the original you will def like this one.

This is one of the most fun games my wife and I have played co-op in a long time.  There's just something serene and peaceful about exploring a really vast area with all sorts of hidden secrets and discoveries to be had, meanwhile stocking up supplies to last through the winter.  And finding all sorts of new and exciting ways to cook and prepare the bountiful selection of deer, rabbit, and tasty humans.  Raw is delicious (just ask Virginia), but dried foot and finger jerky is great for when you're hiking across the island, or have a nice steaming bowl of Greg on a cold winter's morning.  

Just remember folks, friendly fire is not friendly, so do your relationships a favor and don't hit your partner with sharp stick in the back of the head... I mean, we all know you were just trying to spear another baby, but you have to wait your turn!  Plenty of babies to skewer.

Just one thing I'd like to see different.  Babies should be a good source of meat.  I mean, we can enjoy a bowl of Greg, so why not a plate of roast suckling baby.  Mmmmmmm.

the game was great, and while it lasted, the ending could not have been more disappointing. 

Its the most rushed and just beyond confusing ending ever, the storyline makes no sense. Even though the map is 4 times larger than The Forest's map i found literally everything within 18 hours of gameplay. 

They did the same thing activision did the the black ops trillogy, it stopped being good after BO3 because it just got too easy, they give you the POIs to every single location and they show every cave within like a 1000-mile vicinity it feels like. 

I've said it again but please the ending is so bad, the whole game is empty, 90% of my gameplay is building a base where I didn't even do anything in as you have nothing to defend against, some cannibals and embarrassing "mutants" that die with one fire axe swing if you target it. Me and my friends spent about 3 hours trying to find something at the top of the maps, the only useful cave out of 3 caves, which we were given to with the free gps phone thing, we found one good cave and all that had was the door to the VIP keycard. However in the bottom/main part of the map we immediately found everything we needed, a rebreather, every gun, shovel, you name it. From a total beginner's POV if you didn't build a base or anything just focused completely on finishing the game you could genuinely finish this in about 3 hours. Everything is quite literally handed to you. 

In conclusion, huge cash grab, beyond rushed, developers were in molly while making this game, game-breaking glitches (i understand that as its just-released but you can duplicate things without even trying ) I dont believe endgame cared fully on the money but i wish they just delayed it for as long as it took just to get an enjoyable game, the seasons were cool, the building is amazing and killing kelvin is funny but it just feels empty.

I have more to say but it just isnt worth it, reading the reviews on this game is more enjoyable than even playing the game.

So far I feel that the developer's made the right choice releasing the game in early access because the version we have now is Bare Bones but a good starting point. I would like for them to add smaller islands in the ocean surrounding the main island bringing back boats for players to build and not just the same ones from the forest but new variations. The shovel mechanic is really fun but under used in the game I feel we should be able to make traps using the shovel & they really should focus on hiding items all over the map making the shovel more of a focus. Also there is not enough caves to explore. With this being the sequel to The Forest you would think there would be an enormous amount of caves making the caves from the first game look like Childs play. Also there's not enough crafting options so that needs to go way up. The map is huge but nowhere near enough points of interest to keep players occupied. The story is way to short and need to be expanded. Also cannibal camps are downright awful and feels rushed together. I like to be able to make poison weapons and to increase damage output like the forest. There's not enough enemy variety. And kalvin needs to be able to use weapons. You might as well say that every aspect of Sons of the forest needs to be improved in a big way... with the game getting ready to be fully released i cannot recommend buying it. its just to empty and little has changed since i made this review

The game is prone to crashing so you could have spent a long time away from base gathering resources and the game crashes you loose a lot of progress. Also enemies do too much damage, on normal you die with two hits. (((HEAVY CANNIBAL ACTIVATE)))
Compared to the previous game crafting armour is way more difficult. You will have to find 'tape' and 'rope' from scarce boxes around the map in addition to burning enemies for bones. I don't know if its just me but seems the island map is much bigger which makes it a pain to get around. Sons of the Forest is a really unique game. I love the idea of a survival-based horror game where you end up on an island and strive to survive against the elements and cannibals who inhabit the island, and being able to build your own fortresses and bases out of your surroundings. It especially makes for a lot of entertaining and memorable moments with your friends. This game can be a little bit on the demanding side, so make sure you have the right specs to run it. SotF can also be a little challenging, especially for newcomers, but before long you'll eventually figure out where everything is and it won't be so bad anymore, and there is also a peaceful option (w/o enemies) if you want that. The only real gripe I have with SotF is with the ingame bugs, since they can be quite abundant, with clipping out of the map and weird object collision/disappearances being examples. However, I wouldn't let that stop you from having a good time, and in the end the game itself is enjoyable.

[h3]🏆 FINAL RULING 🏆[/h3]

9.0 / 10 [b] (A-) [/b]
If you don't have access to the Internet to search things up all the time to progress in this game, you are cooked.
The most amazing and realistic survival game I have ever played!

Sons of the Forest outdoes The Forest by leaps and bounds, 
as a semi-dedicated fan of crafting survival and a completionist of the previous game its apparent the dedication that sons of the forest has to its world and gameplay, thus my need to comment. 

The abundance of equipment to utilise in game (something The Forest lacked) allows a broader way to play and fight throughout the game allowing for choice of playstyle and greater enjoyment, this compliments new and creepier enemies generously scattered around the environment that make the horror element it promises, realised and very present. The improved enemy designs and behaviours make the game far more intense that its predecessor, with touches of realism in passive and hostile creatures it makes the mobs feel more alive with more unique and individual movements, fighting and interacting with these creatures feels far more calculated and less mundane than the first game. (the inventory can get really messy so for management make sure to hover over an item and click a 1 through 10 to bind an item to a key, so you can quickly switch.)

Exploration is the heart of this game, writing this while still amidst the earlier stages of the game I can attest that progress in the game is at the pace that you set, while this type of gameplay doesn’t suit people who want to speed to the end, it allows for your own path through the vast world. With google telling me main story is “12 hours 45 mins” it doesn’t have a extensive story to drag people along, but it makes up for that fact with it being a crafting survival, navigating the world yourself is paramount to enjoying the game this way. As a person able to enable maximum graphics, the beauty of the world and the minute details it has in its environment that make you think “wow they didn’t need to add that but they did” is the exact reason I believe the map they’ve created deserves praise, changing seasons, beautiful water and natural landscape to admire while being chased for your life, just what everyone wants. Did it live up to its trailers? I can say it differs from the cinematic trailers that shocked us before release, but it does live up to them. It grants what was promised.

In terms of creation, and the grind that gamers seek so dearly sons of the forest has a more customisable building mechanic, still with the base blueprint fill in ability as the first game. Meaning, if you want large custom builds at unique angles or just want a pre-built home both are available, given you collect the copious amount of resources, naturally. As a player, I enjoy having the ability to have a level of organisation and protection, as if it’s a wave by wave defence on my base. But if you don’t care, then you don’t have to bother with many save points around the map making building merely an option for those who want to prolong their experience. 

While earlier versions may have lacked finesse and been unstable, a cause of distress, the game in its current state has improved and is in the last stages before being out of early access. Crashes for my higher end performing pc is no longer a plaguing issue as it was near release, however for those that may have lower specs save regularly as a precaution. The minor bugs make the game more fun, in my eyes, with the funky physics and clipping sometimes causing a laugh but nothing that inconveniences progress. 

Overall, despite imperfections as all games have, I believe that this game is worth buying and playing, especially with friends. For lovers of The forest, and lovers of open world crafting survival horror (I swear that’s not a niche as it sounds) give it a look over. I recommend this game, but that’s just my preference.

The game is great and I'm a big fan of the Forest and Sons of the Forest series. However...

The map is huge. Too huge if you ask me, and the creation of it was not thought through in my opinion. Most of the important storyline places and cool POIs are on one side of the map while the other remains rather empty, unvisited and hard to reach because of the amount of walking it would take. There's a giant mountain in the middle that is dreadful to pass through by any means (glider/knight/sled and you'd have to be crazy to drive a golf cart there). The golf cart gets stuck on tiniest rocks, stick bushes and trees and destroys wooden player-made bridges ¬_¬ (and gets stuck on them too). The knight V trips over nothing on the beach. The best means to travel around the map fast is to cheat or make zipline towers but that's too much boring work (glider is cool but you need to get up high for it ofc).
I wish there was a way to mark things better like with colorful cloth sticks/icons in the Forest rather than the GPS tracker with limited pictures. Maybe customized signs with writing to point a way or mark a knight, radio or a pot would be a good idea too. I also wish we could make roads that'd stay on the map like the ones used by cannibal troops. I'd love to see more fauna. I miss aggressive/neutral animals like boars in the Forest. Could use some predators like wolves or bears in my opinion. I'd love to be able to collect different kinds of furs and make some decent clothing against the elements (winter jacket for winter season is terrible and has next to no resistance). 
You eat berries one at a time T_T It takes 5 minutes to sate hunger/water with all the berries in your inventory. Friends call me crazy for even eating them (and they're probably right). They should also give a bit more food imo. Same with shrooms.
There could be more things to build and more pot recipes. I'd love to be able to put things on a table. Especially something decorative that isn't a damn skull or other gore for once -_- Would love to be able to use the furs I mentioned earlier to decorate the chairs and make custom rugs (btw hide sofa blueprint still MIA).
I was hoping by the time it releases out of early access, we'd have more scary mutants instead of constant AI tweaks to cannibals that are basically 2 shot late game. I miss the Forests very aggressive mutant raids on our bases - that made the late game interesting. 
Caves are very well done - dark and creepy and filled with jumpscares. Wish that remained for the bunkers you go to revisit (killing all mutants there removes them forever atm). 
The main story is still kinda unclear if I look at it through eyes of a player that's never played SotF. I personally was just curious and kept digging for info and explanations on YT to actually understand it fully. 

I hope the game will still be worked on as it comes out of early access. I still feel like there could be so much more to it.

The mechanics, cannibal interactions, new weapons, the 3d printer, and the general beauty of the landscape and caves are all wonderful. The changing of seasons, the sun rays glimmering through the trees, the ocean foam cascading down the sand, the eeriness of the caves and sounds coming from the walls are all so captivating compared to The Forest. The building it also WAY more customizable than The Forest. 
Ok… now…

Being a HUGE fan of The Forest I am really missing hunting animals for their hide and having a main objective in the game which was to save Timmy. It was so amazing and fulfilling at the end when I beat it for the first time. An absolutely crazy ending, and the anticipation for the new game was substantial. 
I am finding this game to be quite boring. I really hope the game devs add a different objective other than… finding the billionaire and seeing the emails between him and his team randomly. 
I want more excitement in the story line since I’m not huge into building. I tried building a base with my friend and the cannibals got through the defensive wall every time. I could improve on my building but I felt The Forest was so much more user friendly. Also in The Forest the cannibals had very specific paths and you could build in certain places to avoid them. Here they seem to be running around everywhere with no real path.
The map is super empty as well. It’s like 3x bigger than the old map with virtually nothing in it.

After 455 hours...It's the almost perfect gave for builders...
Honestly, you can run through the main story in about four hours. 
After that, all there is to do is base building. Once or twice a day between four and eight enemy NPC's will come to attack your base. Its usually the cannibals in the afternoon around 14:00 and two or three times a season at night around 23:00 the mutants come out. 
There's no hunting, in fact, there's barely any wildlife. No quests or side objectives, there is actually no reason to explore almost 80% of the map as all of the story objectives are on one side or 15 -20% of the map. They did spread the inventory items around the map a little better than they were for early release, but once you have them there is no reason to be on that side of the world unless you just want to be.
I wound up making a save where I flew around the map spawning thousands of extra enemies just to make it interesting for a fresh play through.

I do think this would be a great game for groups to play together, especially if one person is acting like a DM. 
Using the DEV Commands to summon enemies and adding or removing things. 
But for solo play... if your not into building then probably don't waste your money.

If you enjoyed the original game, this will be a mediocre followup. If you never played the first game, this will be a mediocre game. While there are a lot of cool new mechanics introduced in this game over the previous, the big area that is lacking is content. Once you figure out what is going on, and especially once you get guns, the game becomes almost trivial, where you are just completing steps to get to the ending, not to experience a story. Unless you really want to know what happens next, I would recommend just replaying the first game as you have likely forgotten it's story by now anyways.

**OUTDATED REVIEW**

Well i didn't expected to have finished product, because of course its a early access stage. Basically the progress seems similar to the The Forest, most of cutscenes and animation ( especially ending ) is still like in Alpha.

Design is overall good, same like gameplay, however there is some things that i miss from The Forest.

- The island of the Sons of the forest is unfortunately worse than The Forest island, at least for now.
Island itself is big, but mostly is empty and you have repetitive locations like abandoned camps or villages, they are not really unique to each other, exploring outside of the map seems boring, there is lack of The mystery of island and there is no really memorable or iconic places like for example sinkhole in The Forest.

- Some known features has disappeared, like for example log cart, some structure recipes or sickness, you don't need worry to get infected by drinking water from the river, because there is no even a feature to boil the water, there is also lack of the upgrading melee weapons. I know its early access, but for me it seems weird that something what was created before, couldn't appear in the next title

- I like the idea of having friends - kelvin seems useful sometimes but not in everything, his AI is a bit junky from the time to time, it would be nice if he get some of voice lines in future. Also character Virginia is quite interesting, however i see here a bit wasted potential letting her just randomly wandering near of your camp, it should have more interesting background view of this character, maybe some of unique quest, before getting her?

- Main Story line seems confusing - you are not sure when you exploring or progressing further, don't wanna spoil anything, but if you see ''Bronze metal doors with hand print on it'' its a final stage of the game, so if you think you didn't explore enough the game, just stay away from them.

However i enjoying playing it and I keep hoping that the final version will be better than the forest in every aspect.

With over 200 hours in so far this game has come a long way since its launch. The game has had major biome overhauls and the caves have been extended and detailed with new hanging bodies, hidden pathways and more gore props to give them a scarier feel. The world outside of the caves is beautiful to look at and is full of cannibal camps, abandoned shacks, bunkers and random camp sites to loot. Though it could use more variety in the cannibal camps as they don't have a unique feel about them. With the updates we have got new types of cannibals that throw spears, others are armoured and some can pounce onto you in a flurry of melee attacks. Though my only complaint is they don't really have that scary feel they had from the first game and look to clean and short in appearance. Also the raids can be very random as i have my game set to have everything on max difficulty and ive never had them attack my base so far and im 40 days in..

9/10 I absolutely love this game, my only problem with this game is there is not much to do after completing the main story line, other then that great game story and atmosphere, loved the difficulty of it and highly recommend playing with a friend

Not recommended for Linux (Mint 21.2 Cinnamon at least).

The game seems to think that there is a controller attached, while there is not. This Linux has an input remapper but it's not injecting anything. It has no profile set but it comes up in Steam's controller settings. Enabling/disabling Steam's controller support doesn't change anything.
If I plug in a controller, I can play the game with that and also access the options menu of the game. There is no way to turn off controller support/detection, or even look at the keyboard bindings. (EDIT: found out that while using the keyboard in the options menu, the keybindings flicker over the controller bindings, like mentioned below, but you can't change the controller bindings to keyboard bindings, it doesn't recognize the key input)
Once in the game, the mouse actually works and the keyboard as well, but the ui, of course, still thinks you are on a controller and shows controller key hints. When you press a keyboard key, it's own hint actually kinda glitches into the controller key hint and sometimes you can make out what key it wants you to press. However, once it wanted me to do some stuff in the inventory, wich I guessd was the "i" key, I was completely lost.
Inside the menu screen there is similar bevavior but it also includes the mouse. When you move it, it shows a pointer but it gets reset to the middle of the screen like every frame or so.

So for now I unfortunately won't play this. :(

EDIT2: If I understand my issue correctly, it might be resolved by uninstalling that pre-installed remapper. But since I plan to use similar remappers in the future, and no other game has this issue (only recently switched my main/gaming pc to Linux), this is a bad option. You should be able to disable controller detection in the game or force it to use kbd + mouse.

I am going to start this review by saying this game has only two good features, the building system and the world design. Outside of that this game really sucks at being survival game. It doesn't promote surviving, instead you get all you need to survive from caves and building a base just means your shit is going to be destroyed pretty often. The controls, inventory and crafting are all really clunky for controller users. The world, while beautiful, feels very empty and sometimes doesn't work with the building causing you to spend 10 minutes trying to get something to place. My biggest complaint is the extremely outdated save system. There is ZERO auto-save and you have to manually save by building a bed or a trap tent. This has lead to me and friends losing entire days of progress due to crashes. 

Overall it isn't a bad game but every-time I play it I find myself getting frustrated with all the little stuff and putting it down for months at a time. Maybe buy it if you want to build but honestly it isn't good enough alone to sale this game.

Originally I said I would not recommend this game to people, due to the lack of variety in activities, very little endgame content, and poor community cultivation. I am happy to say that 2 of the 3 issues have been resolved, and it is clear they will be adding even more content to keep you active. There are still some small issues, like poor controller support, and just minor jank that never got ironed out, but it is not enough to warrant a bad review.

I will say, that I think an emphasis needs to be made on creating a more active and connected community. Games live on for 2 big reasons: Open source code, and community cultivation. Endnight already said they will open up modding on full release, but the community for this game feels fractured, despite evidence of a large base. I think Endnight needs to add better matchmaking, and make it easy to find groups of people that are in the stage of the game you want to be in. The official discord needs overhauling and moderation so that activity is encouraged. Lastly, there needs to be better tools for server hosts/owners to police and control their games, so that trolls and griefers get filtered out as fast as possible.

I love this game, and all I want is more community. I am on the verge of starting one myself if Endnight doesn't start doing it. I want to play with people, but it is so hard to find groups. This game would be in my top 10 games of all time if they made it easy.

P.S: FEMALE. PLAYER CHARACTERS. Seriously Endnight there are a lot of women who play this game and they still can't play as themselves.

Great game that builds significantly from the first one. Innovative gameplay mechanics, great with friends, excellent visual style, good sounds, and overall just fun to play.

Pros:

Excellent base-building mechanics.
Intelligent AI behavior.
Well-balanced weaponry.
Cons:

Insufficient content in the later stages of the game.
Persistent bugs.
Scarcity of ammunition across the map.
The game loses momentum after the first winter, offering limited activities beyond expanding your base and sporadically defending against cannibal raids, which occur roughly every three days.

Additionally, the absence of AR-style weaponry is puzzling, considering the player's role as a PMC. Given the scenario of being deployed by a well-equipped private military company, the lack of modern firearms seems weird.
In summary, the game delivers an enjoyable experience up to the point of achieving self-sufficiency. Beyond that, the excitement fades due to a lack of compelling content.

Sons of the Forest or SOTF is a nicely polished horror survival sandbox game where you are sent to investigate missing person's in a region that you soon find out to be inhabited by cannibals. I'm happy with the regular updates that bring alot of the features that we saw in the original game The Forest. Lately, it seems the focus is to release more types of mutants that want to mutilate and potentially devour your corpse. I find it frustrating at times when I'm trying to build my base up, I am attacked only to end up on a pole at a cannibal camp, cutting myself free, I grab my survival pack and run back to base, and be attacked again unless i kill the hoard of menacing mutant meat munchers. The games cannibal dynamics are broken. At times I am knocked out and taken to the cannibal camp where I am greeted by cannibal's that want to InstaKill me as I try to make my escape towards my survival pack, only to be tied up again, WTF. The building dynamics are nice, but it would be nice to be able to build the stone walls like we were able to build rock walls in the first game. I need to piece makeshift stone walls around my base that conform to the terrain because you cant build contoured stone walls. Over all, the greatness of the game overrides the headaches of dealing with broken mob dynamics. I do recommend this game and I hope that the game developers fix the spawn camping InstaKill cannibals that occur late game.

[h3]Graphics[/h3]
What can one say, it's beautiful, probably the best of all games. You need a powerful computer to handle it, but you definitely need to optimize it.
You could add ray-tracing, i.e. the icing on the cake.

Edit: They improved optimization compared to the post-launch version; now I get around 2 times more fps. They haven't added ray tracing yet, but they should, to make the game even more beautiful.

[h3]Map[/h3]
It's even big, a bit boring, there should be some random events. There are few caves, 3/4 of them are small and the rest are really well done and interesting.

Edit: They added more caves, interesting and large ones, but there aren't any where you can get lost, which is a shame. Surface villages are boring, and cannibals often appear in front of your eyes.

[h3]Mechanics[/h3]
The seasons are great, but they should be more fluid, the snow could fall and on the ground it should increase over time, as well as its melting.
Windstorms should break trees, and even badly erected structures should destroy them.

[h3]Kevin[/h3]
Great idea for him. He himself adds great publicity to the game. He's a bit silly, but he's cute and funny.

Edit: They added a bit more intelligence and commands to him, but sometimes he still doesn't know where to go, likes to walk through walls, and enjoys fishing for fish on the grass. They should add more human-like instincts to it, such as gathering food for itself, drinking and eating, adding wood to the fire, washing off blood, and so on.

[h3]Virgina[/h3]
They should add more human instincts, and also go for ammunition for weapons by itself. Currently, it takes ammunition and batteries out of nowhere.

[h3]Bugs[/h3]
There are few of them: copying logs when building, monsters that go through walls, Kevin who does not know where he is going or for what, Virgina who is lost.

Edit:They fixed most of the bugs, but sometimes the log sled likes to shoot into the sky, cannibals walking through walls, and Kevin and Virginia still have a tendency to get stuck and pass through walls.

[h3]Ideas what to add:[/h3]
Added food for farming (it's survival, after all) Cooking food on a bonfire, more interactions with Virginia, new caves, new settlements and map objects, new building objects, harder to get weapons and items.

Edit: They added things like cooking in a pot (I haven't figured out how it works yet), introduced new caves and storyline, and added new building structures.
They should add larger caves where you could get lost, introduce new cannibals (even though they said they wouldn't), and include more unexpected events in the world.

[b]The entire team working on this game did an awesome job.[/b]

Too many issues to go into, and I wish I was just joking or being too lazy to go into it... It's really just a lot of issues. Updates are so far apart and the changes they make are so damn small. They have zero communication with the playerbase. Right now, getting this game is like throwing 30 dollars in the trash. 

This game is 6 months passed its release date, so saying "this is early access" is brain damage.

Edit: Stone is really amazing. But all of the issues are still present. I take back the 30 dollars in the trash statement. Get the game on discount, it's worth it then.

Edit 2: They added the Hokey Pokey trap and some other really cool things. But most of the main issues are still present. The length of time between updates progressively gets longer. Each subsequent update gains 7 extra days from the last. This game is STILL in EA with no roadmap or end in sight.

Edit 3: Despite the last update having landed, they haven't fixed any of the issues. You can make corner ramps now. Amazing. But the foundation still buries itself into the ground and doesnt allow you to build in certain directions still if you are trying to make a big base. And I don't mean massive, I mean more than 7x7. If you try to make a 9x9 or more, you will find the logs bury themselves into the earth and limit expansion. You will spend a LONG time building your base just to find out a section of it cannont be built because of this garbage design. Mobs still spawn inside your base and can clip through the walls. Kelvin still cannot pick up small stones. You expect me to run around and find hundreds of tiny rocks for arrows? Pass. Ammo is heavily limited, even outside of hardcore. Seasons change too fast. AI are still garbage, they get stuck on everything and if you build near water, you will eventually find them at the bottom of it. Kelvin still gets stuck inside of bases, ignoring obvious doors and openings. You have do deconstruct the entire wall just for him to realize he can exit and perform his tasks. Bodies still despawn in seconds. You can't even collect them onto the same fireplace without them just disappearing. I had a whole group of bodies despawn before they could burn into bones. If you are full on a resource, you will still try to pick it up even if you DO NOT WANT TO. Small rocks are the main issue. They are everywhere, and all you want to do is pick up a stick or a log and instead you juggle a stupid little pebble instead. They added a lot of traps and visual stuff, some new building features and world visuals. But they didn't fix the root issues.

I write this review having played through this right after Early Access was released.

I loved the first game.  My group and I were eagerly looking for the second some to come out, and when it did, we pounced on it.

Sadly, the things that were expanded upon from the first game didn't add anything to the game, and other things in the game literally didn't matter.

As has been said in other posts... there is ZERO reason or need to build anything, or learn to cook anything as it adds nothing to the play strategy.

Where the first game had a "figure it out as you go" feel to it, which was fun, this game had a "You pretty much know what you need to do if you played the first one so...   we're just going to make boring time sinks between the things you need to find"

It literally felt like "OK so.. to progress, you're going to need.. THIS TOOL... where is it?  Out "THERE" (motions to the entire island)!" ... and that's the whole game.

No linear drive, no plot/story development.. just... "find.. the THING!"

What made it worse, was we were so eager we jumped right at the beginning.  Imagine spending $30 on a movie, you press play, and it's opening credits...  static... then closing credits...  only to find out 4 months from now there's going to be a SMALL piece of the story added to your movie that MIGHT make it worth the money you spent originally!

That's a terrible way to create a game.  

Unfortunately, this experience will make me gun shy on any other "Forest" game, or anything else this company produces.

With the upcoming full release i figured i should probably write a review. First things first. 

This game is the perfect example of what a Early access game should be. Endnight released it and told people it was early access and told people they would be updating it and wanted feedback. They did that plus more. The game as it is now is 1000% better then what it was on Early Release. Everyone getting this game at release is in for a treat. Not only have they fixed things and added things that the community has wanted, they have done numerous bug fixes and quality of life fixes. Now onto the review.

This game is beautiful and an absolute blast to play. I have not really played with friends that much because they have been waiting for the full release. Almost all of my 156 hours have been solo. There is always something for me to do and find. Even if it is just walking around and looking at the beautiful graphics. I love this game and cant recommend it enough if you love exploration, survival, mystery, and horror. 

Something to be aware of. This game has a steep learning curve with the building. It is not like the forest. It will take some time to get used to it. Also this game is not for the squeamish. There is a lot of gore and violence. If you have played the original forest you have an idea of what i'm talking about. All things considered tho after playing this game i can not go back to the original forest and this game has climbed to the top as the best survival horror game imo. I look forward to the hundreds of hours i will put into this game with friends and playing solo after the official release.

*12/18/23 Review Update*

S'good!

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This game is far from a state which should reach paying customers - 8 years to learn how to inefficiently use the Unity engine. CPU Utilization is a joke.

Random events being triggered which are not happening to the player. Random gunshot sound effects, nobody nearby, day 2 on the beach landing site. The game is pretty in appearance and horrendous in execution.

The mandatory companion NPC 'Kelvin' while a novel idea, is broken, to the point of being a joke in memes now. They did not make a way for the NPC to identify a tree as 'off limits' to being destroyed if player assets are associated with it, literally breaking the use of those recipes for player-built assets. This is a laughable amateur error which should have prevented the devs from adding Kelvin to the game, or done their actual jobs and released the NPC in a functional manner which was not destructive to elements of the game offered to the player.

When in-game the 'days remaining until the next update' is just a 'Gone Fishing' sign and fat middle finger to paying customers but made okay under the guise of 'Early Access'.

Endnight and other devs following this common 'Early Access' money grab should  be embarrassed and ashamed.

I regret having done so and would recommend not giving Endnight a cent until they have a product worthy of asking the public to pay for it.

[h1]this review is written at the point of the last early access update, update 15 (and some hotfixes).[/h1]
Sons of The Forest was probably the game i was the most hyped for in 2023, and it did not disappoint at all. The game is absolutely gorgeous graphic wise. I feel like if the game was developed in Unreal Engine 5 though, it would've looked EVEN BETTER, and i was also sort of hoping for it to be on UE5 but its understandable why Endnight wouldn't want to do that, now that they've learned to master Unity.
The map is HUGE, like REALLY HUGE. That is not really a bad thing but the map is also somewhat empty. You can find an occasional campsite, maybe some ponds and lakes and of course, the bunkers (and the old huts on the east-side of the map). And not just that, i feel like the game doesn't really try and make you explore the map. Caves are shown on the map already, and so is the whole geography of it, although in a past update, they did make it so that you have to discover bunkers by having to find certain laptops, which i think was a good choice. I feel like Endnight should've put some radio towers around the map, or something of that sort, which you then have to activate and it will show you some points of interests and unfogs an area of the map (similar to far cry i guess?). It would maybe make for some cool moments, like if you'd just be walking through the forest, and you're completely lost but then see a radio tower in the distance, knowing that you'll actually be able to read the map now.
To finish off about the map part, The game has a few different types of trees but its mostly needle trees and very rarely you can find leaf trees. It would be really good for the map, if Endnight would add different types of forests/biomes into the game, like maybe a birch forest, some flat plains and stuff like that, which brings me to the next point, BUILDING.

The concept of Sons of The Forests building system is amazing, being able to place the logs you've chopped wherever you want. Unfortunately, that is not the case, or at least not for the most part.
Most of the time, you can just pick up your log, and choose wherever you want to place it. But once you've placed the first log down, you are very restricted to a grid. The Forest was also very known for its unique building system, and it gave you a freedom which other survival games didnt have. Sons of The Forest, sadly took away a lot of that freedom with the grid system that they've added. You can only make a square foundation, unless you use some sort of bugs and methods. In The Forest, you could make your foundation any shape, you could even try and make it somewhat circular. I feel like this can be fixed, by being able to turn the grid on and off. Of course there is more to it but since i don't know much about programming myself, I don't even know where you would begin. There are also some bugs that I've found with the building system, like if you wanted to make your rooms a little taller, by adding a quarter log on top of a full log, you can put a ceiling on it, but for some reason, the rain will still pass through the ceiling, same goes for the snow.
To make building more interesting, i think Endnight should/could add different wood types, that all look different and can maybe be used for different things. For example, you could use the birch logs to make thinner walls, since birch trees can be smaller then something like a pine tree.
Also, maybe having a paintbrush and a bucket to paint furniture and logs/rocks would make things look even more interesting.
Lastly about building, maybe some more prebuilt cabins and blueprints would be really cool, which Endnight is already doing anyways.

Caves are a slight downgrade from The Forest. While they look visually better, they still all look very similar. Many people have mentioned, how Endnight should add different types of caves, like maybe granite caves, limestone caves and so on would make cave exploring more interesting. But the biggest problem with the caves is the fact, that they are all disconnected. This is something that was so good about The Forest, the fact that all the caves were connected with each other and you could sometimes get lost sometimes. Of course, adding back the climbing pickaxe would help with that, and would also make spelunking more interesting.

Those are probably about the most important parts in my opinion, that Endnight could improve upon and also maybe add.
Nevertheless, i am REALLY hyped for the full release of Sons of The Forest and i know Endnight is cooking up something good!

[h1] Recommended: Yes[/h1]
[b] Rating: 9.0/10.0[/b]

Summary: I completed Sons of Forest and left the island on normal mode, so I may not have full context, but ready to write a review. It feels like a survival game, and seem to force player to be resourceful and rely on crafting to survive. Ammo for guns, grenades and bombs are less plentiful, and I often had to rely on crossbows and explosive arrows to get the job done. Each enemy feels meaningful and threatening, as they could potential end any game if not careful. The island is full of cannibals and other disgusting monsters. Sometimes the cannibals come from nowhere while you are cooking something, and I might have had to run for my life. There are NPCs that are helpful, and many caves to explore. As I explored, I also felt myself to be more powerful and sustainable. It feels like an adventure. I did not play "The forest" which this game is the sequel to, and perhaps now it is the time to try it out. Also, this is an early access game, so a lot of things may still be patched.

 

[b] Pros: [/b]
[list]
[*] Surviving on the local fauna and critters feels like you can self-sustain yourself
[*] Crafting is fun. They are not redundant, and can help make a difference in survival, which I tend to see less in other games.
[*] You feel like a survivor in the forest as you pick up stones, sticks and plants which can be edible or not.. 
[*] Guns feels powerful, especially as you collect the more poweful ones and you can choose to bring them out at the critical moments like boss fights.
[*] Bows are especially fun to play with, and can help you fend off irritating cannibals with a variety of arrow types.
[*] Local cannibals are exciting to deal with, as they can be very menacing when in big numbers and living in proximity to camps you set up.
[*] Game feels like a mystery if you are into such things. How did the cannibals and mutants came about, why there are so many dead people on the island, etc.
[/list]

[b] Cons [/b]
[list]
[*] The quality and sound of guns is a bit inadequate as compared to what I hear from other games. 
[*] Selection of items feel too clunky if I had to go to the menu, or manually assign numbers all the time within inventory. This is especially while fighting enemies, since I often end up not knowing where to reach for that Molotov when I need it. Can use a UI improvement.
[*] Guns are also hard to aim, like other weapons, but I feel that's part of game design. However it makes a little less sense for why a pistol have good aim but not a shotgun with sights. Perhaps this will be patched.
[*] Some of the notes seem a bit too cryptic or useless, but I also do not know if they are supposed to be by design.
[*] The friendly NPCs can be useful but even if they are by design very docile, I don't understand how they can just sit around cowering when cannibals are threatening all our lives.
[*] Cannibals feel a bit overpowered and feels like they spawn out of nowhere and in unlimited quantities. This may depend on the difficulty, though.
[*] Torchlight and night vision googles can feel more useful. Especially night googles feel a bit too dark in caves, and don't really help you see any better than simple torches. 
[*] Nit: How come those camping tents cannot be reused by compression? Maybe game balance, but too unrealistic considering other aspects of the game.
[*] The game can make you feel extremely lost, and without adequate time, you might not know what to do next. When you are stuck: [spoiler] go look for the following: 1) maintenance card ; 2) VIP card; 3) golden armor. You have to find (1) and (2) in bunkers, and you have to find the golden armor in some cave. Try to explore each cave a bit more so you could find critical items like rifle, can-opener and other things like re-breathers and grappling hook. The internet is full of guidelines as to how you can find them , like: [url=https://sonsoftheforest.fandom.com/wiki/Sons_of_the_Forest_Wiki] Sons of forest wiki [/url] Good luck! [/spoiler] 

[/list]

"Sons of the Forest" is a gripping sequel to "The Forest" that promises an even more thrilling multiplayer experience. Set in a mysterious and dangerous wilderness, this game builds on its predecessor's strengths while introducing new elements, making it a fantastic choice for cooperative play. Working alongside friends, you'll face mutated creatures, solve puzzles, and explore haunting environments together. The collaborative aspect not only enhances survival chances but also deepens the sense of immersion and excitement as you unravel the mysteries of this eerie world. With upgraded visuals, refined mechanics, and a strong emphasis on teamwork, "Sons of the Forest" offers an adrenaline-fueled multiplayer adventure that keeps you on the edge of your seat throughout the journey.

Despite being in early access for the time being, this game is already a ton of fun. Amazing atmosphere is my first big appraisal. As someone who loves camping and the outdoors, they captured that environment very well, through all 4 seasons. The combat is fun, the story is interesting, and the crafting and building are great. There may be a few small areas that feel lacking, but the positives far outweigh the negatives, and the game still has not had its full release. Give it a try if this stuff sounds interesting to you. I highly recommend going in completely blind, whether you have played the first game or not.

Let me start off by saying that I like this game and I LOVE playing The Forest. The Forest is one of my all-time top favorite games to play with friends. That being said... 

I definitely feel like this game is weaker in terms of gameplay. While this game has beautiful graphics, an awesome AI system, and provides better building utility, it is lacking something to make it spark. I think it's awesome that Endnight Games wants to make a more proactive approach towards survival. They give you a guide on how to build and you have to follow the guide to make it work. But going through the guide is a little confusing. I think that The Forest had a much better guide, where it was easy to find everything you needed. I also wish they kept some crafting mechanics, like making snow boots or something. It kind of saddens me that animal hide isn't too necessary anymore. 

I also don't like the unnecessary details and slow scroll through the inventory. In The Forest, everything is done quickly, where you don't have to watch your person assemble bone armor, molotovs, etc. In SOTF, you have to view EVERYTHING. While it makes it more immersive, I feel that it is unnecessary. It takes a lot of time and with the amount of time it takes to scroll through your inventory, craft, and then go out your inventory, you're probably half-way dead, if not dead already. And why aren't there anymore hotkeys for your inventory??? I miss those; please bring it back! While I understand that you can just hold the I key and equip a weapon, you can only have 2 slots for weapons on it and it's not enough. I also want to quickly access other items while I'm running, not stop and hold I and pray that a cannibal will one-shot me in my attempt to switch out my weapon or heal myself. 

With all of that said, I actually like this game and I do like that it is much more difficult than The Forest. I really enjoy the unique AI features and the difference in behavior between different cannibal tribes. It's not a complete game, so I'm looking forward to seeing what is coming in the future! 

EDIT: With all of the new updates and whatnot, I can gladly change this to a thumbs up. The map is pretty huge, but with new ways to travel, hot keys, and more content, the game is starting to feel more and more complete.

Vintage chocolate chip cookies

Ingredients
150g salted butter, softened
80g light brown muscovado sugar
80g granulated sugar
2 tsp vanilla extract
1 large egg
225g plain flour
½ tsp bicarbonate of soda
¼ tsp salt
200g plain chocolate chips or chunks
Method
STEP 1
Heat the oven to 190C/fan170C/gas 5 and line two baking sheets with non-stick baking paper.

STEP 2
Put 150g softened salted butter, 80g light brown muscovado sugar and 80g granulated sugar into a bowl and beat until creamy.

STEP 3
Beat in 2 tsp vanilla extract and 1 large egg.

STEP 4
Sift 225g plain flour, ½ tsp bicarbonate of soda and ¼ tsp salt into the bowl and mix it in with a wooden spoon.

STEP 5
Add 200g plain chocolate chips or chunks and stir well.

STEP 6
Use a teaspoon to make small scoops of the mixture, spacing them well apart on the baking trays. This mixture should make about 30 cookies.

STEP 7
Bake for 8–10 mins until they are light brown on the edges and still slightly soft in the centre if you press them.

STEP 8
Leave on the tray for a couple of mins to set and then lift onto a cooling rack.

RECIPE TIPS
FREEZING THE BISCUITS
If you’ve frozen the biscuits, take them out and arrange them on a lined baking sheet. Once defrosted, pop them in a medium oven 190C/170 fan/gas mark 5 and heat for 2-3 mins to crisp up. Don’t leave them too long or they’ll dry out.

STORING DOUGH
You can keep the uncooked dough in a sealed container in the fridge for up to two weeks. Simply take some out, dollop on a lined baking tray and allow to come up to room temperature for 5 mins before baking

Perfect Survival!!! Keep going!!

As a survival game, it's absolutely brilliant. Hunger and thirst mechanics really push you to hunt, the building mechanics are great, the AI of the cannibals are all wonderfully done. That's where it stops.

If you decide to stray from sole survival and follow the storyline, you will be disappointed. You will have zero clue what you are doing the entire time unless you google walkthroughs. I will most likely change my review after the 1.0 release, hoping that they do a massive overhaul of the story, because right now, there isn't much of a story. Don't even get me started about the east side of the mountain and how there is literally no content there.

So much potential with this game, it just needs some major overhaul of it's storyline, or well, it's actually NEEDS a storyline.
I'd hoped for an improvement to the first game. The game has far exceeded those expectations. It's really great.

Congrats to Endnight. This is a beautiful game. I like hanging out in my base a night with a campfire. And during the day, I sometimes just like to admire the trees, lakes, waterfalls and creatures.

I don't play this game for the story line.  I like to build bases and ziplines all over the map. It is a creative outlet that is so much fun. Compared with the Forest, some of the tedium is removed with Kelvin. He is useful, especially with the new "maintain base" command. 

I have a large base (just sayin')  that is surrounded by a stone wall. Parts of the stone wall is also surrounded (nearly) by an electric fence. Its so much fun toying with enemies at the fenceline. Its very satisfying seeing them fry.

After nearly 400 hours, I'm maybe 1/2 way through the story line. This is the weakest part of the game. It is not really that interesting to me and you only do it to get better weapons. However, I get by with stone arrows and the shotgun if I'm gang attacked. You don't have to go far in the story to get the shotgun. (I thought it would be good to get the crossbow, but meh.) 

For my play style I like the game mostly as is. But I think there could be improvements. I think it would be better if some of the items were necessary for progress, e.g. some enemies can only be killed easily by fire, spears or the crossbow because of armour. Or, if you needed to learn a skill such as rope bridge building to cross a path to a critical item or place. I think you should have to earn a lot of the weapons by finding blueprints or the weapon its self. Too many are just given to you. And, it would be more challenging if the enemies learned how to make better armour through the game and therefore became harder to kill. Essentially, the easier levels should get a bit harder as you go along. Perhaps hard should remain the same.

  
TIPS. 

There are two ways to create a safety zone. 
1. Build stone walls or log spike walls (two layers of logs thick). The enemies can't bust through these as a general rule (you may get a freak event where several attack a wall and bust through but its the exception). Adding electric fences makes for additional fun. You can watch enemies die and then go collect stuff. Deer run into them and die. Add traps in your base for fun, but they are also not necessary.
2. Enemies drown. build a base or platform over deep lake water but just the right distance from the shore. When attacked, retreat to the platform. Enemies will try to follow you and will drown. You can have a lot of fun with this.  

Most enemies cannot jump electric fences. To keep everything out you just build extra height to the fence (above the electrified bottom rungs). To get out of the base you need to build a zip-line to get over your perimeter fence. Virginia and Kelvin find their way across electric fences, taking some damage but not dying.

The swat traps are great for taking out babies. Fun to watch. 

You can eat food raw and you are fine. Put it on a drying rack if you want it to keep longer.

Use hotkeys for all your main weapons and healing/energy mixes. 

***To enjoy the game, you need to teach yourself how to build with logs***. For building, read the survival guide carefully. It shows you a lot in pictures. Teach yourself to build flat platforms on uneven ground. Start at the lower ground and build toward higher ground. This is easier. Put in a pillar, then add a log at 45 degrees sloping down. This only works if it slopes down to higher ground or the same level. Use the game feature of placing a log under the end of the sloped down log. The game will cut the new upright log to size.  When working from high to low ground it's trickier. You need to place a pillar log on the high ground then use two logs on the lower ground. After placing a pillar on high ground, place one pillar on the lower ground at a suitable distance from the uphill pillar. Then, use your eye to cut it to the same height as the base of the uphill pillar. Then you add another log on top of the cut pillar, and place a cross-beam that will be level.

To start, I've played The Forest all the way through, the game is extremely fun and well put together. With that being said, my group and I were EXTREMELY excited for this game, Sons of The Forest.

Let's start with the great things about this game!

- Rotating seasons creates A LOT of diversity within the game
- The new AI system VAIL is extremely intimidating making the game a really fun challenge
- The graphics are phenomenal
- Improvements of certain mechanics that were in the last installment

Unfortunately that ends there and as this game sits I cannot recommend it. So I figured I would come here to share some thoughts and feedback for Sons of The Forest's.

I wanted to start with an item that has created a lot of displeasure in multiplayer sessions. Upon getting knocked down by an enemy, if a teammate revives you, you can get knocked down AGAIN quicker than you can get out of the animation, leading to very annoying and very aggravating sequences of getting knocked down 2, 3, 4, even 7 times in a row before being able to get away from the enemy. You are not given any protection while locked in the animation. Another is that upon being revived you DO NOT get up with your last used weapon. Leaving to a very aggravating dance of trying to get into the slow inventory system to get your weapon back out.

[strike]Moving onto bugs, there is a very weird water rebound bug with loose logs. If you throw logs or if logs fall into a body of water they will bounce (sometimes to the stratosphere), kind of like Black Ops 2 launch day care package bouncing. Another agitating bug is one where you get injured and then you are no longer able to access your inventory without being knocked down.[/strike]

Now for necessary quality of life changes that have to happen. Decrease enemy hitboxes. I am so tired of hitting spooky's or regular mutants from behind and getting knocked down if they swing in any direction that isn't my own. It happens ALL THE TIME. [strike]Another is the lack of a log sled. Now, the log sled doesn't have to carry nearly as much as it did in the last entry, but we need SOMETHING. Maybe it wasn't added due to collision issues that were prevalent in The Forest, but we certainly need something. Also, GIVE US BACK THE ABILITY TO BIND OUR NUM ROW TO WEAPONS WE CHOOSE.[/strike]

Now with all of that being said, I am hoping that with updates and additions to this game that it will change my review but as of this moment I cannot give it a good review. I hope that Endnight takes advantage of this Early Access and brings content in a reasonable time manner.

EDIT 02/28/2023 Number Row Binding has been added in Hotfix #2
EDIT 12/12/2023 Water rebound issue and inventory issue has been fixed. Log Sled has been readded.

I love this game.

Some friends started a server and inspired me to play, but I honestly have just as much fun playing by myself as I do with others. The atmosphere is terrifying. The dark is DARK and if you don't know what you're doing, things can get rough for a while. 

The game is gorgeous. The building (while kind of janky - again, early access!) of bases is really fun, trying to strategize what areas would make good spots and what spots seem good, but are actually awful. The cannibal AI is complex and adaptive, which really just makes the game feel that much more real. I can't express how terrifying I find the caves - especially because most light sources don't equip with good defensive weapons.

Awesome game. I don't know why that one wacko reply said the island is empty, it isn't. It is massive, but once you find one of the knights, exploring becomes so much easier. There is a ton of scattered camps, crashed things, buildings, caves, bunkers. They're spread out, sure, but it's an island. You should have to work a bit to get to point A to point B.

I love playing abandoned survival games like this one.. something about exploring the forcibly abandoned is so fun to me. Especially because there's evil things lurking in the dark.

To new players that want hints: Make armor. You can learn how to craft things by right clicking on a material in your inventory and hovering over the gear, it will show you what you can make. This game got much easier when I figured out how to make armor. Don't attack the cannibals day one or two, they'll leave you alone (the crawling ones being the exception but you can kill them). Only fight when you have to. Build defensive walls, and choose where to build CAREFULLY! Natural defenses are so helpful. Stone walls work better than Wood ones. Use Kelvin!

(Spoilers)
To the devs: You all are awesome. My only wish is to get to explore more of that beautifully abandoned resort. I love what I have explored so far and I can't wait to see this game when it is finished. Also, the story feels very vague and easily missed. I felt very confused in the end, like I had missed a ton. Fabulous job either way. Thank you for this game!!

The crafting animations are good and the additions of the guns is amazing they are not overpowered and the scarcity of ammo make you save them for fights against big mutants.  It’s easy to have 100 9mm ammo then enter a cave and leave with 7.  This is an amazing 2nd game to the forest and I would totally recommend it.  It is easy to pour hours into this game in a single session
